These measures were taken in accordance with the relevant UN Security Council resolutions. Yes. n.a. Exchange Arrangement The currency of China is the Chinese renminbi. The currency unit is the yuan. Unitary. The exchange rate of the renminbi is determined with reference to an undisclosed basket of currencies. The method for determining the renminbi (RMB)–U.S. dollar mid-rate is as follows: the China Foreign Exchange Trading System (CFETS), before the daily interbank foreign exchange market opening quote, requests quotes from all market makers of the interbank foreign exchange market. These quoted prices are used as the calculation sample for the RMB–U.S. dollar exchange mid- rate. After eliminating the highest and lowest quotes, the CFETS calculates the weighted average of the remaining quotes, which becomes the daily RMB–U.S. dollar foreign exchange mid-rate. The weighting is calculated on the basis of indicators such as the trading volume of quoting parties in the interbank foreign exchange market and the circumstances of the quotations. The mid-rate of the RMB against the euro, yen, and Hong Kong dollar is determined by the CFETS based on the mid-rate of the RMB against the U.S. dollar at 9:00 a.m. in the international foreign exchange market. Effective May 21, 2007, the band around the daily trading price of the RMB against the U.S. dollar in the interbank foreign exchange spot market was widened from ±0.3% to ±0.5%; thus, the exchange rate of the RMB against the U.S. dollar in the spot foreign exchange market may fluctuate in a floating band of within ±0.5% of the mid-rate published on the same day by the CFETS of the RMB against the U.S. dollar. The exchange rate of the RMB against other currencies fluctuates within a floating band of ±3% of the mid-rate published on the same day of the RMB against that currency. The RMB appreciated against the U.S. dollar by 6.9% in 2007. Calculated on a cumulative basis, the RMB appreciated against the U.S. dollar by 17.92% between July 21, 2005 (when the reform of the RMB exchange rate formation mechanism was initiated), and the first quarter of 2008, with the RMB appreciating by 4.07% against the dollar in the 304 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Exchange tax Exchange subsidy Foreign exchange market Spot exchange market Operated by the central bank Allocation Auction Fixing Interbank market Forward exchange market References to legal instruments and hyperlinks PEOPLE’S REPUBLIC OF CHINA first quarter of 2008. Despite the appreciation, the rate has remained within a 2% crawling band. Although market supply and demand play a role in determining the RMB exchange rate, the observed path of the exchange rate and information on intervention and reserves buildup suggest that the exchange rate is determined mainly by official action, resulting in its classification as a crawling peg. No. No. n.a. n.a. n.a. As of January 15, 2007, 22 banks had been introduced as market makers in the interbank foreign exchange market. To give market forces a greater role in determining the renminbi exchange rate, steps have been taken to liberalize and develop China’s foreign exchange markets, including the establishment of an over- the-counter spot foreign exchange market and the introduction of RMB foreign exchange forwards and swaps and currency swap derivatives. Qualified interbank foreign exchange market participants may conduct interbank RMB foreign exchange forward transactions. They may also conduct foreign exchange swap transactions six months after they receive authorization to deal in foreign exchange forward transactions and may apply to conduct RMB and foreign exchange currency swaps. For transactions with clients, the following apply: (1) All foreign exchange transactions eligible for spot settlement (purchase or sale) under the foreign exchange regulations are also eligible for forward settlement. (2) Forward settlement is subject to examination of performance. A bank may, in accordance with its own business operation and risk management guidelines, decide to execute a forward contract with a client. When the forward contract expires, the bank buys or sells the foreign exchange. (3) The principal of a forward contract must be fully settled at the agreed forward transaction price, and nondelivery forwards are not permitted. (4) If, at the expiration of a forward contract, the client breaches the contract, the matter is dealt with according to commercial principles. (5) A client may adjust the time limit of the forward contract (advance or renew the contract) by means of swaps. The contractual amount, the renewal times, and the time limit are determined through negotiations between the client and the bank. Residents and nonresidents may take their personal, legitimately held foreign currency abroad as follows: (1) Foreign currency cash in an amount not exceeding US$5,000 or the amount declared at the most recent entry may be taken out of the customs territory without restriction. (2) A Permit to Hold Foreign Currency issued by a foreign-exchange-designated bank is required for amounts between US$5,000 and US$10,000. (3) Other than in special circumstances, taking more than US$10,000 in foreign currency cash out of the customs territory is not permitted. If the amount is in excess of US$10,000, a Permit to Take Foreign Exchange out of the Customs Territory is required from the local SAFE. (4) Foreign currency payment vouchers such as traveler’s checks are not subject to the rules on exports of cash. Residents and nonresidents may bring into China up to RMB 20,000. Residents and nonresidents importing more than US$5,000 must declare it to customs. Yes. Based on commitments made on accession to the WTO, China currently implements an import tariff quota administration regime for wheat, corn, husked rice, sugar, cotton, wool, wool tops, and chemical fertilizers. Imports within the quota require the appropriate approvals. Based on the stipulated targets agreed to by the WTO, China implements inspections, quarantines, and certifications with regard to import products. An import quarantine approval system is applied to high-risk plants and animals and plant and animal products. There are four categories of import customs duty: the MFN tariff rate, conventional tariff rate, preferential tariff rate, and general tariff rate. The MFN tariff rate is applied to imports whose place of origin is a member of the WTO to which the MFN treatment clause is applied, imports from countries or regions that have signed bilateral trade agreements with China and that contain clauses of reciprocal MFN treatment, and imports whose place of origin is within the territory of China. The conventional tariff rate is applied to imports from countries or regions that have signed a regional trade agreement with China stipulating favorable customs duty. The preferential tariff rate is applied to imports from countries or regions that have signed a trade agreement with China that stipulates favorable customs duty rates. The general tariff rate is applied to imports from countries or regions other than those mentioned above, including imports of unclear origin. The following products are subject to a state import monopoly: wheat, corn, rice, crude oil, oil products, sugar, tobacco and tobacco products, cellulose diacetate fiber, chemical fertilizers, and cotton. Based on commitments made on accession to the WTO, China has begun to eliminate its state import monopolies. 309 ©International Monetary Fund. No. For trade-related foreign exchange administration, a list of “enterprises requiring special attention” has been established, with the exception of bonded zones, bonded logistic parks, bonded ports, comprehensive bonded zones, cross-border industrial zones, and other areas under customs’ close supervision. Enterprises that receive foreign exchange and are not on the list may receive and settle foreign exchange directly according to relevant regulations. Enterprises on the list that receive foreign exchange must provide foreign-exchange-designated banks with a written explanation regarding the nature of the foreign exchange settlement. Specifically, foreign exchange revenue from transit trade for which payment is followed by collection should be settled with the original copy of the validated verification form of the import payment with the bank’s transaction seal (enterprise copy) and the transit trade contract. Foreign exchange revenue from transit trade for which collection is followed by payment should not be settled before the transit trade payment abroad. After payment abroad is complete, the balance should be settled with the original copy of the verification form of the import payment validated with the bank’s transaction seal (enterprise copy) and transit trade contract. Other transaction types (including prepayment for export merchandise) should be settled with the original copy of the export declaration validated with the specific verification form code of export collection and the export contract. Trade-related fees such as commissions (agency fees) and shipping insurance should be settled according to the contract (agreement) and receipt. Other current account foreign exchange revenue falling outside trade-related foreign exchange should be settled according to the contract (agreement) and receipt. The bank should carefully examine the foreign exchange settlement business certificate issued by a local SAFE branch or subbranch if the enterprise can not provide the above-mentioned documents. QFIIs may invest domestically in A shares, subject to the following limitations: (1) A QFII must have a minimum experience in the industry of five years for fund managers and insurance companies, 30 years for securities firms; at least US$5 billion for fund management firms and insurance companies and US$10 billion for securities firms in assets under management in the most recent financial year; and must be free of any major irregularities in its home market over the past three years. (2) A QFII that is a bank must have assets that rank it among the top 100 internationally in the most recent financial year and must manage securities of not less than US$10 billion; other investors must have been in the business for at least five years, and the securities assets they managed in the most recent accounting year may not be less than US$5 billion. (3) Ownership of any Chinese company listed on the Shanghai or Shenzhen stock exchange by a QFII may not exceed 10%, and the total shares owned by QFIIs in a single Chinese company may not exceed 20%. Effective December 9, 2007, the overall QFII quota was raised to US$30 billion from US$10 billion. Closed-end QFIIs may remit capital only after three years, in installments of no more than 20% of the total each time, at intervals of one month or more. Other QFIIs may remit capital only after one year, in installments of no more than 20% of the total, and at intervals of three months or longer. Offshore beneficiaries of the above-mentioned remitted funds should be qualified investor principal parties. (4) QFIIs should authorize a custodian to apply on their behalf at the securities registration and settlement institution to set up securities accounts. Each investor may authorize only one custodian. When the custodian applies on the investor’s behalf to set up securities accounts, it should hold documents such as the qualified investor’s power of attorney and other securities investment business approvals. In addition, within five working days of setting up the securities account, the custodian must report the related circumstances to the CSRC for recording purposes. QFIIs should authorize a member of the securities registration and settlement institution to conduct capital settlement operations on their behalf. A financial institution regulated by the Chinese Banking Regulatory Commission (CBRC) may purchase and sell derivative instruments following the approval of the CBRC for the following objectives: (1) to avoid inherent asset and liability risks; (2) to gain profit; and (3) to provide transaction services for clients, including financial institutions. The relevant documents must be submitted to a regulatory agency following consultations before complex derivative operations are started for the first time in China. The institution involved in derivative transactions must comply with the regulations on foreign exchange administration and other relevant provisions in conducting foreign exchange, stock, and commodity derivative transactions as well as in conducting derivative transactions on a stock exchange. Effective March 7, 2008, regulated financial institutions that meet risk management requirements may trade in gold futures on the domestic market. The regulations governing purchases apply. Purchases of foreign exchange for advance repayment of foreign debt require SAFE authorization and must conform to the following guidelines: (1) Debt examination, approval, and registration requirements must be satisfied in accordance with regulations. (2) The loan contract must contain an advance repayment clause, and both the creditor and the debtor must agree to the advance repayment. (3) The debtor must submit an application to purchase foreign exchange for an advance foreign debt repayment. (4) Owned foreign exchange must be used first, and foreign exchange may be purchased only when all owned foreign exchange is exhausted. Financial institutions authorized by the CBRC may lend overseas with SAFE approval. Resident subsidiaries of multinational corporations may either lend directly or arrange for a domestic bank to lend to the offshore member company of the group. One-year or longer international commercial borrowing by Chinese institutions must be approved in advance. Financial institutions with approval to engage in foreign borrowing may conduct short-term foreign borrowing with maturities of one year or less within the balance approved by the SAFE. Specific transaction- based approval is not required. Advance LCs with a maturity of more than 90 days but less than one year are included in the category of short-term credits, whereas those exceeding one year are included in medium- and long-term international commercial loans. Deferred trade payments with terms of more than 180 days and amounts above US$200,000 must fit into external debt and limit management. Within this limit, borrowing from a nonresident does not require prior approval, but the borrower must register the credit with the SAFE. Renminbi credits extended by banks to domestic institutions may be used only for productive purposes and may not be used to purchase foreign exchange for debt-service payments. Domestic banks’ foreign financial guarantees and all guarantees provided by other domestic institutions (except for collateral or mortgages by solely foreign investment enterprises for their own credit) are subject to prior authorization by the SAFE. The external nonfinancing guarantees provided by banks do not require prior approval; however, all external guarantees must be registered. When a guarantee is exercised, the specific transactions must be approved on a case-by- case basis by the SAFE. FFEs may accept guarantees from foreign institutions. A three-tier classification system is in effect, defining activities in which foreign exchange investment is encouraged, restricted, or banned. Outward direct investment is permitted only after examination of the source of the foreign exchange funds, approval of the authorities concerned with foreign direct investment, and completion of offshore investment foreign exchange registration. There is no limit on the amount of foreign exchange that may be used in Chinese enterprises’ direct investment abroad, allowing domestic investors to purchase foreign currency to participate in direct investment abroad. Nonresidents are free to invest in China as long as they meet requirements under Sino-foreign joint-venture laws and other relevant regulations, and are approved by the Ministry of Commerce. Status under IMF Articles of Agreement Restrictions and/or multiple currency practices Exchange measures imposed for security reasons References to legal instruments and hyperlinks Currency Exchange rate structure Classification Managed floating with no predetermined path for the exchange rate Exchange tax Exchange subsidy Exchange Measures The IMF staff report for the 2007 Article IV consultation with Colombia states that, as of December 26, 2007, Colombia maintained two exchange measures subject to IMF approval under Article VIII: (1) a multiple currency practice and an exchange restriction arising from a tax on outward remittances of nonresident profits that were earned before 2007 and have been retained in the country for less than five years; and (2) an exchange restriction arising from the special regime for the hydrocarbon sector. Branches of foreign corporations are required either to surrender their export proceeds or to agree to a government limitation on their access to the foreign exchange market. While Colombia is free under the Articles to impose surrender requirements and to exempt the application of those requirements, conditioning such exemptions on the acceptance of limitations on the availability of foreign exchange for the making of payments and transfers for current international transactions is inconsistent with Article VIII, Section 2(a). (Country Report No. 08/31) Effective December 26, 2007, the tax on outward remittances was eliminated for remittances of profits earned in 2007 and beyond, in accordance with Law 1111 and applies only in respect of profits earned before 2007 and retained in the country for less than five years. No. n.a. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Colombia is the Colombian peso. Unitary. The de jure exchange rate arrangement is independently floating. All foreign exchange transactions are conducted at a market-determined exchange rate; however, the Banco de la República (BR) intervenes in the foreign exchange market to adjust the level of international reserves, limit excess volatility of the exchange rate, and influence the speed of adjustment of the nominal exchange rate. As a result, the de facto exchange rate arrangement is classified as managed floating with no predetermined path for the exchange rate. The BR can intervene at its discretion and via its automatic rule, which is designed to limit volatility. Under this rule, it sells (buys) foreign exchange options when the peso depreciates (appreciates) by more than 2% from its 20-day moving average. No. No. 323 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Foreign exchange market Spot exchange market Interbank market Forward exchange market References to legal instruments and hyperlinks COLOMBIA All foreign exchange transactions are conducted at a market-determined exchange rate. Yes. Derivative contracts are permitted on underlying commodity and financial transactions to cover exchange rate, interest rate, or shareholder index price risks. The types of contracts permitted include standardized stock exchange contracts and over-the-counter contracts (forwards and swaps). Exchange market intermediaries (EMIs, including commercial banks and stockbrokers) may trade foreign exchange derivatives with nonresidents who hold foreign investments registered with the BR or who have offered issues on Colombia’s public securities market. Effective May 6, 2007, the overall gross exposure to risk by each EMI participating in the foreign exchange derivative market may not exceed 500% of its total capital. www.banrep.gov.co/politica_cambiaria/index.html. Arrangements for Payments and Receipts Prescription of currency requirements Use of foreign exchange among residents Residents may freely hold foreign exchange within the country and trade it with other residents or EMIs. The use of foreign exchange among residents is prohibited, except in the following cases: (1) payment for freight and international transport tickets (Article 76); (2) personal expenses using international credit cards (Article 76); (3) payment of insurance premiums denominated in foreign exchange under Decree 2821 of 1991, and payments in Colombia of damages payable in foreign currency by insurance companies based in Colombia, pursuant to Article 14 of Law 9 of 1991; (4) payments connected with contracts between local foreign direct investment companies engaged in exploration and exploitation of oil and natural gas, coal, ferronickel, and uranium and companies providing technical services exclusively in this sector (payments in foreign currency are authorized provided the corresponding foreign exchange is derived from resources generated in their operations) (Article 51); (5) purchases and sales between residents of fuel for ships and aircraft used in international travel transportation (Article 51); (6) purchases and sales of crude oil and natural gas produced domestically by Ecopetrol and other residents (Article 51); (7) imports and exports of goods and services transacted between residents and industrial users of these goods based in industrial free zones (Article 54); (8) payments in connection with domestic operations through the mechanism provided in External Resolution 11 of 1997 (Article 79, paragraph 5); and (9) payments by residents in connection with sales by public entities of shares or preemptive rights in Colombian corporations and the remuneration they receive from concession or licensing contracts (External Resolution 37 of 1993, Art. 2). Payment in foreign currency is permitted for foreign-currency-denominated derivatives. Residents may purchase and sell foreign currency professionally, in cash or traveler’s checks, after enrolling in the commercial registry and the registry of foreign currency buyers and sellers. Authorization does not include the direct or indirect offer of professional services with added value, such as the marketing of checks or securities in foreign currency, international payments, money orders and remittances, or any type of exchange market channel for third parties. Settlements between Colombia and other LAIA countries may be conducted voluntarily through accounts maintained within the framework of the LAIA multilateral clearing system. Not for Redistribution Import licenses and other nontariff measures Positive list Negative list Licenses with quotas Other nontariff measures Import taxes and/or tariffs State import monopoly References to legal instruments and hyperlinks COLOMBIA There is a list of unrestricted imports applicable to all countries. The Ministry of Trade, Industry, and Tourism is authorized to administer licensing requirements with respect to imports under special customs regimes and imports subject to and for the purpose of antidumping controls, as well as for implementation of policies and safeguards for the protection of national industries. Imports of the following goods are subject to prior licensing requirements: chicken parts, chemicals, drug precursors, narcotics, detonators, explosives, cloth, and tires. Licenses are required for (1) goods on the prior licensing regime list; (2) goods subject to nonrefundable import licenses; (3) goods for which tariff exemptions are requested; (4) used, imperfect, repaired, rebuilt, refurbished, substandard, reprocessed goods and inventory balances; (5) goods subject to the annual licensing system; and (6) goods imported by official institutions, except gasoline, urea, and other fuels. The Government of Colombia determines whether waste, excess, or scrap metal requires prior licensing. Registration is required for goods requiring prior requisitions, permits, or authorization, such as fishery resources, private surveillance and security equipment, radioactive isotopes and radioactive material, clothing exclusive to law enforcement officers, and hydrocarbons and gasoline. Registration is also required for products subject to (1) sanitary controls to protect human, plant, and animal health; (2) emission certification; (3) vehicle inspection; quantitative safeguards quotas; and (4) control for environmental protection under international treaties, agreements, or protocols (Art. 2 of Decree 3803 of 2006). Imports of chemical, biological, and nuclear weapons; nuclear byproducts; and toxic waste are prohibited as well as merchandise prohibited under international agreements. Also prohibited are imports of used clothing and footwear, unless they are processed through the Social Action Office in the Office of the President of the Republic, and imports of used goods if there are locally produced equivalents registered with the Ministry of Trade, Industry, and Tourism. Quotas have been set under the CAN-MERCOSUR agreement for sweets, cocoa, chocolates, and other prepared foodstuffs containing cocoa; infant formula; and meat products. (Preferential access quotas, Decree 1900 of June 2005). During October 2006–December 2007, quotas applied to some men’s clothing from the People’s Republic of China (restrictive quotas for underwear, Decree 3590 of 2006; restrictive quotas for textiles, Decree 691 of 2006). The 10% tariff on a quota of polyethylene with a density of less than 0.94 was deferred from February 21 to June 6, 2007 (Decree 476 of 2006). Effective July 12, 2007, the 13% tariff on imports of biaxially oriented polyterephthalate with a thickness of less than 30 microns was deferred until December 31, 2007 (Decree 2646 of 2007). The 12% tariff on some import quotas of polyethylene with a density of 0.94 or more and ethylene copolymers with other olefins was deferred from September 13, 2007, to January 26, 2008 (Decree 3484 of 2007). Controls apply for sanitary, security, health, environmental protection, and national production purposes. With certain exceptions, imports are subject to the CET of the Andean Community. Exchange Arrangement The currency of the Democratic Republic of the Congo is the Congo franc. Unitary. The exchange rate of the Congo franc is determined by supply and demand in the foreign exchange market. The Central Bank of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (BCC) publishes the daily average exchange rate, which is based on the combined average of the amounts and rates applied in market transactions, as reported by exchange bureaus and banks. The BCC, while observing the international reserves target in the monetary program, intervenes to smooth exchange rate fluctuations, but not against market fundamentals. A charge of 0.02% is levied by the BCC on payments made or received by licensed banks, to or from abroad, regardless of the status of the originator or the beneficiary. No. n.a. The BCC organizes foreign exchange auctions on an ad hoc basis to buy foreign exchange from commercial banks with the view to achieving its international 342 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Fixing Interbank market Forward exchange market References to legal instruments and hyperlinks DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE CONGO reserve target under the program agreed to with the IMF. The BCC is committed to holding foreign exchange auctions as the only means of smoothing exchange rate fluctuations. n.a. No charges or commissions are assessed on interbank market transactions. In their transactions with customers, commercial banks and financial institutions may charge an exchange commission not exceeding 1%. The spread between the buying and selling rates for foreign banknotes set by the commercial banks and financial institutions in the foreign exchange market must not exceed 5%. Exchange market participants may engage in spot and/or forward operations. Forward operations are completed on contract maturity. Congo franc equivalents for exchange transactions are calculated at rates agreed to between contracting parties. They are paid on the agreed date and, at the discretion of the contracting parties, through a clearinghouse, credit to an account, or cash payment. The contractual maturity of forward operations must take account of holidays in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and abroad. Restrictions and/or multiple currency practices Exchange measures imposed for security reasons References to legal instruments and hyperlinks Currency Exchange rate structure Classification Conventional pegged arrangement Exchange tax Exchange subsidy Exchange Measures No restrictions as reported in the latest staff report as of December 31, 2007. No. n.a. Exchange Arrangement The currency issued within the CAEMC, which is legal tender in the Republic of Congo and the other member countries, is the CFA franc. Unitary. The Republic of Congo participates in a currency union with five other members of the CAEMC and has no separate legal tender. The CFA franc is pegged to the euro, the intervention currency, at a fixed rate of CFAF 655.957 per €1. Exchange transactions in euros between the BEAC and commercial banks are made at the same rate. Buying and selling rates for certain other foreign currencies are also officially posted, with quotations based on the fixed rate for the euro and the rates in the Paris exchange market for the currencies concerned. Effective January 1, 2007, the exchange rate regime of the CAEMC countries has been reclassified to the category conventional pegged arrangement from the category exchange arrangement with no separate legal tender. The new classification is based on the behavior of the common currency, whereas the previous classification was based on the lack of a separate legal tender. The new classification thus reflects only a definitional change and is not based on a judgment that there has been a substantive change in the exchange regime or other policies of the currency union or its members. Payments destined to all countries are subject to a commission of 1% (exclusive of VAT), with a minimum charge of CFAF 75. Exempt from this commission are payments of the government, the Postal and Telecommunications Administration, and BEAC members; salaries of Congolese diplomats abroad; expenditures of official missions abroad; scholarships of individuals studying or training abroad; payments made on behalf of individuals for purchase of books and periodicals not intended for sale; and debt-service payments due from companies that have entered into an agreement with the Republic of Congo. Arrangements for Payments and Receipts Prescription of currency requirements Controls on the use of domestic currency Payments arrangements Regional arrangements Administration of control Payments arrears Controls on trade in gold (coins and/or bullion) On domestic ownership and/or trade On external trade Within the CAEMC, the CFA franc is used freely for payments and receipts in current and capital transactions. Settlement with all countries other than CAEMC members must be made through correspondent banks in one of the currencies of the two parties or in any other currency accepted by the two parties to the transaction. An Operations Account is maintained with the French Treasury that links all Operations Account countries. All purchases and sales of foreign currencies and euros against CFA francs are ultimately settled through a debit or credit to the Operations Account. Exchange regulations of CAEMC member countries are harmonized. The Ministry of Economy, Finance, and Budget (MEFB) is responsible for administering foreign exchange regulations and may delegate all or a portion of its power to the BEAC, the Banking Commission in Central Africa (COBAC), and authorized intermediaries. Authorized intermediaries are usually delegated to administer foreign exchange transactions and are responsible for checking the validity of transactions, collecting statistics, and reporting to the monetary authorities. The tasks delegated exclude some types of transactions. The BEAC ensures exchange regulation surveillance, evaluates cover against exchange risk, studies matters for which advice may be requested when foreign exchange accounts are opened by some resident legal entities, and monitors the repatriation of export proceeds. COBAC must ensure that the authorized intermediaries comply with the specific provisions of these regulations and do not destabilize the CAEMC banking system. No. Residents may hold gold in the form of coins, art objects, and jewelry; however, to hold gold in any other form, authorization of the MEFB is required. When traveling outside the CAEMC, travelers must use means of payment other than BEAC banknotes. Nevertheless, resident travelers may carry with them a maximum of CFAF 100,000 when exiting the CAEMC. Resident and nonresident travelers crossing the borders of the CAEMC must, on exit, declare to customs their foreign currency, securities, and assets in amounts exceeding CFAF 1 million. When leaving the CAEMC, nonresident travelers may take with them foreign currency up to the equivalent of the amount they declared on entry. An annual import program classifies imports by the following zones: (1) members of the CAEMC, (2) France, (3) other Operations Account countries, (4) EU countries other than France, and (5) all remaining countries. No. n.a. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Costa Rica is the Costa Rican colón. Unitary. Since October 17, 2006, the Banco Central de Costa Rica (BCCR) officially pursues a crawling band arrangement with an increasing but moderate width. The band is defined in terms of colones per $1 and does not include a central parity. The edges of the band are periodically adjusted whenever warranted by financial and macroeconomic conditions. The new system had an initial width of 3%, with the floor set at C 514.78 per $1 and the ceiling set at C 530.22 per $1. The floor was adjusted up by C 0.06 and the ceiling by C 0.14 every business day, resulting in an upward crawl of 2.9% and 6.7% a year, respectively. On January 31, 2007, the rate of crawl of the band’s floor was reduced by C 0.06 a day to zero and that of the ceiling by C 0.14 a day to C 0.11, allowing for a faster widening of the band and the floor for the colón was changed to C 519.16 per $1 (previously, C 514.78) and the ceiling to C 540.55 per $1 (previously, C 530.22). On November 22, 2007, the band’s floor was adjusted by 4% to C 498.39 per $1 and the ceiling to C 562.83 per $1. The crawl of the band’s floor was modified from zero to a negative daily adjustment of C 0.06, allowing for a 3% nominal annual appreciation of the colón, and the rate of crawl of the band’s ceiling was reduced to C 0.06 a business day, resulting in a change of 3% a year. These changes widened the band to 13%. However, despite changes in the parameters of the exchange rate band, the exchange rate has remained at the floor of the band, with limited variability throughout the period. In accordance with Article 97 of the Organic Law of the BCCR and Article 5 of the Regulations on Spot Market Exchange Operations, a fee is charged for participation by ADs in the foreign exchange market. Effective August 30, 2007, authorized agents must transfer to the BCCR 25% (previously, 10%) of the positive margin of foreign exchange transactions. Proceeds must be transferred to the BCCR by the next business day. No. 362 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Foreign exchange market Spot exchange market Operated by the central bank Allocation Auction Fixing Interbank market References to legal instruments and hyperlinks COSTA RICA Intermediaries authorized to operate in the spot exchange market are free to set buying and selling rates for transactions with the public. The rates must be those actually used in transactions, i.e., including any surcharge or additional cost, so that they reflect the final price negotiated by the customer. Intermediaries may trade in foreign currency in the electronic market for foreign currency operations (MONEX), in which the BCCR buys and sells currencies for its own needs and those of the nonbank public sector as well as for purposes of protecting the exchange rate band and intervention. Previously, foreign exchange transactions were carried out through the organized markets for the electronic trading of currencies (MONED). Foreign currency buying and selling transactions of the nonbank public sector are carried out directly with the BCCR or through government owned commercial banks. Public institutions may buy and sell foreign currency in amounts exceeding $100,000 or $10 million a month only through the BCCR. Transactions involving lesser amounts may be conducted through government-owned commercial banks. The exchange rates applied represent the weighted average daily rate resulting from BCCR transactions on the MONEX to meet the net requirements of the nonbank public sector, even though the BCCR may, in special circumstances, supply foreign currency from its international monetary reserves at the average wholesale market price. n.a. n.a. n.a. The external value of the colón is determined in the interbank market. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Côte d’Ivoire is the CFA franc. Unitary. Côte d’Ivoire participates in a currency union with seven other members of the WAEMU and has no separate legal tender. The CFA franc is pegged to the euro, the intervention currency, at a fixed rate of CFAF 655.957 per €1. Exchange rates for other currencies are derived from the rate for the currency concerned in the Paris exchange market vis-à-vis the euro. Effective January 1, 2007, the exchange rate arrangement of the WAEMU countries has been reclassified to the category conventional pegged arrangement from the category exchange arrangement with no separate legal tender. The new classification is based on the behavior of the common currency, whereas the previous classification was based on the lack of a separate legal tender. The new classification thus reflects only a definitional change and is not based on a judgment that there has been a substantive change in the exchange regime or other policies of the currency union or its members. A bank commission of 0.3% applies to transfers to all countries outside the WAEMU. The proceeds of this commission must be surrendered in their entirety to the treasury. In addition, banks are allowed to charge an exchange commission of up to 2% on over-the-counter exchange for euros. No. n.a. 369 ©International Monetary Fund. Use of foreign exchange among residents Payments arrangements Regional arrangements Clearing agreements Administration of control The CFA franc is the only legal tender, and residents are not permitted to use foreign exchange for domestic transactions. An Operations Account is maintained with the French Treasury that links Operations Account countries. All purchases or sales of foreign currencies or euros against CFA francs are ultimately settled through a debit or credit to the Operations Account. A multilateral clearing agreement exists in the context of the WAMA among the countries of the WAEMU, Cape Verde, The Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Liberia, Mauritania, Nigeria, and Sierra Leone. All payments related to current transactions between the member bank countries may be effected under the clearing arrangements. However, this excludes transactions specified by the committee of governors of the CBs of ECOWAS members and payments related to the exportation from the country of a member bank to the country of another member bank of finished products originating in countries whose CB or monetary authority is not a member of the WAMA. Exchange control is administered jointly by the Directorate of the Treasury in the Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) and the BCEAO. Most of the authority to supervise foreign exchange transactions is delegated to authorized banks, which are required to report these operations to the MEF. The BCEAO is also authorized to collect—either directly or through banks, financial institutions, the postal administration, or judicial agents—any information necessary to compile balance of payments statistics. Customs officers monitor outflows of foreign exchange and confirm imports and exports of goods. Exempt from this requirement are (1) imports by or on behalf of the treasury or the BCEAO, (2) imports of manufactured articles containing minor quantities of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles), and (3) imports by travelers of gold objects up to a combined weight of 500 grams. Both licensed and exempt imports of gold are subject to customs declaration. Exports of gold have been liberalized. CFA franc banknotes may be exported freely by travelers. In addition, the exchange of BCEAO banknotes between authorized intermediaries and their correspondents outside the WAEMU is prohibited. Reexportation of foreign banknotes by nonresident travelers is permitted up to the equivalent of CFAF 500,000; reexportation of foreign banknotes above this ceiling requires documentation demonstrating either the importation of the foreign banknotes or their purchase against other means of payment registered in the name of the traveler or through the use of nonresident deposit accounts in local banks. Residents are free to import domestic currency. The exportation of BCEAO banknotes between licensed intermediary banks and their correspondent banks located outside the WAEMU is strictly prohibited. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Croatia is the Croatian kuna. Unitary. The de jure exchange rate arrangement is managed floating with no predetermined path for the exchange rate. The Croatian National Bank (CNB) may set intervention exchange rates, which it applies in transactions with banks outside the interbank market to limit exchange rate volatility. The exchange rate of the kuna vis-à-vis the euro remained broadly stable in 2007 due to overall market conditions and the actions of the CNB to stabilize it on several occasions. Thus, effective September 1, 2006, the classification of the de facto exchange rate arrangement has been changed from managed floating with no predetermined path for the exchange rate to a conventional pegged arrangement. Nonresidents may acquire real estate in Croatia under the condition of reciprocity, subject to permission from the minister of justice in accordance with the law on property and other property rights. Financial loans must be reported to the CNB for statistical purposes. 386 ©International Monetary Fund. This prohibition does not apply to residents extending financial loans to immediate relatives. Resident natural persons are required to use foreign financial credits through authorized domestic banks. Gifts and endowments greater than the equivalent of €3,000 (if made in foreign exchange) or HRK 15,000 (if made in kunas) must be approved by the CNB if the donor is an individual. Resident legal persons, branches of foreign companies, and sole traders may make cashless transfers abroad of gifts and grants, provided all tax and other legally prescribed obligations in Croatia have been met. CNB approval is required for the physical cross-border movement of cash exceeding HRK 15,000 or the equivalent of €3,000 in foreign exchange, for declaration to the customs authority. Provisions specific to commercial banks and other credit institutions Borrowing abroad Provisions Specific to the Financial Sector The CFSSA regulations apply. An unremunerated reserve requirement of 55% (40% and 15% subcomponents) applies to increases in banks’ foreign liabilities. The net increase in sources of funds received from nonresidents or legal persons in a special relationship with a bank over their level of June 2004 is subject to an unremunerated marginal reserve requirement of 40%. Banks are required to deposit the 40% reserve requirement in an unremunerated foreign exchange account of the CNB. A second-tier marginal reserve requirement of 15% is applied to the increase in nonresidents’ funds over their level of November 2005; a third-tier marginal reserve requirement of 55% is applied to the increase in guarantees and warranties for the accounts of foreign persons, in kuna and foreign currency, serving as a basis for the foreign borrowing of domestic persons. A fourth-tier marginal reserve requirement of 55% is applied to the net increase in funds received from nonresidents that are used to provide financing in the form of syndicated loans to domestic natural and legal persons or that domestic banks extend to domestic natural and legal persons in the name and for the account of the mandator (mandated operations) over their level of May 387 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Differential treatment of deposit accounts in foreign exchange Reserve requirements Liquid asset requirements Credit controls Differential treatment of deposit accounts held by nonresidents Reserve requirements CROATIA 2006. An unremunerated reserve requirement of 55% applies on the net increase in liabilities arising from issued debt securities over their January 2006 level. Deposits denominated in domestic and foreign exchange are subject to a reserve requirement of 17%. The calculation period follows the calendar month. The maintenance period lasts from the second Wednesday of a month to the day preceding the second Wednesday of the following month. Kuna and foreign exchange components of the calculation are determined separately. Fifty percent of the calculated foreign reserve requirement is included in the calculated kuna reserve requirement. Seventy percent of reserve requirement is allocated to the kuna component. The percentage for allocating the foreign exchange component of the reserve requirement calculated on the basis of foreign exchange funds of nonresidents and foreign exchange funds received from legal persons in a special relationship with a bank is 100%; the percentage for allocating the remaining portion of the foreign exchange component of the reserve requirement is 60%. The remaining portion of the reserve requirement may be maintained by the average daily balances of liquid claims in the accounts. The rate of remuneration for the deposited kuna component of required reserves is 0.75%. The remuneration of the foreign exchange component is 50% of the U.S. federal funds target rate for funds allocated in dollars and 50% of the ECB minimum bid refinance rate for funds allocated in euros. Thirty-two percent of foreign exchange liabilities (minimum required amount of foreign currency claims) must be covered by short-term foreign exchange assets with a maturity of less than three months. In addition to foreign-exchange- denominated instruments, liabilities include foreign-exchange-indexed instruments (liabilities in kuna with a one- or two-way currency clause). Effective January 1, 2007, banks that expand credit above 1% each month are required to purchase nontransferable CNB bills (360-day maturity, which pay an interest rate equal to the rate on remuneration of required reserves in kuna) at a rate of 50% of the difference between actual and permissible credits. Effective February 28, 2007, the monthly limits have been replaced by an annual limit of 12% to take into account seasonality of credit growth. Effective May 1, 2007, the calculation basis was split into two parts, with separate calculations for balance- sheet and off-balance-sheet placements. In view of the credit growth of 9% recorded in the first six months of 2007, the CNB reintroduced monthly limits of 0.5% starting in July 2007, with June 30, 2007, as the basis for calculations. Effective October 1, 2007, with September 30, 2007, as the basis for calculation, the CNB requested that credit issued by all bank-affiliated companies be included in the calculation of credit growth, in an attempt to close a potential loophole. Effective January 1, 2008, banks that expand (year over year) credit above 12% from the level at end-2007 (or 1% each month, including credits issued by bank- affiliated companies) are required to purchase nontransferable CNB bills (360-day maturity), which pay 0.25% annualized interest, at a rate of 75% of the difference between actual and permissible credits. Effective February 1, 2008, credit issued by bank-affiliated companies is included in the calculation of a bank’s balance sheet. An unremunerated reserve requirement of 55% (40% and 15% subcomponents) applies to increases in banks’ foreign liabilities. Banks are required to deposit the 40% reserve requirement in an unremunerated foreign exchange account of the CNB. The limit on open positions in foreign exchange is 20% of a bank’s regulatory capital. The Act on Mandatory and Voluntary Pension Funds, the Insurance Act, and the Investment Funds Act are in effect. Insurance companies are regulated by the Insurance Act (Official Gazette No. 151/2005). The CFSSA is the legal successor to the former Croatian Securities Commission, Insurance Companies Supervisory Authority, and Agency for Supervision of Pension Funds and Insurance. In accordance with Article 123 (2) of the Insurance Act, at least 50% of total assets for the coverage of mathematical provisions must be invested in securities issued by the government of Croatia, CNB, or Croatian Bank for Reconstruction and Development, as well as in bonds and other debt securities guaranteed by the government of Croatia. In accordance with Article 117 of the Insurance Act, insurance companies must match their investment of assets covering technical provisions, including mathematical provisions, that are exposed to possible losses because of changes in interest rates, exchange rates, and other market risks, with their liabilities under the insurance contracts that are subject to the same changes. An insurance company must match not less than 80% of the assets covering technical provisions, including mathematical provisions, with its liabilities under the insurance contracts that depend on changes in exchange rates. When investing the assets covering technical provisions, including mathematical provisions, an insurance company must take into account the maturity of the liabilities under individual insurance contracts. Pension fund companies are regulated by the Act on Mandatory and Voluntary Pension Funds. Effective July 17, 2007, pension fund assets may be invested in securities issued and bonds and other debt securities guaranteed by the Government of Croatia, an EU or an OECD member, the Croatian National Bank, and central banks of EU and OECD members, without limitations. For other investments the following limits apply: (1) Investment in bonds and other debt securities issued by a local or regional self-government unit in Croatia or an EU or OECD member; and bonds and other debt securities traded on the organized securities market in Croatia or an EU or OECD member, whose issuer is a joint-stock company with its head office in Croatia or an EU or OECD member state may not exceed 30% of the pension fund’s assets. (2) Investment in shares traded on the organized securities market in Croatia or an EU or OECD member, whose issuer is a joint- 389 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution CROATIA stock company with its head office in Croatia or an EU or OECD member may not exceed 30% of the pension fund’s assets. (3) Investment in units of each open-end investment funds and shares of closed-end investment funds registered in Croatia or in an EU or OECD member may not exceed 5% and all such investments may not exceed 30% of the pension fund’s assets. (4) Investment in deposits, investment certificates, or repo agreements with each bank whose head office is in Croatia or an EU or OECD member may not exceed 2.5%, and all such investments may not exceed 20% of the pension fund’s assets. (5) Investment of the funds on the business account of the pension fund may not exceed 5% of the pension fund’s assets. Effective July 17, 2007, for investments by pension funds in securities issued by nonresidents the following limits apply: (1) Investment in bonds and other debt securities issued by a local or regional self-government unit in Croatia or an EU or OECD member; and bonds and other debt securities traded on the organized securities market in Croatia or an EU or OECD member, whose issuer is a joint- stock company with its head office in Croatia or an EU or OECD member state may not exceed 30% of the pension fund’s assets. (2) Investment in shares traded on the organized securities market in Croatia or an EU or OECD member, whose issuer is a joint-stock company with its head office in Croatia or an EU or OECD member may not exceed 30% of the pension fund’s assets. (3) Investment in units of each open-end investment funds and shares of closed-end investment funds registered in Croatia or an EU or OECD member may not exceed 5% and all such investments may not exceed 30% of the pension fund’s assets. (4) Investment in deposits, investment certificates, or repo agreements with each bank whose head office is in Croatia or an EU or OECD member may not exceed 2.5%, and all such investments may not exceed 20% of the pension fund’s assets. (5) Investment of the funds on the business account of the pension fund may not exceed 5% of the pension fund’s assets. Previously, mandatory and voluntary pension funds were allowed to invest only up to 15% and 20% of the value of their assets, respectively, in securities issued by nonresidents. Effective July 17, 2007, for investments by pension funds abroad the following limits apply: (1) Investment in bonds and other debt securities issued by a local or regional self-government unit in Croatia or an EU or OECD member; and bonds and other debt securities traded on the organized securities market in Croatia or an EU or OECD member, whose issuer is a joint-stock company with its head office in Croatia or an EU or OECD member state may not exceed 30% of the pension fund’s assets. (2) Investment in shares traded on the organized securities market in Croatia or an EU or OECD member, whose issuer is a joint-stock company with its head office in Croatia or an EU or OECD member may not exceed 30% of the pension fund’s assets. (3) Investment in units of each open-end investment fund and shares of closed-end investment funds registered in Croatia or an EU or OECD member may not exceed 5%, and all such investments may not exceed 30% of the pension fund’s assets. (4) Investment in deposits, investment certificates, or repo agreements with each bank whose head office is in Croatia or an EU or OECD member may not exceed 2.5%, and all such investments may not exceed 20% of the pension fund’s assets. (5) Investment of the funds on the business account of the pension fund may not exceed 5% of the pension fund’s assets. Previously, the investment portfolio of mandatory and voluntary pension funds that could be held abroad was limited to 15% and 20%, respectively, of the value of the pension fund’s assets. Effective July 17, 2007, the new investment rules apply. Previously, mandatory pension funds were required to invest at least 50% of the value of their assets in long-term debt securities issued by the Republic of Croatia and the CNB. 390 Limits (max.) on securities issued by nonresidents Limits (max.) on investment portfolio held abroad Limits (min.) on investment portfolio held locally ©International Monetary Fund. Investment firms and collective investment funds Limits (max.) on securities issued by nonresidents Limits (max.) on investment portfolio held abroad Limits (min.) on investment portfolio held locally Currency-matching regulations on assets/liabilities composition References to legal instruments and hyperlinks The Investment Funds Act distinguishes among several types of investment funds and deals separately with the limits on investments for each type. A closed-end investment fund with a public offering may not invest more than 15% of its net asset value in securities of any single issuing body. An open-end investment fund with a public offering may not invest more than 10% of its net asset value in transferable securities and money market instruments of any single issuing body. Assets of an open-end investment fund with a private offering must consist of not less than six different securities, units, or shares in investment funds or money market instruments; the three that account for the largest share of the fund’s assets must not exceed 60% of the fund’s asset value. Securities, units, or shares in investment funds of a single issuer or deposits with a single deposit institution must not exceed 20% of the value of all securities, units, or shares in investment funds or deposits in a fund. Under certain conditions, detailed in the Act, the limitations do not apply to securities or money market instruments issued or guaranteed by Croatia or units of local and regional self-government of Croatia; or EU members, local government units of EU members, non-EU members, or international public organizations of which one or more members are EU members. An open-end venture capital investment fund with a private offering, within five years of the date of its establishment, must not make fewer than five investments in different units or shares, subject to a condition that units or shares of a single issuer must not exceed 33% of the fund’s assets. The prospectus of the fund must clearly indicate the states, units of local government, and public international bodies in whose securities and money market instruments more than 35% of the fund’s net asset value may be invested. A closed-end investment fund with a public offering for investment in real estate may acquire real estate abroad based on reciprocity. According to Article 80 of the Investment Funds Act, at least 50% of net value of a closed-end investment fund with a public offering for investment in real estate must be in real estate located in Croatia, except in the case of investment in units or shares of companies involved exclusively or predominantly in the acquisition and sale, rent, and lease of real estate and real estate management in units or shares of another fund for investment in real estate. A maximum of 20% of an investment fund’s net asset value may be placed as a deposit with any single bank. Exchange Arrangement Effective January 1, 2008, the currency of Cyprus is the euro (previously, the Cyprus pound). Unitary. Effective January 1, 2008, Cyprus participates in a currency union (EMU) with 14 other members of the EU and has no separate legal tender. The euro, the common currency, floats freely and independently against other currencies. Previously, Cyprus participated in the ERM II and the pound fluctuated within a tight band: officially ±15% but in practice less than ±2.25%. As a result, effective January 1, 2008, the exchange rate regime of Cyprus has been reclassified to the category independently floating from the category pegged exchange rate within a horizontal band. Provisions Specific to the Financial Sector Provisions specific to commercial banks and other credit institutions Borrowing abroad Maintenance of accounts abroad Lending to nonresidents (financial or commercial credits) Lending locally in foreign exchange Purchase of locally issued securities denominated in foreign exchange Differential treatment of deposit accounts in foreign exchange Reserve requirements Liquid asset requirements Investment regulations Abroad by banks Yes. Banks may maintain accounts abroad, subject to the net open positions in foreign exchange described below. Banks are allowed to grant loans in foreign currencies with a maturity of up to 15 years to nonresidents, subject to the liquid asset requirements prescribed by the CBC for prudential reasons. Banks are allowed also to lend in local currency to nonresidents. Banks may grant loans with a maximum maturity of 15 years to residents (subject to the liquid asset requirements prescribed by the CBC for prudential reasons). These are subject to liquid asset requirements prescribed for prudential reasons. The prudential liquidity regulations applied to accounts in foreign currencies, held by either nonresidents or residents, are different from those applied to accounts in euros. Effective January 1, 2008, in accordance with the ECB Regulation (ECB/2003/9), the reserve requirements on deposit liabilities of credit institutions are unified at 2% for deposits both in domestic and in foreign currency. Previously, a minimum reserve requirement of 5% applied to deposits in Cyprus pounds and 2% to deposits in foreign currencies. Liquid assets in foreign currencies must equal at least 75% of deposit liabilities in foreign currencies. For deposits in local currency (euros), the liquidity positions of banks are monitored by the CBC for prudential purposes using a maturity mismatch approach. The maximum mismatch ratios allowed are (1) –10% of total deposits in the time band of “zero to seven days,” and (2) –25% in the time band of “zero to one month.” Banks may acquire assets abroad in accordance with the CBC directive establishing the framework within which banks may use the funds derived from foreign currency deposits from customers. The acquisition of 10% or more of a bank’s share capital by any resident or nonresident person, either alone or with associates, is subject to prior approval by the CBC in accordance with the Banking Law. The overall net open/uncovered overnight (intraday) position in all foreign currencies should not exceed 6% of the bank’s capital base. Furthermore, the bank’s overall net foreign exchange intraday exposure should not exceed 8% of a bank’s capital base. The net open/uncovered overnight (intraday) position in any one foreign currency should not exceed 3% (5% for intraday) of the bank’s capital base. Banks that do not engage in retail banking, and whose main business is to carry out investment transactions, are allowed to maintain a net open position limit in all currencies of up to 30% of their capital base at the close of a business day and up to 40% of their capital base during working hours. The limits that must be observed by the above category of banks in any one currency for the overnight and intraday positions are 15% and 25% of their capital base, respectively. Exchange Arrangement The currency of the Czech Republic is the Czech koruna. Unitary. The external value of the koruna is determined by supply and demand in the interbank exchange market, in which the Czech National Bank (CNB) participates. The CNB pursues a program of daily sales of foreign exchange reserves, broadly equivalent to the amount of portfolio gains on its reserves, aimed at preventing the level of reserves from continuing to rise. Other interventions have been limited to conversion of large one-off privatization receipts, and proceeds of EU transfers. However, since 2006, no privatization revenue has been received and EU transfers represented an insignificant amount in net terms. Thus, the classification of the de facto exchange rate arrangement has been changed, effective January 1, 2006, from managed floating with no predetermined path for the exchange rate to independently floating. Trade with Iraq is prohibited. Suppression of the Financing of Terrorism Act No. 3 of 2006. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Dominica is the Eastern Caribbean dollar, issued by the ECCB. Unitary. Dominica participates in a currency union with seven other members of the ECCU and has no separate legal tender. The Eastern Caribbean dollar is pegged to the U.S. dollar under a currency board arrangement at EC$2.70 per US$1. Effective January 1, 2007, the exchange rate arrangement of the ECCU countries has been reclassified to the category currency board arrangement from the category exchange arrangement with no separate legal tender. The new classification is based on the behavior of the common currency, whereas the previous classification was based on the lack of a separate legal tender. The new classification thus reflects only a definitional change and is not based on a judgment that there has been a substantive change in the exchange regime or other policies of the currency union or its members. Full-service banks wishing to invest abroad or to open cross-border branches must fulfill certain minimum requirements, including (1) authorization from the Monetary Board, which requires approval by the Superintendency of Banks; (2) a solvency ratio equal to or greater than 10% and fulfillment of prudential requirements in the Monetary and Financial Law or in Monetary Board resolutions; (3) sufficient management capacity to perform offshore functions; (4) maintenance of a cooperation agreement between the Superintendency of Banks and the host- country supervisory authorities; (5) approval by the host-country authorities of the investment; (6) a favorable report from the host-country supervisory authorities regarding the rating and soundness of the financial intermediary in which investment is to be made; and (7) submission of necessary documentation to the Superintendency of Banks. Not for Redistribution Differential treatment of deposit accounts in foreign exchange Reserve requirements Credit controls Investment regulations Abroad by banks Open foreign exchange position limits On resident assets and liabilities On nonresident assets and liabilities DOMINICAN REPUBLIC The reserve requirement ratio is 20% for both domestic and foreign currency bank deposits. The reserve requirement for foreign currency deposits at the CBDR must be maintained at 100%. To meet reserve requirements for domestic currency, banks may retain up to 2% in cash, with the remainder to be retained at the CBDR. The reserve requirement for small loan offices that become credit corporations is 5%, and it must be gradually built up to 15% over a period of six months. The reserve requirement is 15% for other financial intermediary institutions (savings and loan associations, savings and credit banks, and credit corporations) and 10% for Banco Agrícola de la Republica Dominicana. The calculation of the reserve requirement position of full-service banks and other financial intermediary institutions in domestic currency is made daily for purposes of monitoring liquidity; it is accumulated weekly for full-service banks and biweekly for savings and credit banks, credit corporations, and savings and loan associations for purposes of determining penalties, if any. Information required for calculating the reserve requirement position of financial intermediary institutions is submitted electronically to the CBDR on a daily basis through the online banking system or such other means as may be determined. Full-service banks and credit institutions may extend direct or indirect loans and guarantees or securities to a resident or nonresident individual, legal entity, or risk group for up to 10% of their paid-up capital and reserves, and up to 20% of capital and reserves if such operations are secured with first-ranking mortgages or real guarantees. Full-service commercial banks and other credit institutions may invest up to 20% of their paid-up capital in branches, agencies, or representative offices abroad, and they may make equity investments in foreign financial institutions. Full-service banks wishing to invest abroad or to open cross-border entities must fulfill certain minimum requirements, including (1) prior authorization by the Monetary Board, which requires approval of the Superintendency of Banks; (2) a solvency ratio equal to or greater than 10% and fulfillment of prudential requirements in the Monetary and Financial Law or in Monetary Board resolutions; (3) sufficient management capacity to perform offshore functions; (4) maintenance of a cooperation agreement between the Superintendency of Banks and the host- country supervisory authorities; (5) approval by the host-country authorities of the investment; (6) a favorable report from the host-country supervisory authorities regarding the rating and soundness of the financial intermediary in which investment is to be made; and (7) submission of necessary documentation to the Superintendency of Banks. The net short or long foreign currency positions of full-service banks are subject to the limits established in the Foreign Exchange Regulations. The limits are as follows: (1) for the long position for all financial intermediaries, the equivalent of 20% of liabilities denominated in foreign currencies plus contingent liabilities without foreign currency collateral, or 100% of paid-up capital and legal reserves, whichever amount is larger; and (2) for the short position for financial intermediaries, the equivalent of 20% of their assets denominated in foreign currencies, or 100% of the paid-up capital and legal reserves. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Egypt is the Egyptian pound. Unitary. The Central Bank of Egypt (CBE) buys and sells foreign exchange daily at the rate prevailing in the interbank market. Decree No. 40 of 2006 provides for intraday adjustment of the CBE’s exchange rate for official transactions. The pound has appreciated by about 4% vis-à-vis the dollar since August 2007. As a result, the de facto exchange rate arrangement of Egypt has been reclassified, effective August 1, 2007, from the category conventional pegged arrangement to the category managed floating with no predetermined path for the exchange rate. However, nonbank ADs are not permitted to deal in transfers into or out of the country; they must sell all working-day foreign currency surpluses in excess of their authorized operating balances to commercial banks. At the end of the day, the CBE stands ready to buy commercial bank foreign currency balances in excess of their authorized net open position. Authorized commercial banks are permitted to conduct forward foreign exchange transactions for their own accounts. CBE approval is not required, and the banks are free to determine the rates for forward transactions. Decree No. 40 of 2006; www.cbe.org.eg. No. Certain products require import licenses issued by specific government agencies, including National Defense, Agriculture and Livestock, Public Health, Environment and Natural Resources, and the Surveillance Board of the Pharmaceutical Chemicals Profession. Licenses issued by the Ministry of Economy (MOE) are required for ethyl alcohol, whether denatured or not; refined or raw cane sugar; corn; wheat flour; and rice. Prior authorization by the Ministry of Defense is required for imports of weapons and explosives. For imports of chemicals, an environmental permit is required from either the Ministry of the Environment and Natural Resources or the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock. El Salvador prohibits imports of the following products for reasons of health, security, public morality, or environmental protection: subversive materials or materials containing teachings contrary to the political, social, and economic order; obscene materials; unethical or indecent films; abortion-related products; and slot machines. Imports of coffee in a form that can be used as seeds for planting and imports of coffee bushes are prohibited. Also prohibited are lightweight passenger and freight motor vehicles more than 8 years old, and heavy passenger and freight vehicles more than 15 years old, except collectors’ items and vehicles donated to the state or to public service or charitable organizations, those used exclusively by disabled persons, those performing a specific service, such as agricultural, earth- moving, or industrial work, and those connected with power-generation plants, well drilling, and water purification units. The MOE grants import permits or licenses for products that are subject to some form of quota under the free trade agreement with the United States, including beef, pork, milk in liquid or powdered form, other dairy products, yellow or white corn, sorghum, chicken parts, and rice. Sugar intended for the domestic market must be fortified with vitamin A. El Salvador has authorization from the WTO to use the minimum price valuation method for imports of the following used articles: clothing; televisions; shoes; retreaded tires; sacks or bags for packing; and used vehicles, spare parts, and accessories. Prior to entry into the country, all these products must undergo fumigation. The following tariff rates apply: (1) capital goods, zero; (2) finished goods, 15%; (3) automobiles, firearms, cigarettes, liquor, luxury goods, textiles, garments, and shoes, 25% to 30%; and (4) meat, rice, sugar, alcohol, and spirits, 40% plus an additional 5% on alcoholic beverages and tobacco. Yes. n.a. Exchange Arrangement The currency issued within the CAEMC, which is legal tender in Equatorial Guinea and the other member countries, is the CFA franc. Unitary. Equatorial Guinea participates in a currency union with five other members of the CAEMC and has no separate legal tender. The CFA franc is pegged to the euro, the intervention currency, at a fixed rate of CFAF 655.957 per €1. Exchange transactions in euros between the BEAC and commercial banks are made at the same rate. Buying and selling rates for certain other foreign currencies are also officially posted, with quotations based on the fixed rate for the euro and the rates in the Paris exchange market for the currencies concerned. Effective January 1, 2007, the exchange rate regime of the CAEMC countries has been reclassified to the category conventional pegged arrangement from the category exchange arrangement with no separate legal tender. The new classification is based on the behavior of the common currency, whereas the previous classification was based on the lack of a separate legal tender. The new classification thus reflects only a definitional change and is not based on a judgment that there has been a substantive change in the exchange regime or other policies of the currency union or its members. A commission of 0.5%, excluding VAT, is levied on transfers to countries that are not members of the BEAC. This commission is not levied on transfers relating to central and local government operations, payments for imports covered by a duly issued license and domiciled with a bank, scheduled repayments on loans properly contracted abroad, travel allowances paid by the government and its agencies for official missions, and payments of insurance premiums. Exchange regulations of CAEMC member countries are harmonized. The Ministry of Economy, Commerce, and Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises (MECSMSE) is responsible for administering foreign exchange regulations and may delegate all or a portion of its power to the BEAC, the Banking Commission in Central Africa (COBAC), and authorized intermediaries. Authorized intermediaries are usually delegated to administer foreign exchange transactions and are responsible for checking the validity of transactions, collecting statistics, and reporting to the monetary authorities. The tasks delegated exclude some types of transactions. The BEAC ensures exchange regulation surveillance, evaluates cover against exchange risk, studies matters for which advice may be requested when foreign exchange accounts are opened by some resident legal entities, and monitors the repatriation of export proceeds. COBAC must ensure that the authorized intermediaries comply with the specific provisions of these regulations and do not destabilize the CAEMC banking system. Not for Redistribution Financial credits By residents to nonresidents To residents from nonresidents Guarantees, sureties, and financial backup facilities Controls on direct investment Outward direct investment Inward direct investment Controls on liquidation of direct investment Controls on real estate transactions Purchase abroad by residents Purchase locally by nonresidents Sale locally by nonresidents Controls on personal capital transactions Loans By residents to nonresidents To residents from nonresidents Gifts, endowments, inheritances, and legacies EQUATORIAL GUINEA Residents may generally freely grant financial credits to or borrow from nonresidents. Authorization is required, however, when (1) borrowing is guaranteed by the government or made by public or quasi-public enterprises, (2) the total outstanding debt of a resident borrower exceeds CFAF 100 million, and (3) the total outstanding amount of the loan granted by a resident lender exceeds CFAF 100 million. Loans exceeding CFAF 100 million require authorization unless they are granted by a resident authorized bank. When the total outstanding debt of a borrower exceeds CFAF 100 million, authorization from the appropriate authorities is required. The same applies to borrowing guaranteed by the government or made by public or quasi-public enterprises. Controls apply to all these transactions. Direct investment abroad by residents is not restricted, provided the amount of the transactions does not exceed CFAF 100 million or it is in the form of an increase in capital resulting from the reinvestment of undistributed profits. Only authorized banks may verify and execute these transactions. Direct investment abroad by residents in amounts exceeding CFAF 100 million must be declared to the MECSMSE 30 days before it is made. Direct investment from abroad is not restricted, provided the amount of the transactions does not exceed CFAF 100 million or it is in the form of an increase in capital resulting from the reinvestment of undistributed profits. Only authorized banks may verify and execute these transactions. Direct investment from abroad exceeding CFAF 100 million must be declared to the MECSMSE 30 days before it is made. The liquidation of foreign direct investment in Equatorial Guinea and abroad in amounts exceeding CFAF 100 million must be declared to the MECSMSE 30 days before liquidation. This category of transaction is not subject to specific regulations. It is implicitly subject to the same regulatory provisions as transactions involving the direct investment of financial assets. Currency Exchange rate structure Dual Classification Conventional pegged arrangement Exchange tax Exchange subsidy Foreign exchange market Spot exchange market Operated by the central bank Allocation Auction Fixing Interbank market References to legal instruments and hyperlinks Exchange Arrangement The currency of Eritrea is the Eritrean nakfa. Effective January 1, 2007, the exchange rate structure has been reclassified from unitary to dual because, despite the unification of the exchange rate, the parallel market rate deviates significantly from the official exchange rate. The nakfa is pegged to the U.S. dollar at the exchange rate of ERN 15 per $1. The Bank of Eritrea (BE) prescribes a 0.5% commission on sales and a 0.25% commission on purchases of foreign exchange, except for banknote transactions. ADs are permitted, but not required, to levy an additional service charge of up to 0.25% for buying and 0.75% for selling foreign exchange on their own accounts. No. ADs conducting transactions in the foreign exchange market are to apply the official exchange rate of ERN 15 per $1. There is only one foreign exchange bureau authorized to engage in foreign exchange operations. The black market premium is estimated to be in the 15% to 20% range, but the size of the parallel market is unknown. A government-appointed committee including the governor of the central bank is in charge of allocating foreign exchange across sectors. Essential commodity imports are given priority access to foreign currency. n.a. n.a. n.a. n.a. 461 ©International Monetary Fund.
