The maximum amount of ECB credit that a corporation can obtain under the automatic route is the equivalent of $500 million in a financial year. All corporations registered under the Companies Act (except banks, financial institutions, housing finance companies, and nonbank financial companies) may borrow abroad up to the equivalent of $20 million for loans of a minimum three years average maturity and up to $500 million for loans of more than five years average maturity under the automatic route without RBI approval. Effective August 7, 2007, borrowing (up to $500 million for permissible end uses) is allowed only for foreign currency exposure. As of the same date external borrowing up to $20 million requires RBI approval. Effective May 21, 2007, borrowing with an average maturity of three to five years is subject to a maximum spread of 150 basis points (previously, 200 basis points) over the six-month LIBOR of the currency in which the loans are raised or the applicable benchmark(s), and borrowing with more than five years average maturity is subject to a maximum spread of 250 basis points (previously, 350 basis points). Under the approval route, corporations can obtain ECB loans of an additional amount of $250 million with average maturity of more than 10 years over and above the existing limit of $500 million under the automatic route during a financial year. ADs may issue performance bonds or guarantees in favor of overseas buyers for bona fide exports from India, as well as guarantees in the ordinary course of business for missing documents or authenticity of signatures and for other similar purposes. The RBI has granted general permission to agents of foreign shipping and airline companies to give guarantees on behalf of their companies for any debt or other obligation—such as income tax, customs, or postage—to any central or state government agency in India. Banks may not issue a guarantee, standby LC, or letter of comfort of undertaking on behalf of their constituents in favor of an overseas lender to access external commercial borrowing or financial credit. However, banks may issue the same instruments in favor of an overseas lender on behalf of their importer constituents for trade credits (i.e., buyer or supplier credit) for imports of noncapital goods for up to a year and capital goods for a period of less than three years and up to the equivalent of $20 million an import transaction, without RBI approval. The RBI allows ADs to grant loans to residents against guarantees from nonresidents, subject to, among other things, the condition that no direct or indirect payment is made abroad by way of guarantee, commission, or otherwise. Effective June 14, 2007, Indian companies and registered partnerships acquiring foreign companies or investing directly abroad in joint ventures or wholly owned subsidiaries may invest up to 300% (previously 200%) of their net worth through the automatic route. This limit was further raised on September 26, 2007, to 400% from 300%. For the purpose of investing abroad net worth is calculated as of the date of the company’s latest audited balance sheet. Indian corporations may fund overseas direct investment in joint ventures or wholly owned subsidiaries with external commercial borrowing. Financial entities investing abroad in any activity must also obtain approval from the regulatory authorities concerned in India and abroad. Indian corporations may also use proceeds of ECB credits for investment in joint ventures or wholly owned subsidiaries abroad. Companies may freely 636 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Inward direct investment INDIA invest the proceeds of their ADR and GDR issuances for acquisition of foreign companies and direct investment in joint ventures and wholly owned subsidiaries. Companies may also invest by way of share-swap transactions under the automatic route, subject to approval by the Foreign Investment Promotion Board for the inward leg of the transaction. This route is not available for investments in Pakistan. The annual limit for rupee investments in Bhutan and Nepal under the automatic route is 400% of net worth. Investment in Bhutan is also permitted in freely convertible currencies. Indian corporations and partnership firms may invest in agricultural activity abroad incidental to this activity either directly or through their overseas offices (i.e., purchase of land through a joint venture or wholly owned subsidiary) within the limit for investment under the automatic route. Resident employees of a foreign company’s office, branch, or subsidiary in India in which the foreign company holds not less than 51% equity, either directly or indirectly, may invest under an employee stock option plan without limit, subject to certain conditions. Foreign direct investment (FDI) up to 100% is allowed under the automatic route in most sectors. In some sectors, less than 100% is allowed (private sector banks; insurance, telecommunications, and single-brand product retailing; stock exchanges; print media; asset-reconstruction companies; broadcasting; defense production; companies investing in infrastructure or the services sector (except the telecom sector); satellites; and air transport services). There are other exclusions, including industrial licensing and locational policies. FDI is not permitted in retail trade (except single-brand retailing), lotteries, gambling, atomic energy, housing and real estate, and agriculture (excluding floriculture, horticulture, development of seeds, animal husbandry, pisciculture, and the cultivation of vegetables, mushrooms, etc., under controlled conditions and services related to agriculture and allied sectors), and plantations, except tea plantations. Foreign companies may establish branch offices or units in SEZs to undertake manufacturing and service activities. FDI in nonretail trading companies requires registration with the Ministry of Commerce and Industry and a certificate showing a trading company’s status as an export trading, star trading, or superstar trading house. The automatic route permits foreign investment of up to 51% of the paid-up capital of such Indian companies. Foreign investment in print media requires registration with the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting and is subject to the following restrictions: (1) Foreign investment in companies engaged in the publication of news or information about current affairs may not exceed 26%. (2) Foreign investment in other print media may not exceed 74% of the paid-up capital of the company, including all foreign direct and indirect investment; NRI, PIO, or FII investment; and investment on a repatriation or nonrepatriation basis. FDI in the insurance sector requires a license from the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority. Applications for investment in areas that do not fall within the automatic route but that are covered by the foreign investment policy require Foreign Investment Promotion Board (FIFB) approval. Such investment may be approved in accordance with sector-specific guidelines and sectoral equity ceilings. The Department of Economic Affairs of the North Block is the relevant agency for all FDI proposals, other than by NRIs and proposals in single-product retailing. The latter are granted approval by the Department of Industrial Policy and Promotion of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. General permission has also been granted to foreign venture capital investors who have obtained permission under the FEMA from the RBI and are registered with the SEBI to invest in an Indian venture capital undertaking or VCF. Foreign investment up to 49% is allowed in stock exchanges, depositories, and clearing corporations, with FIFB approval. FDI is allowed up to 100% in (1) distillation and brewing of potable alcohol; (2) manufacture of industrial explosives; (3) manufacture of hazardous chemicals; (4) 637 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDIA manufacturing activities located within 25 kilometers of the standard urban area limits that require an industrial license under the Industries Development and Regulation Act, 1951; (5) setting up greenfield airport projects; (6) laying natural gas/liquid natural gas (LNG) pipelines, market study and formulation, and investment financing in the petroleum and natural gas sector; (7) cash and carry wholesale trading and export trading; (8) coal and lignite mining for captive consumption; (9) setting up infrastructure relating to marketing in the petroleum and natural gas sector; (10) exploration and mining of diamonds and precious stones; and (11) the petroleum and national gas retail industry. Effective April 19, 2007, FDI in certain telecom services was raised to 74% from 49%. NRIs may use funds derived from fresh remittances or held in their NRE or FCNR accounts to (1) make portfolio investments with repatriation benefits of up to 5% of the paid- up capital, provided their total holdings of shares and convertible debentures held under the Package Scheme of Incentives do not exceed 10% (extendable to 24% if the general meeting of the investing company passes a special resolution) of the paid-up capital of the company or of the total paid-in value of each series of convertible debentures issued by the company; (2) invest freely in national savings certificates with full repatriation benefits. Existing joint-venture companies may raise the ratio of foreign equity shares to prescribed percentages of their capital through expansion of their capital base or through preferential allocation of shares to the foreign investor; and (3) invest on a nonrepatriable basis in money market mutual funds (only NRIs), subject to RBI approval. Outstanding external commercial borrowing and lump-sum fees and royalties may be converted into equity without RBI prior approval. Shares may be sold freely on the stock exchange and the sale proceeds repatriated. Other sales of shares, securities, or immovable property may be allowed by authorized banks after complying with conditions prescribed by the RBI. RBI approval is required only for sales of shares in financial sector companies or in cases where preconditions and norms have not been fulfilled. Repatriation of after- tax sales proceeds is generally permitted, provided no condition of nonrepatriation was imposed when the original investment was approved. These transactions require the permission of the RBI. Residents may hold, own, or transfer immovable property outside India, provided such property was acquired while the person resided outside India or was obtained through an inheritance or as a gift. That person is also free to dispose of such property or acquire new property from the sale proceeds of such property. Residents may buy immovable property abroad using RFC accounts. Effective September 26, 2007, residents may acquire property abroad using a personal remittance up to the equivalent of $200,000 (previously, $100,000) a financial year. General permission has been granted to Indian companies that have established offices abroad to acquire immovable property abroad for their business use and for staff residences. NRIs may invest in companies engaged in real estate development (e.g., construction of houses). ADs and housing companies may extend loans to NRIs and PIOs for acquiring residences in India. Repatriation of after-tax sales proceeds is permitted up to the amount brought in to purchase the property, subject to certain conditions. ADs may allow remittances of up to the equivalent of $1 million a year—subject to the payment of applicable taxes—for sales of immovable property. Provisions specific to commercial banks and other credit institutions Borrowing abroad Provisions Specific to the Financial Sector External commercial borrowing is subject to the policy framed by the RBI in consultation with the MOF. ADs may avail themselves of foreign currency borrowing not exceeding 25% of their unimpaired tier I capital or the equivalent of $10 million, whichever is higher. Banks may raise capital using two foreign exchange instruments. First, banks may augment their capital funds through the issue of innovative perceptual debt instruments in foreign currency up to 49% of the eligible amount (i.e., 15% of tier I capital) without RBI approval, subject to compliance with certain specified conditions. Second, banks may augment their capital funds through the issue of upper tier II instruments in foreign currency up to 25% of their unimpaired tier I capital without RBI approval, subject to compliance with certain specified conditions. Capital funds raised through the issuance of these two instruments in foreign currency are in addition to the existing limit for foreign currency borrowing by ADs. During 2007, the cash reserve ratio (CRR) was increased from 5.5% by 25 basis points on five occasions, effective January 6, 2007, February 17, 2007, March 3, 2007, April 14, 2007, and April 28, 2007. The CRR was further increased by 50 basis points on August 4, 2007, and on November 10, 2007. Effective November 10, 2007, all rupee and foreign currency deposits are subject to a CRR of 7.5% of net demand and time liabilities. Credit balances in ACU (dollar) accounts, transactions in collateralized borrowing and lending obligations with Clearing Corporation of India, Ltd., net interbank liabilities between 15 days and one year, and demand and time liabilities of the banks’ offshore banking units, however, are exempt from reserve requirements. All rupee and foreign currency deposits are subject to a statutory liquidity ratio of 25% of net demand and time liabilities. Effective April 24, 2007, interest rates with respect to FCNR (B) deposits of all maturities contracted must be paid within the ceiling rate of LIBOR or swap rates minus 75 basis points for the respective currency or corresponding maturities (previously, minus 25 basis points). On floating rate deposits, interest must be paid within the ceiling of swap rates minus 75 basis points for the respective currency or corresponding maturity. For floating rate deposits, the interest reset period must be six months. Effective April 24, 2007, interest rates on NRE deposits for one to three years should not exceed the LIBOR or swap rate, as of the last business day of the previous month, for dollar deposits of corresponding maturity (LIBOR/swap rate plus 50 basis points, effective January 31, 2007, previously 100 basis points). The maturity period of NRE deposits should usually be one to three years. If a bank accepts deposits with maturities of more than three years, it may do so, provided the interest rates on such long-term deposits are not higher than the rate on three- year NRE deposits. The LIBOR/swap rates as of the last business day of the preceding month are used as the basis for ceiling rates offered the following month. The LIBOR/swap rates on the last business day of each month announced by the Foreign Exchange Dealers Association of India must be taken as the base rates for the interest rate ceiling. n.a. Measures have been taken to freeze the accounts and assets of and prohibit payments to listed individuals and organizations associated with terrorism, in accordance with the relevant UN Security Council resolutions. Restrictions against countries on which the UN has imposed a trade embargo are in effect. n.a. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Indonesia is the Indonesian rupiah. Commemorative gold coins are also legal tender but seldom circulate. Unitary. Indonesia adopted a freely floating exchange rate arrangement on August 14, 1997. The exchange rate is determined by supply and demand in the foreign exchange market. However, the Bank Indonesia (BI) may intervene in the foreign exchange market to prevent undue fluctuations in the exchange rate. Reflecting developments in the exchange rate following official interventions, the de facto exchange rate arrangement is classified as managed floating with no predetermined path for the exchange rate. Not for Redistribution INDONESIA may be imported by industrial firms for their own use or for reconditioning, in accordance with the guidelines of the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MOT). Certain categories of agricultural imports, including foodstuffs, beverages, and fruits, may be imported only by registered importers designated by the MOT. The procurement policies of companies approved for the importation of fruit, alcoholic beverages, and chicken are evaluated annually by the government, although explicit quantitative restrictions are not placed on these products. There is an import ban on rice. There is a registry of authorized importers that includes only Indonesian nationals, although foreign investors are permitted to import the items required for their own projects. Although all imports into Indonesia are subject to licensing requirements, most are classified under the General Importer License. Certain products are granted preferential duties within the framework of AFTA and the WTO. A 5% tariff applies to imports of capital goods and raw materials. Import taxes are collected through foreign exchange banks authorized by the MOF. Imports of certain goods remain restricted to approved importers, most of which are state enterprises. Petramina has a monopoly on the importation of lubricating oil and lubricating grease, and Dahana on the importation of ammunition and gel explosives. The monopoly rights of approved importers (sole agents) also remain in effect for the importation of certain heavy equipment and motor vehicles, although this right may be transferred to general importers. The importation of trucks is restricted. n.a. Controls on capital transactions Repatriation requirements Capital Transactions Onshore banks are prohibited from conducting the following transactions with nonresidents: (1) lending or provision of overdrafts in rupiah or foreign currency, except for noncash credit or guarantees pertaining to investment activities in Indonesia with certain requirements; (2) placing funds in rupiah with nonresidents, including rupiah transfers to banks abroad; (3) purchase of rupiah-denominated securities issued by nonresidents, except securities related to export or import activities and bank drafts issued by overseas banks for the accounts of Indonesian workers overseas; (4) interoffice transactions in rupiah and interoffice accounts in foreign currency for provision of credit outside Indonesia; (5) equity participation in rupiah with nonresidents; and (6) rupiah transfers to an account held by nonresidents and/or a joint account held by a nonresident and a resident at a domestic or foreign bank, except for economic activities in Indonesia or between accounts held by the same nonresident. Not for Redistribution Controls on capital and money market instruments On capital market securities Shares or other securities of a participating nature Purchase locally by nonresidents Sale or issue locally by nonresidents Sale or issue abroad by residents Bonds or other debt securities Purchase locally by nonresidents Sale or issue locally by nonresidents Purchase abroad by residents Sale or issue abroad by residents On money market instruments Purchase locally by nonresidents Sale or issue locally by nonresidents Purchase abroad by residents Sale or issue abroad by residents On collective investment securities Purchase locally by nonresidents Controls on derivatives and other instruments INDONESIA Foreign investors are allowed to purchase without limit shares issued by Indonesian companies in the Indonesian capital market. There is a limit on ownership of joint securities companies that are also finance companies. Foreign companies are permitted to issue Indonesian depository receipts (IDRs) through custodian banks in Indonesia. IDRs are instruments that facilitate the trading of shares of foreign companies in the Indonesian capital market. Custodian banks in turn issue IDRs based on the shares that the foreign companies have in the custodian bank. No controls apply as long as the shares are not listed on the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX). Securities listed on the IDX should comply with the Capital Market Act and with the requirement concerning the maximum percentage of foreign ownership of shares. Indonesian companies do not issue shares; they issue U.S. depository receipts in the U.S. capital markets and global depository receipts on the London Stock Exchange. Foreign investors may purchase government bonds issued in the primary market without limitation, except for government bonds issued for individual or retail investors. The purchase of such bonds by nonresidents is allowed only in the secondary market. n.r. Yes. Banks are allowed to issue securities on primary capital markets, subject to regulations on offshore loans. Yes. Yes. The regulations governing bonds or other debt securities apply. The approval of the BI is required for issuance of instruments by banks with maturities of more than one year. Issuance of instruments with maturities of less than one year does not require approval; however, the value of the instruments should not exceed 30% of a bank’s capital. Instruments issued by nonbank corporate entities must fulfill prudential requirements and must be reported to the BI. No person may purchase more than 1% of any fund. Effective May 5, 2007, banks are allowed to conduct derivative transactions only with foreign exchange or interest rate derivatives. In addition, banks must enter into a written agreement with their clients and explain the risks of these transactions and must submit an online daily report to the BI. Not for Redistribution Controls on credit operations Commercial credits By residents to nonresidents To residents from nonresidents Financial credits By residents to nonresidents Guarantees, sureties, and financial backup facilities By residents to nonresidents Controls on direct investment Inward direct investment INDONESIA derivative exposure transacted by their branches or subsidiaries. Domestic banks’ forward and swap sales or option transactions involving sale to and/or purchase from nonresidents of foreign currency against rupiah are limited to the equivalent of $1 million a bank or a customer, except for hedging purposes with underlying investment-related transactions in Indonesia with a time frame of no less than three months and for merchandise exports and imports using LCs. Resident banks are prohibited from granting credit to nonresidents (including overdrafts in rupiah or foreign currencies). Resident entities, including nonbank corporate entities, may borrow from nonresidents subject to compliance with the applicable regulations and the submission of periodic reports to the BI. Nonbank corporate entities intending to borrow are required to implement risk management procedures; long-term foreign borrowing must be rated by a credit rating agency, a foreign borrowing plan for one year, and a risk management analysis. There are limitations on the granting of credit by banks to nonresidents. Banks are allowed to provide sureties and guarantees to nonresident entities only under the following conditions: (1) when there is a sufficient counterguarantee from bona fide overseas banks (excluding overseas branches of the bank involved) and (2) when there is a cash deposit valued at 100% of the guarantee. Several sectors are subject to controls: (1) Foreign investment companies in infrastructure projects, such as seaports; electricity generation, transmission, and distribution for public use; telecommunications; shipping; airlines; potable water supply; public railways; and nuclear electric power generation should be established by way of a joint venture between foreign and Indonesian partners, and the share of Indonesian partners should be at least 5% of the total capital issued at the establishment of the company. (2) A foreign investment company may be established as a straight investment; that is, 100% of the shares may be owned by a foreign citizen and/or entity. However, some of the company’s shares must be sold to Indonesian citizens and/or entities through direct placement and/or indirectly through the domestic capital market no later than 15 years after the commencement of commercial operations. Foreign ownership of direct investments must begin to be divested by the 11th year of production. For investments above $50 million or its equivalent, divestment of 50% must be completed within 20 years. For smaller investments, the divestment requirement is less stringent. All foreign enterprises are eligible to receive preferential customs duty treatment for imports of required raw materials for the first two years of production activity. There is no limit on the period that foreign investment companies can import raw materials. In addition, an enterprise exporting more than 65% of its production is free to hire foreign experts as needed to meet its export commitments. Income tax waivers are granted for up to eight years to newly established corporations in 22 industrial sectors. Takeovers of nonstrategic operations by foreign investors are permitted without government approval. 652 ©International Monetary Fund. Restrictions and/or multiple currency practices Exchange measures imposed for security reasons In accordance with IMF Executive Board Decision No. 144-(52/51) Other security restrictions References to legal instruments and hyperlinks Currency Exchange rate structure Classification Crawling peg Exchange tax Exchange subsidy Exchange Measures The IMF staff report for the 2006 Article IV consultation with the Islamic Republic of Iran states that, as of February 1, 2007, Iran maintains one exchange restriction and two multiple currency practices (MCPs) subject to IMF jurisdiction under Article VIII, Sections 2(a) and 3. The exchange restriction arises from limitations set out in the by-laws adopted to implement the Foreign Investment Promotion and Protection Act on the transferability of (periodic) rial profits from certain foreign direct investments. The MCPs arise from (1) budget subsidies for foreign exchange purchases in connection with payments of certain letters of credit opened prior to March 21, 2002, under the previous multiple exchange rate system and (2) obligations of entities that had received allocations of foreign exchange at subsidized “allocated rates” under the previous multiple exchange rate system to surrender unused allocations to the Central Bank of Iran at the allocation rate. (Country Report No. 07/100) All banking, finance, and credit institutions have been instructed by the Central Bank of Iran (BMJII) to freeze suspected accounts, based on an official list. These measures were taken in accordance with UN Security Council resolutions. Yes. n.a. Exchange Arrangement The currency of the Islamic Republic of Iran is the Iranian rial. Unitary. The Islamic Republic of Iran continues to maintain a de jure managed floating arrangement against a basket. Starting in November 2007, the rial gradually depreciated against a composite of currencies, including the euro, the dollar, and the yen. Thus, effective January 4, 2008, the classification of the de facto exchange rate arrangement has been changed from a conventional pegged arrangement to a crawling peg. Currency Exchange rate structure Classification Crawling peg Exchange tax Exchange subsidy Foreign exchange market Spot exchange market Operated by the central bank Allocation Auction Exchange Arrangement The currency of Iraq is the Iraqi dinar. Unitary. Under a policy of pursuing exchange rate stability, the Central Bank of Iraq (CBI) limited the fluctuations of the dinar to within ±1% until October 2006. Since then, the CBI has changed its monetary stance and allowed the exchange rate to gradually appreciate following a predetermined path. Within these limits, the exchange rate of the dinar is determined in the foreign exchange market. No. No. n.a. Auctions are held daily, and eligible bidders may buy and sell foreign exchange at freely determined rates. All final transactions are allocated at a single settlement price. Brokerage companies buying and selling foreign currency are authorized to charge commissions in Iraqi dinars not exceeding 0.25% for purchases and 0.5% for sales. Exchange bureaus of private banks are permitted to participate in the daily auction but must remain within the bureau’s capital ceiling. The amounts of letters of guarantee issued to the CBI by brokerage companies to insure against the misuse of foreign exchange transfers and to ensure good performance by brokerage firms in buying and selling foreign currencies authorized by the CBI and compliance with relevant instructions are up to 20% of a company’s capital. 663 ©International Monetary Fund. On August 2, 2007, the authorities notified the IMF that Ireland maintains certain restrictions in accordance with EU regulations solely for the preservation of national and international security. These include the freezing of funds and economic resources of certain individuals and entities in Belarus, Côte d’Ivoire, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, the Islamic Republic of Iran, Iraq, Lebanon, Liberia, Myanmar, Somalia, Sudan, Uzbekistan, the former Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, and Zimbabwe; of persons and entities associated with Osama bin Laden, Al-Qaida, and the Taliban; and of certain other persons, groups, and entities, with a view to combating terrorism. Certain restrictions apply to the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea. In accordance with EU regulations and the relevant UN Security Council resolutions, certain restrictions are maintained on the making of payments and transfers for current international transactions with respect to the former government of Iraq, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Myanmar, certain individuals associated with the previous government of the former Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, Côte d’Ivoire, Liberia, Sudan, Uzbekistan, Zimbabwe, certain persons suspected of involvement in the assassination of former Lebanese Prime Minister Rafik Hariri, and in support of the effective implementation of the mandate of the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia. Financing related to military activities in Lebanon and Somalia is prohibited. Restrictions also apply to transfers and transactions with persons and entities associated with Osama bin Laden, Al-Qaida, and the Taliban and individuals and organizations associated with terrorism. It is prohibited to provide financing or other types of assistance, which may aid in the development of nuclear weapons in the Democratic People’s Republic of North Korea (effective March 27, 2007) and in the Islamic Republic of Iran (effective April 19, 2007). http://ec.europa.eu/external_relations/cfsp/sanctions/index.htm. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Ireland is the euro. Unitary. Ireland participates in a currency union with 14 other members of the EMU and has no separate legal tender. The euro, the common currency, floats freely and independently against other currencies. Effective January 1, 2007, the exchange 670 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRELAND rate arrangement of the EMU countries has been reclassified to the category independently floating from the category exchange arrangement with no separate legal tender. The new classification is based on the behavior of the common currency, whereas the previous classification was based on the lack of a separate legal tender. The new classification thus reflects only a definitional change and is not based on a judgment that there has been a substantive change in the exchange regime or other policies of the currency union or its members. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Italy is the euro. Unitary. Italy participates in a currency union with 14 other members of the EMU and has no separate legal tender. The euro, the common currency, floats freely and independently against other currencies. Effective January 1, 2007, the exchange rate arrangement of the EMU countries has been reclassified to the category independently floating from the category exchange arrangement with no separate legal tender. The new classification is based on the behavior of the common currency, whereas the previous classification was based on the lack of a separate legal tender. The new classification thus reflects only a definitional change and is 679 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ITALY not based on a judgment that there has been a substantive change in the exchange regime or other policies of the currency union or its members. The accounts are used for trade in cross-border areas. The balances in these accounts may be used only to finance trade between certain districts of Croatia and Slovenia and the Italian provinces of Trieste and Gorizia. The balances are not transferable. There is no automatic mechanism through which outstanding balances are settled within 90 days. Only Italy is allowed to maintain a debit balance on these accounts. Residents are allowed to conduct foreign exchange transactions freely, with settlements effected either indirectly—through the Bank of Italy, other financial intermediaries, or the Poste Italiane S.p.a.—or directly by drawing on external accounts or by offsetting debits and credits vis-à-vis other residents or nonresidents. Effective January 1, 2008, the Ufficio Italiano dei Cambi (UIC) merged with the Banca d’Italia. All related powers and functions have been transferred to the Banca d’Italia. Any reference to the UIC in laws and regulations is to be interpreted as referring to the Banca d’Italia (Legislative Decree 231 of November 21, 2007). Effective January 1, 2008, data on all foreign transactions exceeding the equivalent of €50,000 between Italian residents and residents in EU member countries or in Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, or Switzerland must be reported to the Banca d’Italia for statistical purposes; the amount to be reported remains €12,500 for transactions with residents of other countries. Previously, operators and intermediaries were required to report to the UIC, for statistical purposes, data on foreign transactions that exceeded the equivalent of €12,500 by filling out a foreign exchange statistical return. Commemorative gold coins in denominations of J$100 and J$500 and souvenir coins in denominations of J$5, J$10, J$25, J$50, and J$100 are legal tender but do not circulate. Unitary. The exchange rate of the Jamaican dollar is determined in the domestic foreign exchange market. No. No. n.a. n.a. n.a. The market is operated by ADs, cambios, bureaux de change, and the Bank of Jamaica (BOJ). ADs include all commercial banks, selected merchant banks, and the three largest building societies. ADs engage in (1) the purchase and sale of foreign currency in the form of cash, drafts, traveler’s checks, and other instruments; (2) granting loans and taking deposits; and (3) making other international payments. Cambios are allowed to purchase and sell unlimited amounts of foreign exchange in any form to any person. Their main function is the exchange of currency for hotel guests. However, unlike ADs, cambios are not permitted to grant loans or accept deposits. Excess foreign exchange may be sold 685 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution JAMAICA without restriction to commercial banks, other ADs, and the general public. Proceeds from official loans, divestment of government assets, and taxes on the bauxite sector payable in foreign currency are sold directly to the BOJ. The BOJ purchases foreign exchange from ADs and cambios under the following terms: (1) Purchases are made in U.S. dollars, Canadian dollars, pounds sterling, and euros. (2) The minimum amount the BOJ will purchase in a single transaction is 50,000 units of the foreign currency. (3) The exchange rates for these currencies are negotiated by the BOJ. This market is currently inactive. www.boj.org.jm/uploads/pdf/papers_pamphlets/ papers_pamphlets_How_The_Foreign_Exchange_Market_Works_.pdf. Surrender may be made in any of these three major currencies as well as in euros. Surrender of Canadian dollars and pounds sterling may be made in U.S. dollars and must be covered at the cross-currency rate derived from their respective weighted-average buying rates in the local market on the day of purchase. Payments to all countries may be made by crediting Jamaican dollars to an external account or a foreign currency account. Receipts in any foreign currency from all countries must be debited to an external account. Economic agents are free to settle all transactions with domestic currency. The Jamaican dollar may be used to conduct and settle all current and capital transactions. The clearing arrangements formerly in place under CARICOM ceased to be in effect on September 25, 1991. The BOJ no longer intervenes in CARICOM private sector commercial transactions; settlements for such transactions are effected by the commercial banking sector in convertible currencies. Exporters and importers from CARICOM members make their own arrangements for settling their transactions. Trading in foreign exchange, other than by and through an AD, is prohibited. In addition, any foreign currency dealings conducted in the course of business, whether by residents or nonresidents, must either (1) be authorized in the capacity as ADs or (2) be exempt as a result of a ministerial order of exemption, pursuant to section 22c of the BOJ Act. Individuals to whom foreign asset acquisition restrictions apply are listed in section 22 b(1) of the BOJ Act. Those individuals may acquire foreign assets (including foreign securities) only pursuant to directives issued by the BOJ. Acquisition of foreign assets is governed by the following directives issued under the BOJ Act: (1) Securities dealers’ activities are limited to securities issued by the government of Jamaica and securities issued or guaranteed by the governments of the United States, the United Kingdom, or Canada. Imports are subject to customs tariffs of up to 20% for nonagricultural products and 40% for agricultural products, in compliance with the fourth phase of the CARICOM CET. Some agricultural imports are subject to additional stamp duties of up to 95%. Taxes are collected by customs agents at the port of entry. The WTO- bound tariffs on 10 categories of agricultural products (certain poultry and vegetables) are 100%. Additional stamp duties on these imported products raise the rate of total duty payable to 260%. On March 23, 2007, the authorities notified the IMF that Japan has imposed financial sanctions against the Islamic Republic of Iran in accordance with UN Security Council Resolution 1737. The measures include freezing the assets of 10 entities and 12 individuals designated in the annex of the resolution as engaged in the Islamic Republic of Iran’s nuclear and other activities and the prohibition of payments to Iran for the purpose of contributing to the supply, sale, or transfer to Iran, or the manufacture or use in Iran, of any goods or technology related to Iran’s nuclear and other activities. A license from the MOF and the Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI) is required for capital transactions between residents and the following nonresidents: (1) organizations, high officials, and persons affiliated with the former government of Iraq, in accordance with a UN Security Council resolution; (2) former Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic and persons affiliated with him; (3) Al-Qaida and the Taliban, and individuals, groups, and organizations associated with terrorism; (4) former Liberian President Charles Taylor, his immediate family, and senior officials of the former Taylor regime, in accordance with a UN resolution; (5) individuals and entities who violated the arms embargo to the Democratic Republic of the Congo, in accordance with a UN resolution; (6) individuals constituting a threat to the peace and national reconciliation process in Côte d’Ivoire; (7) individuals impeding the peace process in Darfur, Sudan; (8) entities and individuals involved with the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea’s missile or weapons of mass destruction programs; and (9) entities and individuals engaged in the Islamic Republic of Iran’s nuclear and other weapon activities. The Japanese tariff system is stipulated by the Customs Law, Customs Tariff Law, and Temporary Tariff Measures Law. The harmonized classification schedule annexed in the Customs Tariff Law sets out both the classification and the corresponding customs duty rate (called the general rate) of particular products. The rate actually applied, however, is not necessarily the general rate. The Temporary Tariff Measures Law sets out the temporary rate for certain products, which in these cases prevails over the general rate. In addition, when the customs duty rate in the WTO Concession Schedule (so-called WTO rate) or the rate set forth by the Economic Partnership Agreement (so-called EPA rate) is lower than the general rate (or the temporary rate, if applicable), the WTO rate or EPA rate is applied. Not for Redistribution KAZAKHSTAN (Position as of December 31, 2007) Article VIII Date of acceptance: July 16, 1996. Status under IMF Articles of Agreement Restrictions and/or multiple currency practices Exchange measures imposed for security reasons Other security restrictions References to legal instruments and hyperlinks Currency Exchange rate structure Classification Conventional pegged arrangement Exchange tax Exchange subsidy Foreign exchange market Exchange Measures No restrictions as reported in the latest staff report as of December 31, 2007. There is provision for the right to introduce a special permit regime for certain foreign exchange operations in the event of a threat to the economic security of Kazakhstan and the stability of its financial system. Decisions to introduce or extend the special permit regime, as well as the list of operations that may be performed only with a special permit, are determined by the president after joint consultations with the government and the National Bank of Kazakhstan (NBK). n.a. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Kazakhstan is the Kazakhstani tenge. Unitary. The de jure exchange rate arrangement is independently floating. The exchange rate of the tenge is determined on the basis of supply and demand in the foreign exchange market. The NBK intervenes in the domestic foreign exchange market to smooth the path of the tenge exchange rate against the dollar and prevent unjustified exchange rate fluctuations. The main intervention currency is the dollar. Because the tenge has remained within a 2% band as a result of official actions, effective October 1, 2007, the classification of the de facto exchange rate arrangement has been changed from managed floating with no predetermined path for the exchange rate to a conventional pegged arrangement. The official exchange rate of the tenge against the dollar is determined on the basis of daily quotes from the domestic currency market (the weighted average rate at 11:00 a.m. the previous day, based on trading results on the Kazakhstan Stock Exchange—KASE). The rates for other currencies are calculated on the basis of their quotes against the dollar on the global currency market. The NBK publishes daily exchange rates of certain currencies against the tenge for accounting and customs payments computation purposes. No. No. The foreign exchange market includes the KASE, which conducts daily trading online using an electronic trading system, an over-the-counter (OTC) interbank 707 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution KAZAKHSTAN market, and a network of more than 3,000 exchange bureaus handling foreign exchange cash transactions. n.a. n.a. n.a. Commercial banks set their own exchange rates without restrictions. Foreign exchange futures are quoted on the KASE. Forward exchange operations are also conducted in the interbank market. n.a. No. Foreign exchange control is provided by the NBK, other government bodies within the scope of their authority as established by law, and foreign exchange control agents. Foreign exchange control agents are authorized banks and authorized organizations performing certain types of banking operations, as well as other organizations that have been assigned responsibility for monitoring compliance with foreign exchange legislation in the performance of their operations in accordance with licenses they have received. The NBK monitors compliance by residents and nonresidents with the requirements of foreign exchange legislation and proper performance of the functions of foreign exchange control agents by authorized banks and authorized organizations. The MOF provides for monitoring and supervision of government loans, supervision of the earmarked and efficient use of government guaranteed loans, and monitoring of government and government guaranteed debt. There is a licensing regime for imports of alcoholic products, explosives, products for military use, weapons (official and civilian weapons), poisonous substances, industrial waste, nuclear materials (equipment), special equipment for use in police investigations, pesticides (toxic chemicals), opium raw materials, x-ray equipment, instruments and equipment using radioactive substances and isotopes, encryption equipment, white spirit, and light and medium distillates for specific types of processing and for chemical conversions in some processes. Imports of the following items are prohibited: weapons of mass destruction; narcotic drugs, psychotropic substances and their precursors, and paraphernalia for their use; printed and graphic materials aimed at the overthrow of the government and social order that contain propaganda promoting war, terrorism, violence, or racism, and materials with pornographic content; and ozone-depleting substances and products that contain ozone-depleting substances. Imports are subject to (1) VAT and customs duties (certain goods are exempt); (2) excise taxes (where applicable); and (3) antidumping, protection, and compensatory duties (if such duties exist). Not for Redistribution Repatriation requirements Financing requirements Documentation requirements Export licenses Without quotas With quotas KAZAKHSTAN Exports and Export Proceeds Effective January 1, 2007, residents must ensure that domestic and foreign currency received in payment for exports of goods (work, services) is credited to bank accounts with authorized banks within the time period stipulated by the terms of the transaction. Previously, repatriation was required within 180 days regardless of the terms of the transaction, and crediting export proceeds in foreign exchange to accounts at authorized banks after that deadline was subject to NBK licensing. The crediting of export proceeds by residents to accounts at authorized banks is not required in the following cases: (1) The foreign exchange proceeds are credited to accounts at foreign banks, and these accounts are intended to guarantee the resident’s obligations under the terms of a loan solicited from a nonresident. (2) The foreign exchange proceeds are credited to accounts at foreign banks, and these accounts are intended for the use of the resident’s overseas branches and representative offices. If export proceeds in foreign exchange are not credited to accounts at authorized banks, the repatriation requirement is considered to have been met in full or in part if (1) a nonresident’s obligation is offset by a counterclaim of the same nature; (2) a nonresident’s obligation is met by replacing the original obligation between the parties with a different obligation between the same parties that provides for a different objective or means of fulfillment; (3) the right of claim on a nonresident is assigned to another party; or (4) an insurance payment is received, if an insured event occurs under insurance agreements covering the risk of default by a nonresident. No. Effective January 1, 2007, an export contract or other supporting documents must be presented in order to make export payments and/or transfers. Effective January 1, 2007, a transaction passport must be completed for accounting purposes for export transactions involving the movement of goods valued in excess of the equivalent of $10,000 only at the authorized bank servicing the transaction (previously, at the customs agency and the servicing bank). The transaction passport is verified for compliance with the terms of the export contract and is monitored by the bank until completion of the transaction. Deferral of payment or advance payment on exports is considered a commercial credit. Effective January 1, 2007, the requirement that deferral of payment for a period of more than 180 days and in an amount exceeding $10,000 receive NBK approval was eliminated. Resident exporters are required to register a commercial credit for exports with the NBK in the following instances: (1) If a resident made advance delivery on exports valued in excess of the equivalent of $50,000 more than 180 days before the payment date. (2) If a nonresident makes a prepayment for exports valued in excess of the equivalent of $300,000 more than 180 days before the delivery date. Registration requirements do not apply to export contracts for which transaction passports are completed. Previously, advance delivery of exports for a period of up to 180 days was allowed without restriction. Export licenses are required for 17 categories of goods. Certain listed exports require licenses. Exports of sunflower seeds and soy, sunflower, safflower, cottonseed, and rapeseed oils were temporarily prohibited between January 1, 2007, and February 1, 2008. Provisions specific to commercial banks and other credit institutions Provisions Specific to the Financial Sector Banks are prohibited from engaging as a commercial entity in operations and transactions that are not classified as banking activity and are not explicitly stipulated in the Law on Banks and Banking Activity. Banks are prohibited from purchasing stakes in the authorized capital or shares of legal entities, with the exception of (1) financial institutions; (2) legal entities that are not financial institutions whose shares are listed in the highest listing category of a stock exchange operating in Kazakhstan; (3) credit bureaus, pawn shops, special financial companies established in accordance with the legislation of Kazakhstan on securitization, special nonresident organizations that are established for the purpose of the placement of securities, leasing organizations and organizations engaged exclusively in the ownership and management of real estate to support a bank’s operating activities, and legal entities engaged in the automation of banking 716 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution KAZAKHSTAN activities; (4) legal entities, if the shares in the authorized capital of these organizations have been accepted as collateral and become the property of banks in accordance with the civil legislation of Kazakhstan; (5) associations (unions) of banks; (6) resident joint-stock investment funds; and (7) nonresident legal entities that have the status of banks, insurance organizations, pension funds, or professional participants in the securities market. Limits on participation in the authorized capital (purchase of shares) of a legal entity depend on the ratio of (1) the value of the purchase to the bank’s equity capital, (2) the overall value of the bank’s shares in the authorized capital of legal entities to the bank’s equity capital, and (3) the number of shares purchased compared with the total number of shares placed by the legal entity. Banks are prohibited from performing transactions with securities as a form of commercial activity, with the exception of transactions with (1) bonds of international financial institutions, a list of which is established by the authorized body; and (2) bonds of foreign issuers that have a minimum required rating from one of the rating agencies. In accordance with the Law on Banks and Banking Activity, banks have the right to perform the following types of professional activities in the securities market: (1) brokerage activity with government securities of Kazakhstan and countries with a minimum required rating from one of the rating agencies or, without such a rating, based on a decision by the authorized body, and derivative securities, a list of which and the procedure for acquisition of the underlying assets of which are determined by the authorized body; (2) dealer activities with government securities of Kazakhstan and countries with a minimum required rating from one of the rating agencies or, without such a rating, based on a decision by the authorized body; derivative securities, a list of which and the procedure for acquisition of the underlying assets of which are determined by the authorized body; and other securities established by Article 8 of the Law on Banks and Banking Activity in the Republic of Kazakhstan; (3) custodial activities; and (4) transfer-agent activities. The authorized body issues a license for banks to perform one or several compatible types of professional activities in the securities market as listed above. Authorized banks may extend credit in foreign currency to resident and nonresident legal entities only in noncash form. The securities that banks may purchase are specified in banking legislation. Foreign exchange deposits are included in the group of liabilities for which banks must meet minimum reserve requirements. The ratio of the average amount of a bank’s monthly highly liquid assets in a foreign currency to the average monthly amount of its demand liabilities in that same foreign currency should be not less than 0.9 (the limit of current foreign exchange liquidity). Foreign exchange deposits of nonresidents are included in the group of liabilities for which banks must meet minimum reserve requirements. Investment abroad by resident banks is restricted by limits on the placement of own and borrowed funds in domestic assets. 717 Lending locally in foreign exchange Purchase of locally issued securities denominated in foreign exchange Differential treatment of deposit accounts in foreign exchange Reserve requirements Liquid asset requirements Differential treatment of deposit accounts held by nonresidents Reserve requirements Investment regulations Abroad by banks ©International Monetary Fund. The opening of branches of nonresident banks is prohibited. A nonresident legal entity may obtain consent from the authorized body to acquire the status of a bank holding company or a major shareholder in a bank if it has a minimum required rating from one of the rating agencies. The minimum rating and a list of rating agencies are established by a regulatory legal act of the authorized body. A nonresident bank that has a certain rating from one of the major rating agencies may be a parent bank of a subsidiary bank. A list of the major rating agencies and the minimum required rating are established by the authorized body. Legal entities that are registered in offshore zones or that have affiliates registered in offshore zones, or individuals who are participants in (founders or shareholders of) legal entities registered in offshore zones, a list of which is established by the authorized body, may not directly or indirectly hold, and/or use, and/or determine the disposition of voting shares in resident banks. This restriction does not apply to banks with an individual credit rating no lower than A from one of the rating agencies, a list of which is established by the authorized body. A nonresident that is a founder of a bank must have written notification from the authorized body (for banks that are not located in Kazakhstan, the banking supervision body) of the relevant country indicating that the person is permitted to hold shares in a bank located in Kazakhstan, or a statement from the authorized body (for banks that are not located in Kazakhstan, the banking supervision body) of the relevant country indicating that such permission is not required under the legislation of the country of the founder in question. The following limits apply: (1) The long and short open foreign exchange position limits for euros and other currencies of countries with a sovereign rating no lower than A from Standard & Poor’s (or a similar rating from one of the other rating agencies) should not exceed 12.5% of a bank’s equity capital. (2) The long and short open foreign exchange position limit for currencies of countries with a sovereign rating below A from Standard & Poor’s (or a similar rating from one of the other rating agencies) should not exceed 5% of a bank’s equity capital. (3) The net foreign exchange position limit should not exceed 25% of a bank’s equity capital. Nonresident insurance companies and nonresident insurance brokers may not establish branches in Kazakhstan. Legal entities that are registered in offshore zones, or individuals who are participants (founders, stockholders) of legal entities registered in offshore zones, of which a list is established by the authorized body, may not directly or indirectly be founders or stockholders of insurance (reinsurance) companies in Kazakhstan. This restriction does not apply to insurance (reinsurance) companies registered in offshore zones with an international credit rating not lower than A from one of the rating agencies, of which a list is established by an authorized body. A list of offshore zones with respect to supervision of insurance activities is established by the authorized body. The total amount of an insurance company’s investment in securities of foreign countries, nongovernment securities of nonresidents, and securities of international financial institutions must not exceed 30% of the insurance company’s total assets. The authorized body establishes for such securities a list of international financial institutions and rating requirements based on the international credit rating scale, following Standard & Poor’s, Fitch, and Moody’s Investors Service classifications. 718 ©International Monetary Fund. On July 6, 2007, the authorities notified the IMF that in accordance with UN Security Council resolutions, the Republic of Korea maintains certain exchange restrictions against the following: specific individuals and entities associated with the Taliban, the Al-Qaida network, the former regime of Saddam Hussein; specific individuals and entities posing a threat to international peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and Sudan; specific individuals named by the UN Security Council Committee or named by U.S. Executive Order 13224; and specific individuals and entities involved in the nuclear and/or ballistic missile programs of the Islamic Republic of Iran. Chapter 2008-2 of statement by the Ministry of Strategy and Finance (MOSF). Exchange Arrangement The currency of the Republic of Korea is the Korean won. Unitary. The exchange rate of the won is determined on the basis of supply and demand in the foreign exchange market. However, the authorities intervene when necessary to counter disorderly conditions in the market. No. No. The foreign exchange market in Korea is divided into over-the-counter (OTC) markets and exchanges. The OTC markets consist of a customer market, where foreign exchange banks deal with customers, including importers, exporters, travelers, and nonresidents, and an interbank market, where foreign exchange banks deal among themselves. In the exchanges, standardized products are traded. Residents may buy and sell financial futures on internationally recognized financial futures exchanges or on the domestic exchange, the Korea Exchange (KRX). Spot exchange market Operated by the central bank Allocation n.a. 733 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Auction Fixing Interbank market Forward exchange market References to legal instruments and hyperlinks REPUBLIC OF KOREA n.a. n.a. Foreign exchange banks participate in the interbank market mainly to dispose of open positions arising from transactions with non-financial-sector customers such as companies and nonresidents. Most interbank transactions are handled through brokers. Foreign exchange brokers intermediate between foreign exchange banks without holding any positions. In order to operate a foreign exchange brokerage business, it is necessary to obtain authorization from the MOSF. Financial institutions participating in the interbank foreign exchange market have formed an autonomous committee, the Seoul Foreign Exchange Market Committee. Foreign exchange brokers, the Bank of Korea (BOK), and the government also participate on the committee. The BOK may intervene on the market with the funds of the BOK and the Foreign Exchange Equalization Fund when it is deemed necessary for the stability of the market. Foreign exchange banks may conduct forward transactions, futures transactions, swaps, and options between foreign currencies, as well as between the won and foreign currencies. www.bok.or.kr/index.jsp. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Kuwait is the Kuwaiti dinar. Unitary. The exchange rate of the dinar was previously pegged to the dollar within margins of ±3.5% around a parity rate previously set at KD 0.29963 per $1. On May 11, 2006, the dinar was revalued to KD 0.28914 per $1 (from KD 0.29205 per $1), and thus reached the upper limit of its de jure band. On May 20, 2007, the dinar was revalued again vis-à-vis the dollar, and pegged to an undisclosed basket of currencies reflecting Kuwait’s foreign trade and financial relationships, similar to the policy before January 5, 2003. By end-2007, the cumulative revaluation amounted to 5.9% vis-à-vis the dollar. As a result, effective August 1, 2007, the de facto exchange rate arrangement has been changed to a conventional pegged arrangement to a composite from a conventional pegged arrangement to a single currency. Imports of industrial equipment and machinery and their spare parts require industrial licenses, which are valid for one-time use. Licenses are issued to registered and licensed industrial establishments with the approval of the Industrial Development Commission at the MCI. Private imports of personal objects may be permitted under individual or specific licenses. Registered importers handling a variety of commodities may obtain a general license valid for one year. Other importers must obtain specific licenses for individual commodities, which are also valid for one year. Government procurement policies grant preferences to Kuwaiti-produced goods up to a price margin of 5% over goods produced in other GCC countries, and 10% over goods produced in non-GCC countries. In accordance with the GCC Customs Union, a minimum tariff of 5% applies to non-GCC imports; there are no tariffs on imports from other GCC members with at least 40% local value added. Imports of foodstuffs and some machinery and equipment, spare parts, and raw materials are exempt from import duties. Kuwait applies higher tariffs in industries with domestic producers that supply at least 40% of the local market. Tariff rates differ depending on the domestic-value-added content of the products in question. If domestically produced goods contain at least 20%, 30%, or 40% of domestic value added, protective duties of 15%, 20%, and 25%, respectively, may be applied to competing imports. The degree of protection given by the formula is reduced by 5% in the case of consumer goods. The maximum duty imposed on products that compete with locally manufactured goods is 100%. Duties on goods imported from member countries of the GAFTA are being gradually reduced. No. n.a. Exchange Arrangement The currency of the Kyrgyz Republic is the Kyrgyz som. Unitary. The National Bank of the Kyrgyz Republic (NBKR) participates and intervenes in the interbank foreign exchange market to limit exchange rate volatility as necessary. Despite strong appreciation pressures, the som remained very stable vis- à-vis the dollar from March 2007 to September 2007. As a result, effective March 1, 2007, the exchange rate arrangement has been reclassified to a conventional pegged arrangement from managed floating with no predetermined path for the exchange rate. During September–November, the som appreciated by about 10% against the dollar. Thus, effective October 1, 2007, the exchange rate arrangement has been reclassified to managed floating with no predetermined path for the exchange rate. The official exchange rate of the som against the dollar is defined as the weighted average of the exchange rates of the interbank foreign exchange market transactions for the week. Nonresidents may purchase shares in accordance with regulations. Issuers are required to inform the FMSRS of any acquisition exceeding 5% of its capital or 5% of its stock, as well as of all increases of a multiple of 5% (e.g., 10%, 15%, etc.). Acquisition of more than 10% of the shares of banks is subject to approval by the NBKR. Legal entities not engaging in financial activity may not own more than 20% of a bank’s voting shares. Resident Accounts Balances in foreign exchange accounts may be used for foreign and domestic transactions, subject to general or specific approval. Withdrawals in cash are limited to $10,000 or its equivalent an account a day. Withdrawals exceeding this limit may be approved by authorized banks but must be reported to the BOL. Resident accounts may be credited with (1) foreign exchange transferred from overseas; (2) foreign exchange transferred from other foreign exchange accounts with BOL approval; (3) foreign exchange purchased legally from the domestic market; (4) foreign currency brought into Lao P.D.R. supported by a customs certificate; and (5) foreign exchange derived from salaries, bonuses, travel allowances, family financial assistance, and inheritances supported by proof of source. These accounts may be debited for (1) permitted external payments; (2) domestic payments, where permitted; (3) conversion into domestic currency; (4) purchases of other payment instruments, for example, traveler’s checks and bank drafts; and (5) withdrawals in cash for approved purposes. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Latvia is the Latvian lats. Unitary. The lats is pegged to the euro at the rate of LVL 0.702804 per €1 in the context of the ERM II. The Bank of Latvia (BOL) fixes the rates of the lats daily against 33 convertible currencies and the price of gold. These rates are used for accounting purposes and are valid through the next day. The BOL quotes fixed buying and selling rates in euros only. The spread between the buying and selling rates is 2%. No. No. 769 ©International Monetary Fund. Provisions Specific to the Financial Sector Provisions specific to commercial banks and other credit institutions Open foreign exchange position limits Provisions specific to institutional investors Insurance companies Currency-matching regulations on assets/liabilities composition Pension funds Currency-matching regulations on assets/liabilities composition Investment firms and collective investment funds Limits (max.) on investment portfolio held abroad References to legal instruments and hyperlinks Prudential regulations that are harmonized with EU directives apply. The open foreign currency position is limited to 10% of capital for any single foreign currency and 20% of the institution’s own funds for all foreign currencies. Between January 1, 2005, and April 1, 2007, the open position in euros was not regulated. Currency matching rules are in place. As a general rule for insurance companies, the technical provisions and the assets covering the technical provisions should be matched on a currency-by-currency basis. Insurance companies are exempt from covering technical provisions with matching assets if doing so would mean holding assets in a currency amounting to no more than 7% of the assets held in other currencies. Insurance companies are exempt from holding matching assets covering an amount not exceeding 20% of their commitments in a particular currency. The matching principle is considered to be observed if liabilities in lats are covered with assets in lats or euros. For defined-benefit private pension funds the maximum permitted currency mismatch between the pension fund’s technical provisions and assets covering these provisions is 30%. The open foreign currency position of a defined- contribution private pension fund may not exceed (1) 10% of the assets of that pension fund in a single foreign currency (excluding the euro) and (2) 20% of the assets of that pension fund in all foreign currencies (excluding the euro). Assets of the state-funded pension fund may be invested in the currency in which payments are made as a general rule; however, (1) the investments may be made in currencies other than the currency of obligation if the total amount of such investments does not exceed 30% of the assets of the state-funded pension fund, and (2) investment assets of the state-funded pension fund in a currency other than the currency of obligation may not exceed 10% of the scheme. Investments in euros are not considered investments in unmatched currencies. An investment fund may invest only in demand and time deposits, with original maturity not exceeding one year in banks licensed in the EU, the EEA, or an OECD member country. A closed-end fund may invest in real estate located and registered only in the EU, the EEA, or an OECD member country. No. In general, import licenses are issued mainly for health, security, and fraud- prevention and apply to about 3% (in value terms) of all goods imported into Lebanon. Licenses generally apply to imports of certain animal and plant products, medically hazardous substances, arms, ammunition, explosive materials, and certain telecommunications equipment and petroleum products, as well as to certain industrial products. Import prohibitions apply to a list of products for the protection of health, the environment, safety, and security. All imports from Israel are prohibited. In addition, certain commercial entities listed under the Arab Boycott List are barred from trading with Lebanon. Effective January 1, 2007, Lebanon introduced the Harmonized Tariff System, 2007 version. Previously, Lebanon used the 2002 version. Customs valuation is based on c.i.f. value; customs duties are generally ad valorem. The WTO valuation principle is also applied. The ad valorem rates vary between zero and 70%. There are preferential duty rates for goods imported for industrial, agricultural, or public use. In addition to ad valorem duties, which apply to about 93% of products, the following rates apply: (1) The bracket-based calculation applies to cars. The value of a car is divided into two brackets and the total duty is the sum of the duties applied at each bracket’s rate. (2) Duties may be calculated on the basis of units of measure, such as weight or volume (e.g., for gasoline). (3) A combined duty may be calculated on an ad valorem and specific basis, and the higher amount collected (e.g., for tropical fruits and chickens). In addition, excise duties are collected on alcoholic and nonalcoholic beverages, cars, cement, and fuels. Lebanon applies the 779 ©International Monetary Fund. Currency Exchange rate structure Classification Independently floating Exchange tax Exchange Arrangement The currency of Luxembourg is the euro. Unitary. Luxembourg participates in a currency union with 14 other members of the EMU and has no separate legal tender. The euro, the common currency, floats freely and independently against other currencies. Effective January 1, 2007, the exchange rate arrangement of the EMU countries has been reclassified to the category independently floating from the category exchange arrangement with no separate legal tender. The new classification is based on the behavior of the common currency, whereas the previous classification was based on the lack of a separate legal tender. The new classification thus reflects only a definitional change and is not based on a judgment that there has been a substantive change in the exchange regime or other policies of the currency union or its members. Restrictions and/or multiple currency practices Exchange measures imposed for security reasons References to legal instruments and hyperlinks Currency Exchange rate structure Classification Conventional pegged arrangement Exchange tax Exchange subsidy Foreign exchange market Spot exchange market Exchange Measures The IMF staff report for the second review under the Stand-By Arrangement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia states that, as of April 11, 2007, FYR Macedonia maintained an exchange restriction subject to IMF approval under Article VIII, Section 2(a), arising from restrictions imposed on the transferability of proceeds from current international transactions contained in former frozen foreign currency saving deposits. (Country Report No. 07/257) No. n.a. Exchange Arrangement The currency of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is the Macedonian denar. Unitary. The de jure exchange rate arrangement is managed floating. In accordance with the Foreign Exchange Law, the denar exchange rate is determined freely on the basis of demand and supply of foreign exchange in the foreign exchange market. The National Bank of the Republic of Macedonia (NBRM) participates in the foreign exchange market to achieve the goals of the monetary and foreign exchange policy. Reflecting the stability of the exchange rate as a result of official interventions, the de facto exchange rate regime is a conventional pegged arrangement. The denar exchange rate against the euro is determined by the NBRM as the weighted average of interbank transactions at the end of each business day. The official exchange rate is used for accounting purposes and balance of payments statistics. No. No. The exchange market operates at two levels: wholesale (companies, commercial banks, and the NBRM) and retail (foreign exchange bureaus and natural persons). The wholesale market is also divided into two segments: (1) transactions between companies and banks and (2) interbank market transactions. The NBRM participates in the foreign exchange market to maintain the value of the denar against the euro. Since August 2005, the NBRM has intervened in the foreign exchange market through market makers, on its own initiative, or on the initiative of the market makers. The price is determined on a market basis. The 818 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA frequency of the intervention depends on the conditions in the foreign exchange market. n.a. n.a. n.a. An electronic trading platform is used for quotation and interbank trading. The NBRM introduced market makers to decrease its presence in the foreign exchange market and to enable banks to satisfy the foreign exchange liquidity needs among themselves when demand and supply are in broad equilibrium. The market makers have the exclusive right to trade with the NBRM; they also have the obligation to continuously quote bid and ask rates with a predefined spread of Mden 0.07 with each other and Mden 0.25 with other banks. Foreign exchange bureaus owned and operated by savings institutions, trade companies, sole proprietors, and other legal entities may hold foreign exchange in cash up to the specified maximum level and must keep the balances above this level in a special account with the commercial banks of their preference. Foreign exchange offices owned by banks are excluded from the previous provision. Forward foreign exchange operations are allowed for all residents. n.a. The following limits apply on investments of the assets covering technical provisions: investments in (1) bonds or other securities issued or guaranteed by the NBRM and bonds and other securities issued or guaranteed by the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia may not exceed 80% of the assets covering the technical provisions; (2) certificates of deposit, other securities, and mortgage securities issued by banks licensed by the NBRM may not exceed 60% of the assets covering the technical provisions; (3) bonds and other securities issued by joint-stock companies on the basis of an approval granted by the SEC listed on the primary and secondary market of the Macedonian Stock Exchange or some other recognized exchange supervised by the SEC and commercial notes issued by blue chip joint-stock companies in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia may not exceed 40% of the assets covering the technical provisions; (4) stocks issued on the basis of approval granted by the SEC listed on the primary and secondary market of the Macedonian Stock Exchange or some other recognized exchange supervised by the SEC may not exceed 30% of the assets covering the technical reserves; (5) documents confirming a holding in stocks and units of investment funds in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia operating in compliance with the Law on Investment Funds may not exceed 20% of the assets covering the technical reserves of an insurance company. Insurance undertakings are required to hold and invest funds on accounts in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. In addition, the following limitations on the investment of capital apply: (1) 60% of capital may be invested in real estate, the equity capital of other insurance undertakings, and financial institutions and other legal entities, whereby individual investments of insurance undertakings in real estate may not exceed 10% of the capital; (2) 15% of the capital may be used for advance payments and loans on approval by the insurance company under the general terms and conditions of insurance based on presentation of own policies for which premiums are paid on time, whereby individual investments of the insurance undertaking in such loans may not exceed 1% of the value of capital. The assets covering the technical provisions must be diversified to avoid excessive reliance on any particular category of assets, market, or investment. The insurance undertaking shall adjust the investments of assets covering the technical provisions that are exposed to a risk of potential loss resulting from a change in interest rates, exchange rate fluctuations, credit risk, and other market risks to the liabilities under insurance contracts on which those changes may have an impact.
