Status under IMF Articles of Agreement Restrictions and/or multiple currency practices Exchange measures imposed for security reasons References to legal instruments and hyperlinks Currency Exchange rate structure Dual Classification Conventional pegged arrangement Exchange tax Exchange subsidy Foreign exchange market Spot exchange market Operated by the central bank Allocation Auction Fixing Exchange Measures The IMF staff report for the 2006 Article IV consultation states that, as of February 1, 2007, Malawi maintained a multiple currency practice (MCP) under Article VIII. As the authorities have ceased the informal rationing of foreign exchange and there is no longer a backlog of arrears on import payments, the exchange restriction evidenced by these arrears has been eliminated. IMF staff is assessing whether the official action that gave rise to the MCP has ceased. (Country Report No. 07/147) No. n.a. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Malawi is the Malawi kwacha. There is a dual exchange rate structure as a result of an MCP in connection with the significant spread between the commercial bank exchange rate and the rates at foreign exchange bureaus. The de jure exchange rate arrangement is managed floating with no predetermined path for the exchange rate. Official intervention focuses on meeting the target on the net foreign reserves position and reducing exchange rate volatility and takes into account seasonal fluctuations. The exchange rate arrangement has experienced little volatility against the backdrop of direct and indirect interventions of the CB. Thus, the classification of the de facto exchange rate arrangement has been changed from managed floating with no predetermined path for the exchange rate to a conventional pegged arrangement, effective January 1, 2006. No. No. The spread between the buying and selling rates may not exceed 2% on the foreign exchange market. When imports arrive in the country and payment is due, the importer must submit to an AD bank an application for foreign exchange. Imports of clothing and uniforms designed for military or police use; radioactive substances; mist nets for the capture of wild birds, wild animals, and live fish; compound products suitable only for use as animal fodder; eggs of domestic or wild birds; live poultry (including day-old chicks); meat; dieldrin and aldrin; and table salt require specific licenses from the MOTPSD. Most imports are subject to OGLs, including imports from Commonwealth and WTO member countries. Customs tariffs are ad valorem and range up to 30% of c.i.f. value, with a weighted average of about 15%. Customs tariffs on all items with MFN status range from zero to 25%. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Malaysia is the Malaysian ringgit. Unitary. The Bank Negara Malaysia (BNM) operates a de jure managed float for the ringgit with reference to a currency basket. The composition of the basket is not disclosed. n.a. n.a. n.a. n.a. n.a. n.a. All forward exchange contracts undertaken by residents and forward exchange contracts by nonresidents involving ringgit must be made only with licensed onshore banks. Residents are free to enter into forward exchange contracts against ringgit or a foreign currency with licensed onshore banks for the following purposes: (1) Hedging for payments or receipts for current account transactions. Contracts may be based on a firm commitment or on an anticipatory basis. For forward contracts on an anticipatory basis, the total outstanding value of the contracts should not exceed the total amount paid or received in the preceding 12 844 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALAYSIA months. (2) Hedging for any committed capital inflows or outflows, including payment for permitted investment in foreign currency assets, the drawdown of permitted foreign currency credit facilities, and, effective April 1, 2007, repayment of permitted foreign currency credit facilities. Previously, hedging of foreign currency loan repayments was allowed only for commitments of up to 24 months. (3) Hedging the value of permitted foreign currency investments. Nonresidents may enter into forward contracts to buy or sell foreign currency against ringgit with licensed onshore banks to hedge (1) committed payments or receipts for current account transactions, which may be settled in ringgit with residents, and (2) committed inflows and outflows for investment in, or divestment of, ringgit assets other than (a) funds in the external account, including fixed deposits; (b) negotiable instruments of deposits in ringgit; and (c) over-the-counter derivatives or structured products, which are tantamount to lending or borrowing of ringgit between residents and nonresidents. Effective April 1, 2007, nonresidents are no longer required to reinvest within seven working days the proceeds from the sale of ringgit assets prior to the maturity of the forward foreign exchange contract. Effective April 1, 2007, licensed onshore banks may appoint overseas branches of their banking group as a vehicle to facilitate the settlement of ringgit assets of their nonresident clients. Ringgit transactions undertaken by overseas branches are subject to the following conditions: (1) The overseas bank must conduct only straight pass-through transactions matched with a back-to-back arrangement on both amount and term with the licensed onshore banks. There must not be gapping of the ringgit positions in the books of the overseas branches. (2) The arrangement is available only to nonresident investors with a firm underlying commitment to invest in ringgit assets. (3) Licensed onshore banks undertake full responsibility to ensure compliance with the conditions by establishing internal control and procedures as well as maintaining documentation of the overseas branches’ transactions for audit purposes. Nonresident intermediaries may enter into swap arrangements not exceeding three business days with licensed onshore banks to cover payment for ringgit securities purchased by nonresident intermediaries’ nonresident clients, subject to the following conditions: (1) A swap arrangement must be based on a firm commitment and not made on an anticipatory basis. (2) The maturity date of the arrangement must be the committed payment date, with no rollover option. Multilateral development banks (MDBs) and foreign multinational companies (MNCs) that are allowed to issue ringgit-denominated bonds may enter into forward contracts to sell foreign currency for ringgit to meet coupon or principal payment of the bonds. In addition, they may purchase forward foreign currency for repatriation of proceeds of the issuance abroad. A resident with a firm underlying commitment may enter into interest rate swaps with licensed onshore banks or licensed offshore banks in Labuan. All payments or receipts involving licensed offshore banks in Labuan must be made in foreign currency. The maturity date of the forward foreign exchange contract must be the expected date of receipt or payment of the underlying transactions. For forward sale of export proceeds, the maturity date of the forward contract should not be later than six months after the intended date of export. n.a. 845 References to legal instruments and hyperlinks ©International Monetary Fund. Resident Accounts Yes. Residents are allowed to open foreign currency accounts (FCAs) with licensed onshore banks for any purpose with no overnight limit. Effective April 1, 2007, residents are allowed to open and maintain joint FCAs for any purpose. Previously, residents were allowed to maintain joint FCAs only for education and employment overseas. Effective April 1, 2007, approval of the COFE is required for residents with domestic ringgit credit facilities to convert amounts exceeding RM 1 million a year into foreign currency for credit to an FCA for individuals and RM 50 million a year for a corporate group (previously, RM 100,000 and RM 5 million, respectively). Residents may open FCAs with licensed offshore banks in Labuan or overseas banks for any purpose except retention of export proceeds. FCAs are not subject to any limit. Effective January 1, 2008, the requirement that resident companies maintaining FCAs with licensed offshore banks in Labuan or overseas banks submit a monthly statement, Statement OA, on the accounts to the COFE was abolished. COFE approval is required for a resident (1) to retain export proceeds abroad or (2) with domestic currency credit facilities to convert ringgit into foreign currency for deposit into an FCA exceeding the permitted limits. These accounts are not allowed. Effective April 1, 2007, approval of the COFE is required for residents with domestic ringgit credit facilities to convert ringgit into foreign currency for credit to an FCA in excess of RM 1 million a year for individuals and RM 50 million a year for a corporate group. (Previously, the limits were RM 100,000 and RM 10 million, respectively.) The conversion of ringgit into foreign currency exceeding (1) $150,000 each for credit to FCAs maintained with licensed onshore banks or Labuan offshore banks, and (2) $50,000 for credit to FCAs maintained with overseas banks for the purpose of education or employment abroad is subject to COFE approval. n.a. Nonresident Accounts Foreign exchange accounts permitted Domestic currency accounts All licensed onshore banks are allowed to maintain these accounts for nonresidents. All licensed onshore banks are allowed to open ringgit accounts for nonresidents. Nonresident ringgit accounts in Malaysia are known as external accounts. Sources 847 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALAYSIA of funds in these accounts may include (1) sales of foreign currency; (2) sales of ringgit assets in Malaysia; (3) income from salaries, wages, rentals, commissions, interest, profits, and dividends; (4) proceeds from permitted ringgit loans extended by residents and/or extended in accordance with the terms and conditions of employment; (5) proceeds from repayment of permitted ringgit loans; (6) deposits of ringgit in cash of up to RM 10,000 a day; (7) transfers of up to RM 5,000 a transaction from an account for any purpose through automated teller machine cards, Internet banking, and ringgit checks; and (8) transfers of any amount from another external account held by the same entity. Funds in external accounts may be used for (1) payments for purchases of foreign currency and ringgit assets in Malaysia; (2) payments for administrative and statutory expenses incurred in Malaysia; (3) payments for goods and services for personal use in Malaysia; (4) granting of loans and advances to staff in Malaysia in accordance with the terms and conditions of employment; (5) payments of nonfinancial guarantees to residents (when a guarantee is required); (6) repayments of permitted ringgit loans; and (7) ringgit cash withdrawals. COFE approval is required for transfers of funds between external accounts of different account holders and for use of funds other than for permitted purposes. There are no restrictions on the operation of external accounts of nonresidents working in Malaysia (including their spouses, children, and parents residing in Malaysia), embassies, consulates, high commissions, central banks, international organizations in Malaysia, and participants in the Malaysia My Second Home Programme. Nonresidents are free to convert ringgit funds in external accounts into foreign currency for repatriation. Approval of the COFE is required for residents of Israel to open accounts with financial institutions in Malaysia. n.a. Imports and Import Payments Payments for imports may be made freely in foreign currency. Residents may obtain trade credits extended by the supplier for all types of goods and services. However, credits extended by a nonresident supplier for capital goods for a period longer than 12 months are considered foreign currency credit facilities. Foreign currency trade financing facilities obtained from nonresidents other than the supplier are limited to a maximum of RM 5 million in aggregate for each corporate group. There are no minimum financing requirements. There are no advance payment requirements. n.r. n.r. Preshipment inspections are made by independent surveyors for rice imports. n.r. 848 Convertible into foreign currency Blocked accounts References to legal instruments and hyperlinks Foreign exchange budget Financing requirements for imports Minimum financing requirements Advance payment requirements Advance import deposits Documentation requirements for release of foreign exchange for imports Domiciliation requirement Preshipment inspection Letters of credit ©International Monetary Fund. Other Import licenses and other nontariff measures Negative list Open general licenses Licenses with quotas Import taxes and/or tariffs Taxes collected through the exchange system State import monopoly References to legal instruments and hyperlinks Repatriation requirements Surrender requirements Financing requirements Other documents required are an invoice, a bill of lading, a sanitary or phytosanitary certificate, and a certificate of origin. Import control authority rests with the Royal Malaysian Customs Department of the MOF. Import licensing in Malaysia is administered by various authorities, including the Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI), the Ministry of Plantation Industries and Commodities, the Malaysian Timber Board, the Ministry of Agriculture and Agro-Based Industry and its agencies, including the Department of Agriculture (DOA), the Department of Veterinary Services of Malaysia (DVSM), the Federal Agriculture Marketing Authority (FAMA), the Department of Fisheries (DOF), the Malaysian Pineapple Industry Board, and the Fisheries Development Authority of Malaysia (LKIM). A negative list is established by Malaysian Customs (Prohibition of Imports) Order 2008, Gazette Number P.U. (A) 86/2008, dated March 31, 2008. Import licenses are obtained from the MITI, the Ministry of Plantation Industries and Commodities and its agencies, and the Ministry of Agriculture and Agro-Based Industry and its agencies. Certain licenses are subject to the Tariff Rate Quota, as per Appendix B of Malaysian Customs Duties Order 2007, Gazette Number P.U. (A) 441/2007, dated December 31, 2007. Import duties, sales taxes, and, on selected goods, excise taxes are levied on imported goods. Antidumping duties are imposed on imports of newsprint paper from Canada, Indonesia, the United States, the Philippines, and the Republic of Korea; maleic anhydride from Taipei, Indonesia, and the Republic of Korea; and polyethylene terephthalate from Taipei, Indonesia, the Republic of Korea, and Thailand. n.a. Under a privatization agreement, the BERNAS was granted the sole right to import rice into Malaysia for 15 years beginning in 1996. Exports and Export Proceeds Proceeds from exports must be received and repatriated according to the payment schedule specified in the commercial contract, but no later than six months from the date of export. Export proceeds must be received in foreign currency, except the currency of Israel. Exporters may retain any amount of export proceeds in FCAs with onshore licensed banks. Resident exporters are free to obtain any amount of foreign currency trade financing facilities from licensed onshore banks. Foreign currency trade financing facilities involving export proceeds may be obtained only from licensed onshore banks. 849 ©International Monetary Fund. Exports of live fish are subject to preshipment inspection. If requested, a certificate of health, sanitation, or origin may be issued by the DOF. Veterinary examination, laboratory testing, and animal quarantine procedures—as well as accreditation of establishments and premises for exports of animals and animal products—are carried out by the DVSM in accordance with import requirements of importing countries. Plant and plant products, including rice, may be subject to preshipment inspection, depending on the requirement of importing countries. Raw commodities may also be subject to preshipment inspection, depending on the requirement of importing countries. Exports of rubber from peninsular Malaysia require a certificate issued by the Malaysian Rubber Exchange and Licensing Board. Goods that require export licenses are listed in Customs (Prohibition of Exports) Order 2008, Gazette Number P.U. (A) 87/2008, dated March 31, 2008. Certain exportable products are monitored to prevent shortages in the domestic market. Export licenses for fish and fishery products are issued by the LKIM. The shipment of live fish (including among peninsular Malaysia, Sabah, and Sarawak) also requires a permit issued by the DOF. In accordance with CITES, a permit from the Department of Wildlife is required for exports of endangered species. The FAMA acts on behalf of the Royal Malaysian Customs Department to endorse exports or reexports of all types of vegetables, especially to Singapore, Brunei Darussalam, Indonesia, Thailand, and other countries. Exports of plants, seeds, or shoots for purposes of propagation require export permits issued by the DOA. Exports of endangered species of plants require a CITES permit from the DOA. Export permits and veterinary health certification from the DVSM are required for exports of animals and animal products. Export licenses (issued by the Malaysian Pineapple Industry Board) are required for fresh pineapple and canned pineapple products. A service charge of RM 0.184 a kilogram is imposed on exports of canned pineapple. Export licenses or permits from the MITI are required for exports of scrap and waste metals, certain iron and steel products, palm oil, milk, sugars, cement, clinker, roofing tiles, brick, and all products to Israel, and toxic chemicals and their precursors under the Chemical Weapons Convention. All applications for live fish import and export permits must be made through an Internet-based system, e-permit. Importers and exporters may get online approval through this system, provided the conditions set out in the requirements are met. Yes. Export taxes are levied on a selected number of commodities. n.a. n.a. Customs (Prohibition of Exports) Order 2008, Gazette Number P.U. Financial guarantees must be registered with the COFE only if (1) the aggregate amount of financial guarantees issued or obtained by the nonbank resident exceeds RM 50 million; and (2) the guarantee is to secure a credit facility that has not been approved by the COFE and that credit facility is extended by (a) a resident (bank or nonbank) to another resident (bank or nonbank); (b) a resident (bank or nonbank) to a nonresident; (c) a nonresident to a resident (bank or nonbank); or (d) a nonresident to another nonresident. Licensed onshore banks are free to issue financial guarantees on behalf or in favor of nonresidents. Licensed onshore banks or nonbank residents are free to obtain financial guarantees from nonresidents. The regulations governing capital and money market instruments apply. Controls are imposed on equity shares in accordance with the national economic policy; however, no foreign exchange restrictions apply. The following inward investments require approval under the FIC guidelines: (1) Acquisition of property (such as land or land with commercial or residential buildings) by local or foreign interests, depending on the value of the properties. Effective January 1, 2007, the guidelines were relaxed on the acquisition of residential property with a value of not less than RM 250,000. (2) Acquisition of assets or interest, mergers, or takeovers of companies and businesses in Malaysia by any means that will cause ownership or control to be transferred from local to foreign interests, even if the value is less than RM 10 million. (3) Acquisition of (or acquisition that will result in an increase of) 15% or more of the voting power (equity interest) by any foreign interest or associated or nonassociated group of foreign interest in the aggregate of 30% or more of the voting power of a Malaysian company or business, regardless of whether the value is less than RM 10 million, with the exception of open market acquisitions on the Bursa Malaysia intended for short-term holding. (4) Control of Malaysian companies and businesses through any form of joint-venture agreement, management agreement, or technical assistance arrangement. (5) Mergers or takeovers of any company or business in Malaysia. Applications requiring approval of the SC under the securities and futures laws as well as approval under the FIC guidelines are centralized at the SC. Notwithstanding the above, certain exemptions or relaxation of the foreign equity limits are granted to companies with Multimedia Super Corridor status; companies with major foreign-based operations seeking listing on the Bursa Malaysia; and intermediaries licensed under the relevant acts and regulations administered by the SC, including investment banks, local and 855 ©International Monetary Fund. Investment both locally and abroad is subject to certain prudential limits: (1) Investment in shares and interest-in-shares may not exceed 25% of a bank’s capital base. (2) Banks may not make direct real estate investments except for the purpose of conducting their business or for housing or other amenities for their staff, unless approved by the BNM. Banks are exempt from this restriction when they acquire real estate through realizing a collateral. This restriction does not apply to Islamic banks. Effective March 30, 2007, Islamic banks may undertake property development and investment activities related to Islamic banking business activities, in accordance with the nature of Islamic finance, which allows co- ownership in property by banks and customers as a means of financing. (3) The aggregate value of long-term investment in shares, immovable properties, and units of unit trust funds and property trust funds may not exceed 50% of a bank’s capital base. (4) Investments in private debt securities of a single issuer (and related counterparties) may not exceed 35% of a bank’s capital funds as part of the large exposure regime. (5) Investment in property trust funds and unit trust funds may not exceed 10% of a bank’s capital funds. Investment in individual funds may not exceed 5% of the issue size of a fund or 5% of a bank’s capital funds, whichever is lower. A framework has been established at the WAEMU level to combat the financing of terrorism in member countries. The framework facilitates the enforcement of the decisions on the freezing of funds made by the Sanctions Committee of the UN Security Council, based on the list of persons and entities established by that committee. Effective April 6, 2007, the Council of Ministers of the Union adopted Decision No. 09/2007/CM/UEMOA amending Decision No. 14/2006/CM/ UEMOA of September 8, 2006, on the list of persons, entities, or organizations affected by the freezing of assets and other financial resources in the context of combating the financing of terrorism in the member countries of the WAEMU. Effective March 28, 2008, the WAEMU Council of Ministers adopted Decision No. 09/2008/CM/UEMOA, amending Decision No. 09/2007/CM/UEMOA of April 6, 2007, on the list of persons, entities, or organizations affected by the freezing of assets and other financial resources in the context of combating the financing of terrorism in the member countries of the WAEMU. The uniform law on combating the financing of terrorism in the member countries of the WAEMU was adopted by the WAEMU Council of Ministers. Regulation 14/2002/CM/UEMOA by the WAEMU Council of Ministers of September 19, 2002; www.uemoa.int/actes/Default.htm; www.bceao.int. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Mali is the CFA franc. Unitary. Mali participates in a currency union with seven other members of the WAEMU and has no separate legal tender. The CFA franc is pegged to the euro, the intervention currency, at the rate of CFAF 655.957 per €1. Exchange rates for other currencies are derived from the rate for the currency concerned in the Paris foreign exchange market vis-à-vis the euro. Effective January 1, 2007, the exchange rate arrangement of the WAEMU countries has been reclassified to the category conventional pegged arrangement from the category exchange arrangement with no separate legal tender. The new classification is based on the behavior of the common currency, whereas the previous classification was based on the lack of a separate legal tender. The new classification thus reflects only a definitional change and is not based on a judgment that there has been a substantive change in the exchange regime or other policies of the currency union or its members. 868 ©International Monetary Fund. Exchange control is administered jointly by the MOF and the BCEAO. Most of the authority to supervise foreign exchange transactions is delegated to authorized banks, which are required to report these operations to the MOF. The BCEAO is also authorized to collect—either directly or through banks, financial institutions, the postal administration, and judicial agents—information necessary to compile balance of payments statistics. Customs officers monitor outflows of foreign exchange and confirm importation and exportation of goods. All residents of WAEMU countries are treated as residents of Mali for the purposes of financial transactions. All foreign exchange operations with foreign countries must be effected through authorized intermediary banks, the postal administration, or the BCEAO. No supporting documents are required for transfers up to the equivalent of CFAF 300,000. There are no controls on holding gold for noncommercial purposes. Imports of gold require MOF authorization. Exempt from this requirement are (1) imports by or on behalf of the treasury or the BCEAO, (2) imports of manufactured articles containing minor quantities of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles), and (3) imports by travelers of gold objects up to a combined weight of 500 grams. Licensed and exempt imports of gold are subject to customs declaration. CFA franc banknotes may be exported freely by travelers. However, BCEAO repurchases of exported banknotes are still suspended. Exchange Arrangement Effective January 1, 2008, the currency of Malta is the euro (previously, the Maltese lira). Unitary. Effective January 1, 2008, Malta participates in a currency union (EMU) with 14 other members of the EU and has no separate legal tender. The final conversion rate for the Maltese lira was Lm 0.4293 per €1. The euro, the common currency, floats freely and independently against other currencies. Previously, Malta participated in the ERM II, and the lira was classified as a de facto conventional pegged arrangement to the euro. As a result, effective January 1, 2008, the de facto exchange rate regime of Malta has been reclassified to the category independently floating from the category conventional pegged arrangement. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Mauritania is the Mauritanian ouguiya. Unitary. The de jure exchange rate arrangement classification is managed floating with no predetermined path for the exchange rate. From October 2005 to January 2007, the ouguiya was de facto pegged to the dollar, at an exchange rate of UM 268.6 per $1. On January 25, 2007, a new foreign exchange market opened with a market- determined exchange rate based on supply and demand. The Central Bank of Mauritania (BCM) intervenes only as a last resort. After remaining essentially unchanged over the first few months of 2007, the exchange rate of the ouguiya vis- à-vis the dollar appreciated from UM 268.5 per $1 on April 25 to UM 251.0 per $1 at end-December 2007. The de facto classification of the exchange rate arrangement has been changed from a conventional pegged arrangement to managed floating with no predetermined path for the exchange rate, effective May 1, 2007. No. Yes. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Mexico is the Mexican peso. Unitary. The exchange rate of the peso is determined freely in the foreign exchange market. Bank of Mexico (BOM) transactions in the foreign exchange market are limited to rule-based, nondiscretionary foreign exchange auctions to manage its foreign reserves. Every three months the BOM announces the amount of dollars it plans to auction (on a daily basis throughout a given quarter). This amount is 50% of the net increase in foreign exchange reserves in the previous quarter (net of the dollar sales via this mechanism). No. No. The Exchange Commission agreed to establish a rule-based mechanism to reduce the rate of international reserves accumulation. The BOM sells dollars directly in the foreign exchange market every day according to the following procedure: the BOM announces every quarter the total amount of dollars it will offer to the currency market each day during the subsequent four quarters. The total dollars to be sold equals 50% of the net international reserves accumulated during the previous quarter. One-fourth of the established amount is auctioned each quarter, not including the cumulative amount of dollars sold through the auction mechanism during the same period. Based on the total amount of dollars, the BOM auctions on a daily basis a fixed amount of dollars following a preestablished schedule (the daily amount to be sold is determined according to the number of business days in the current quarter). The BOM calculates this exchange rate to pay obligations in dollars in Mexico. To calculate the rate, the BOM requests that commercial banks report their interbank 905 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Interbank market Forward exchange market References to legal instruments and hyperlinks MEXICO spot exchange. Using the banks’ reported rates, the BOM calculates the Fix rate, which is published at noon every banking business day. The Fix rate serves only as a reference; its use in foreign exchange transactions by maket participants is not mandatory. Yes. Only commercial and development banks are allowed to enter into exchange rate, stock exchange, and other derivative transactions. Authorization from the BOM is required, which is granted on the basis of certain organizational, legal, and risk- management requirements. Not for Redistribution Financing requirements for imports Documentation requirements for release of foreign exchange for imports Import licenses and other nontariff measures Negative list Open general licenses Licenses with quotas Other nontariff measures Import taxes and/or tariffs MEXICO No. No. Import licenses issued by the Ministry of Economy (MOE) are required for 145 of the 12,116 items on which Mexico’s general import tariff is levied, including the 25 tariff lines related to “special operations,” under which manufacturing industries may import (with zero duties but under a license) finished goods that allow them to complement their offer and fulfill the manufacturing program “Programa of Fabricación” in which they have registered; temporary imports of raw materials and intermediate inputs for exporting industries do not need a license. New licenses are issued, provided the criteria set by the MOE are satisfied. On average, import licenses are valid for a period of one year, but for some sensitive products, they are valid only for three or six months. For some products, open-ended import licenses may be granted, allowing imports to be effected during a period of six months to one year, subject to an overall limit. Depending on the importer’s performance, the license may be renewed repeatedly. No import license is required for funeral carriages and coaches, go-karts, and collectors’ vehicles (at least 30 years old); imports of other used cars are subject to MOE approval, but only special- purpose vehicles that are different from those made locally are allowed. Imports of gold and silver are allowed under OGLs. Yes. Imports of used agricultural machinery, raw materials, and intermediate products require agricultural certificates, inspection, and lab analysis. Goods covered by CITES are prohibited. Other nontariff regulations, including those related to national security concerns (weapons and ammunition); Health Department standards; ecological and environmental regulations; and restrictions on drugs, narcotic substances, nuclear energy, and toxic and hazardous materials, apply to about 1,700 of the 12,116 items of Mexico’s general import tariff. About 3,724 tariff items are subject to qualitative examination by customs to verify that goods fulfill certain Mexican consumer standards. Among Customs Act import duties, 94% range from zero to 20%, with higher rates for a few products, including fructose (210% tariff) and clothing, footwear, and leather goods (35% tariff), whereas 2,344 tariff items are totally duty-free regardless of country of origin. A 50% tariff applies to imports of new cars from countries with which no commercial agreement exists. A 7%–10% duty rate applies to 14 tariff items designated to describe special-purpose vehicles in the automobile sector. Imports from members of the LAIA, the EFTA, Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, El Salvador, the EU, Guatemala, Honduras, Israel, Japan, Nicaragua, and Uruguay are granted preferential duty treatment. Trade with Canada and the United States takes place under the NAFTA. Mexico has applied antidumping duties to the following products: synthetic rubber and steel products from Brazil; textiles and articles of apparel, electronic products for personal use, nonelectronic toys, pencils, padlocks, bicycles, shoes, tools, iron and steel valves, and chemical products from China; beef, polyvinyl chloride, seamless steel tubes, chemical products, and apples from the United States; seamless steel tubes from Japan; polyester from Korea; steel products from the Russian Federation and Ukraine; aluminum packaging from the República Bolivariana de Venezuela; chemical products from Denmark; and frozen beef, olive oil, and furazolidone from the EU. 908 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MEXICO Tariffs do not apply to imports destined for reexportation, except those under a free trade agreement. The tariff measures are designed to support industrial competitiveness, allow imports of strategic inputs, and reduce production costs. Specific tariff items exist for statistical purposes for wines, brandy, distilled agave, footwear heels and soles, and machinery for repairing airships and aircraft parts and steel products. Reduced generalized duty rates apply to about 6,187 tariff lines related to inputs in order to reorder product chains and standardize the rates applicable to intermediate inputs. Reduced duty rates are applicable to textile inputs, which are also subject to quotas. Effective February 22, 2007, the duty rate on various aluminum products has been eliminated. Effective June 18, 2007, reduced duty rates apply to inputs and capital assets, for sectors such as fur, plastics, and general manufactured products. Effective June 30, 2007, import duties were reduced for rattan fibers, medicines and devices used in the human health sector, and some fibers and textile inputs. Units of quantity and descriptions for various tariff items have been modified. New tariff items apply in sectors using chemical products, ostrich skins, galvanized zinc, steel sockets for tools, winches, and motorcycles. Numeric codes for 3,918 tariff items have been adjusted for goods imported into the Border Region. The amendment of the Program of Sectoral Promotion (PROSEC) decree reflects changes in the Customs Act to promote competitiveness and provides for adjustments in the numerical codes of the tariff items in these programs. Such laws specify activities for which investment is reserved for the government or Mexican investors. Thus, with the authorization of the MOE, investment trusts may be established by Mexican banks acting as trustees. These trusts issue ordinary participation certificates that may be acquired by foreign investors; the certificates grant only economic rights to their holders and do not confer voting rights in the companies whose stock is held by the trusts (such voting rights being exercisable only by the trustee). Foreign commercial entities must be authorized by the MOE before engaging in ongoing commercial activities in Mexican territory. Foreign securities publicly offered in the domestic market must be approved by the National Banking and Securities Commission (CNBV). CNBV authorization is required for banks and securities firms to purchase shares of foreign financial intermediaries. Controls apply to the purchase (1) of foreign securities by banks and securities firms on their own behalf and on behalf of their clients; and (2) by an insurance company or a privately managed pension fund of securities denominated in foreign currency, with the exceptions of capital market instruments registered in the National Registry of Securities (NRS) and of securities issued in foreign currency by the federal government or payable abroad by Mexican financial institutions or their foreign affiliates. Domestic securities offered in foreign markets must be registered with the NRS. The rules applicable to shares or other securities of a participating nature apply. Provisions specific to commercial banks and other credit institutions Provisions Specific to the Financial Sector Banks that obtain an unconditional warranty from foreign financial entities may be exempt from the limits on foreign currency liabilities and investments for foreign exchange transactions, provided the long-term debt of the warrantor is rated at least “AA–” by Standard & Poor’s or “Aa3” by Moody’s Investors Service. BOM approval is required for debt rated by other agencies. Banks, multiple-scope financial institutions, and limited-scope financial institutions must disclose fees and commissions to users of financial services, and the BOM is authorized to regulate the fees of banks and other financial intermediaries and to determine whether there are reasonable conditions regarding the fees charged by the institutions for active, passive, and service operations, as well as to take the appropriate regulatory measures. Granting of credits, financial leasing, and financial factoring may be provided by any person without approval by the federal government. People who engage in the aforesaid activities in a customary and professional manner are considered multiple-scope companies, which may be regulated or not regulated. Regulated multiple-scope companies are supervised by the CNBV and are entities that maintain economic links with credit institutions or 913 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MEXICO holding companies that have a credit institution in their financial group. Effective June 15, 2007, according to the Financial Services Ordainment and Transparency Law, the BOM may regulate interest rates, bank commissions, and anticipated payments of operations with clients by commercial banks, limited-scope financial institutions, and multiple-scope regulated financial institutions. Effective February 1, 2008, commercial banks’ operations are subject to limits on market concentration and operational credit risk. In the case of operational risk, limits apply to transactions made by one or more individuals or entities that are part of the same commercial group, that imply the acquisition of any kind of property or services. Effective the same date, certain acts and operations, such as transfers of resources made by credit institutions through foreign payment systems, are considered final, irrevocable, payable, and effective vis-à-vis third parties. Borrowing abroad is permitted, subject to the limits on the liabilities of commercial banks denominated in foreign currency and on open foreign exchange positions. Foreign exchange risk positions, both total and for each foreign currency, must not exceed the daily limit of 15% of a bank’s base capital. There are limits on the amount banks may lend, regardless of the borrower’s residence. There are limits on the amount that banks may lend regardless of the borrower’s nationality or residence, and on their net open foreign exchange position. Banks may enter into transactions on their own account with respect to securities, commercial debt instruments not registered with the NRS, and capital instruments, whether or not registered with the NRS. Banks must invest in liquid assets—as determined by the BOM and denominated in foreign currency—an amount calculated through the maturity structure of their liabilities payable in foreign currency. Controls apply to the types and amounts of transactions for banks. Any shareholder, regardless of nationality or residence, may acquire the control of “O” shares, with MOF approval. If the acquisition exceeds 5% of the shares representing the capital stock of a banking institution, CNBV approval is required prior to MOF approval. Yes. n.a. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Moldova is the Moldovan leu. Unitary. The National Bank of Moldova (NBM) intervenes in the domestic foreign exchange interbank market in order to smooth out sharp exchange rate fluctuations of the Moldovan leu against the dollar. The official exchange rate of the leu against the dollar is determined daily as the weighted average of the exchange rates used in market transactions. The official exchange rate is used in accounting and statistical calculations. Institutions eligible to deal in foreign exchange are authorized banks and foreign exchange bureaus. Foreign exchange purchased by individuals against cash at foreign exchange offices of authorized banks or at foreign exchange bureaus is subject to a tax of 0.1%. Receipts from this tax are used for domestic social services. No. Authorized banks and foreign exchange bureaus are the ADs on the domestic foreign exchange market. Authorized banks are allowed to purchase from and sell to residents and nonresidents any currency (intrabank market). Foreign exchange bureaus are authorized to perform exchange operations for individuals. Authorized banks and foreign exchange bureaus are allowed to set their own buying and selling rates for their foreign exchange transactions. The Moldovan foreign exchange market is decentralized. Authorized banks operate on the domestic foreign exchange interbank market. 923 ©International Monetary Fund. The use of foreign currency among residents is allowed only in cases stipulated by legislation. Moldova has concluded agreements on settlements with some CIS countries, providing for settlements and payments in accordance with international banking practices. There are several bilateral agreements for the promotion of investments and trade development that include provisions on payments between the signatories. Moldova has 10 bilateral interstate agreements on free trade with CIS countries, except for Tajikistan. The agreements on free trade within the CIS stipulate the full application of preferential trade, except for bilateral trade with the Russian Federation, Belarus, and Ukraine, which apply unilateral exceptions to this regime. Moldova has eight bilateral interstate agreements on free trade with countries that are members of the Stability Pact for South Eastern Europe. The CEFTA, which has been in effect since May 1, 2007, replaces the existing agreements on free trade within the Stability Pact and provides for canceling all import and export customs duties, quantitative restrictions, and other taxes with an equivalent effect on the trading of industrial products and most agro-industrial products. The NBM has ultimate authority for foreign exchange arrangements and is responsible for managing the country’s foreign exchange reserves, regulating the currency market, and granting licenses to engage in foreign currency transactions. According to the Law on Regulation of Repatriation of Funds, Goods, and Services Obtained from External Economic Transactions, control over the repatriation of funds, goods, and services is exercised by fiscal authorities, which carry out verification on repatriation through on-site inspections of legal entities’ economic activities. Secondhand centers and pawnshops are not allowed to purchase or accept for storage or as collateral precious metals in bullion or precious metal coins. A license from the Chamber of Licensing is required to conduct international trade in gold. Foreign currency may be imported and exported by resident banks with a B- or C- type license and, with NBM approval, by nonresident banks that have correspondent accounts with resident banks. Domestic currency may be imported and exported only by nonresident banks that have correspondent accounts with resident banks, and only with NBM approval. Imports and exports of banknotes and coins by resident and nonresident banks must be declared to customs. Resident and nonresident individuals have the right to export when departing from Moldova domestic currency cash and checks, as well as cash and traveler’s checks in foreign currency, up to the equivalent of (1) €10,000 an individual without submission to customs authorities of supporting documentation; and (2) €50,000 an individual by declaring in written form and submitting to the customs authorities the following supporting documents: (a) customs documents confirming the importation of currency into Moldova; and/or (b) export permissions issued, according to the NBM normative acts, by authorized banks or by the NBM. Resident and nonresident individuals have the right while entering Moldova to import unlimited banknotes, coins, and checks in domestic currency, as well as banknotes, coins, and traveler’s checks in foreign currency. Resident and nonresident individuals must declare in written form to the customs authorities the importation of banknotes, coins, and checks in domestic currency, as well as banknotes, coins, and traveler’s checks in foreign currency, if their total amount exceeds the equivalent of €10,000 an individual. The following imports are subject to licensing for the purpose of consumer protection and to ensure compliance with domestic standards: dual purpose goods and technologies, ammunition, military equipment, and special compounds for the manufacture thereof; explosive substances; nuclear products and technology; medicine, equipment for the manufacture of medicine, and medical equipment; chemicals; cultures for developing microorganisms; and stupefying or psychotropic materials and compounds for their derivation or production. There are several tariff bands for imports. A zero customs tariff is applied to cotton, fertilizers, pharmaceutical products, textbooks, and base metals and products thereof, as well as to other goods. Customs duties are not imposed on goods and objects produced in and imported from CIS countries that have ratified the Agreement on the Creation of a Free Trade Zone or with which Moldova has bilateral interstate agreements on free trade. Imported goods and services are subject to a standard VAT of 20%; imports of gas and liquid gases are subject to a reduced VAT of 5%. In 2007, a special 40% customs duty (but not less than €100 a ton) was applied on imported sugar as a safeguard measure and was temporarily extended, effective February 16, 2008, for four years. The CEFTA, which went into effect May 1, 2007, supersedes all existing free trade agreements in the framework of the Stability Pact for South Eastern Europe, and foretells the abolishment of all import and export customs duties, quantitative restrictions, and other taxes of equivalent effect in regard to trade in industrial goods and the majority of agro-industrial goods. Payments for Invisible Transactions and Current Transfers Controls on these transfers Resident individuals may freely purchase foreign currency through authorized banks or foreign exchange bureaus. The following rules apply for the making of current payments and transfers abroad (in foreign and domestic currencies) by resident individuals: (1) transfer abroad for the purpose of family expenses, as follows: (a) up to €1,000 without the submission of documents confirming kinship; (b) from €1,000 to the equivalent of €10,000 on submission of documents confirming kinship; and (c) more than €10,000 on submission of documents confirming kinship and of documents confirming the necessity of making the payment or transfer by the individual in whose benefit the transfer is made; (2) transfer abroad in the resident’s name for the purpose of current expenses for the period of his or her temporary stay abroad: (a) up to €10,000, on submission of documents confirming the temporary stay abroad; and (b) more than €10,000, on submission of documents confirming the temporary stay abroad and documents confirming the necessity of making the payment or transfer by the individual in whose benefit the transfer is made; (3) transfer abroad in the resident’s name for the purpose of obtaining a study visa, on submission of a document confirming the admission of the respective individual at the education institution and the document or information confirming the necessity of depositing funds in his or her account abroad for the purpose of obtaining the study visa; and (4) payment or transfer for the benefit of a nonresident in the amount of up to €1,000, without the submission of supporting documents, unless otherwise provided for in the normative acts of the NBM. Transfers exceeding €1,000 require the submission of supporting documents. Resident legal entities may purchase foreign currency through authorized banks and effect payments or transfers in favor of nonresidents for current international transactions up to the amounts shown in the supporting documents. Services must be rendered by nonresidents to resident legal entities no later than one year from the date of the advance payment for the services. Rendered services must be equal in value to the amount paid for them. If services are not rendered by nonresidents to resident legal entities, any amount of advance payment must be repatriated no later than one year after the advance payment was made. Nonresident individuals may purchase foreign currency through authorized banks or foreign exchange bureaus freely. Nonresident legal entities may purchase foreign currency freely through authorized banks. Submission to the authorized bank of the above documents is not required in the following cases: (1) for legal entities, in case of (a) transfers in the name of the same account holder; (b) payments or transfers by diplomatic missions, consular offices, other official representation of foreign states, and the representation of international organizations located and accredited in Moldova; and (c) payments or transfers by nonresident banks; and (2) for individuals, in the case of (a) transfer in their own name; and (b) payment or transfer in favor of an individual or legal entity in an amount not exceeding the equivalent of €1,000. The procedures for purchases of state securities by foreign investors at auctions are similar to those applied in the case of local investors. A foreign investor may not possess more than 50% of state securities within a single international securities identification number (ISIN), whether obtained on the primary or the secondary market. A noncompetitive bid submitted by an investor for state securities may not exceed MDL 300,000 at face value under a single ISIN number. The following rules apply to the purchase of shares or securities of a participating nature in Moldova. A person who purchases or acquires 5% or more of the total number of voting securities of a certain class of an issuer (and each subsequent purchase or acquisition of 5%) must inform the issuer within five working days of the date of purchase. The person, who purchased directly or indirectly, individually or with affiliates, a significant part of shares, representing more than 25% of voting shares of the company, must publish the relevant information in the mass media indicated in the company’s charter within 10 days of the purchase date. A public offer for mandatory takeover is performed if a certain person holds, individually or together with affiliates, more than 50% of the issuer’s voting shares in circulation. A public offer for mandatory takeover can be performed only once. A public offer for voluntary takeover is performed if a person, individually or together with affiliates, intends to receive more than 50% of voting shares in circulation of a certain issuer. A public offer on the secondary market is made by the insider, the issuer, or any other person. A public offer on the secondary market, initiated by the issuer with the aim of preventing a decrease of the security price on the stock exchange market, may be performed after notification of the National Commission for the Financial Markets (NCFM), not later than three days from the day the issuer submitted the request. Minority shareholders have the right to require, at any time, the acquisition of their shares at a reasonable price by the person who holds, independently or together with affiliates, more than 90% of the corporation’s total value of voting shares. This request must be fulfilled within 30 days. It is prohibited to submit a tender offer on the secondary market, purchase, sell, or negotiate the 931 ©International Monetary Fund. Provisions specific to commercial banks and other credit institutions Provisions Specific to the Financial Sector Resident banks are permitted to purchase (for their portfolios) securities issued and guaranteed by the governments of OECD countries (previously, G7 countries) to purchase financial derivatives (forwards, swaps, options, futures) with foreign currencies as the basic asset from nonresidents, and to make real estate investments abroad without NBM approval. The regulation on equity investments of banks in legal entities ensures the consolidated supervision of risks assumed by banks as a result of banks’ investments in legal entities, by requiring banks to present financial reports of the legal entities in which banks hold 25% or more of the capital, as well as informing the NBM of investments held in the capital of legal entities. Recommendations on the internal control systems of banks in Moldova determine the minimum list that must be maintained by banks of their direct and indirect owners to ensure transparency with regard to both the banks’ ownership structure and the individuals who have considerable influence over banks’ management and activity. Recommendations on the country and transfer risk management system by the banks in Moldova determine the fundamental principles related to internal policies and procedures of banks’ risk management. The regulation on holding significant interest in a bank extends the requirements for the presentation of information regarding the persons affiliated with an applicant wishing to hold a significant interest in banks’ equity and determines the procedures for the presentation of documents related to a foreign bank’s significant interest in a bank in Moldova. The regulation on publishing information on financial activity by authorized banks of Moldova requires banks to inform the public of the total 934 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MOLDOVA exposure of a bank to affiliated persons, accounting policy, principal strategic directions of banks’ activities, conditions of credit extension to individuals, and information on the bank’s management. Effective February 15, 2007, amendments were accepted to the regulation on the licensing of banks to increase the information presented in order to obtain a license. Effective November 30, 2007, procedures have been introduced for the risk assessment related to banks’ assets other than credits and contingent liabilities and for creating loan loss provisions. Effective January 25, 2008, prudential regulations related to the identification of clients and the effective beneficiaries, the monitoring of transactions and business relationships, and enhanced precautions have been amended to provide for the prevention and combating of money laundering and terrorism financing. Effective February 26, 2008, the procedures for preventing and combating money laundering by banks have been amended. Notification to the NBM is required for (1) financial loans or credits, except for interbank loans (for the purpose of managing bank liquidity) with an initial repayment period of less than one year; and (2) commercial loans or credits bearing interest and factoring, except for factoring operations in which the nonresident factor assumes the risk for the debtor’s insolvency. There are no controls on the opening and maintaining of FCAs abroad by banks holding types B and C banking licenses. Authorized banks may open accounts in lei with nonresident banks only with NBM approval. Authorized banks are prohibited from opening accounts in shell banks. NBM approval is required for financial loans or credits, except for (1) interbank credits (for the purpose of managing bank liquidity) with an initial repayment period of less than one year, and (2) financial leasing. Banks holding types B or C licenses are allowed to extend foreign currency credits to (1) other resident banks; (2) resident legal entities and (a) from individuals engaged in entrepreneurial activities for settlements with nonresidents; (b) from funds received in accordance with credit agreements between the government and nonresidents or between resident banks and international financial institutions; (c) from funds under cofinancing programs, in accordance with credit agreements between the government and nonresidents or between resident banks and international financial institutions; (3) resident individuals for settlements with nonresidents for personal expenses such as education, medical treatment, and items for personal use; and (4) legal entities and individuals for reimbursing credits in foreign exchange from other resident banks received for settlement with nonresidents. Restrictions are imposed on certain transactions with the former Republic of Serbia and Montenegro. n.a. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Mongolia is the Mongolian togrog. Unitary. The de jure exchange rate arrangement is managed floating with no predetermined path for the exchange rate. The Bank of Mongolia (BOM) reserves the right to intervene in the foreign exchange market using the dollar as the principal intervention currency. The official (reference) exchange rate of the togrog vis-à- vis the dollar is announced daily by the BOM as the daily average of the buying and selling rates of transactions among participants in the interbank foreign exchange market. The official exchange rate is applied to customs valuation and public sector imports and service payments, including debt service, and to trade and service transactions conducted under bilateral payments arrangements. Exchange rates for other convertible currencies are calculated on the basis of the cross rates vis-à-vis the dollar in international markets. As the result of the exchange rate stability due to official action, the classification of the de facto exchange rate arrangement is a conventional pegged arrangement. No. No. n.a. n.a. n.a. Effective March 28, 2007, a bank must meet the reserve requirements for togrog and foreign currency deposits with togrog and foreign currency reserves, respectively. In meeting the reserve requirements, there is a 50% cap on the share of the reserve requirement that may be met by cash in vault for foreign currency reserves, but togrog cash in vault is not treated as reserves for togrog deposits. Banks are required to obtain a supplementary foreign exchange settlement license to engage in these transactions. Effective November 17, 2007, the limits are 15% of adjusted capital for the net position in a single currency and 40% of adjusted capital for the total net position in all currencies. The adjusted capital is calculated as follows: (1) The amount of capital invested in parent, subsidiary, and other affiliated financial institutions is deducted from tier 1 capital. (2) The maximum amount of tier 2 capital must be less than the amount of tier 1 capital, and the amount of subordinated debt under tier 2 capital is limited to 50% of tier 1 capital. (3) If a bank and a related party have holdings of each other’s capital, directly or indirectly, the lesser of the cross holdings will be deducted from the bank’s capital to determine the adjusted capital. In accordance with the relevant UN Security Council resolutions, authorization from the Foreign Exchange Office (FEO) is required to conduct financial transactions between residents and nonresident individuals or entities with suspected links to terrorism. Morocco maintains restrictions against certain countries pursuant to UN Security Council resolutions. www.oc.gov.ma. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Morocco is the Moroccan dirham. Commemorative gold coins with a face value of DH 250 and DH 500 and commemorative silver coins with a face value of DH 50, DH 100, DH 150, and DH 200 are also legal tender. Unitary. Bank Al-Maghrib (BAM)—the central bank—intervenes continuously in the market during the day by setting the buying and selling rates applicable to its operations with banks, based on a basket of currencies weighted in accordance with the geographic distribution of Morocco’s foreign trade. The basket is composed of the euro and the dollar, with weights of 80% and 20%, respectively. This quotation system is also based on dollar exchange rates in the international exchange markets, respecting a 0.6% spread between the buying and selling prices. Banks trade within this range. A 0.2% commission is charged on customers’ purchases and sales of currencies for dirhams. This commission is not charged on transactions between banks. No. For exchange operations with customers, banks may not exceed the rate limits of 0.6% between the buying and selling prices set by the BAM. Prescription of currency requirements Controls on the use of domestic currency Use of foreign exchange among residents Payments arrangements Regional arrangements Administration of control Payments arrears Controls on trade in gold (coins and/or bullion) On domestic ownership and/or trade On external trade Controls on exports and imports of banknotes Arrangements for Payments and Receipts All transactions between Morocco and foreign countries—regardless of the type of transaction—must be settled in foreign currencies that are quoted by the BAM or in convertible dirhams. Controls apply to the use of domestic currency for current and capital transactions and payments. Transactions among residents in Morocco must be denominated and settled in domestic currency. A regional payments arrangement among the CBs of Algeria, Libya, Mauritania, Morocco, and Tunisia governs payment operations among those countries. Economic operators may settle their transactions either within the framework of these arrangements or by following normal procedures. Exchange control is administered by the FEO, an agency under the MOF. This office has delegated the execution of the main exchange control measures to authorized banks. Import and export licenses, which are required for some products, are issued by the Department of Foreign Trade (DFT). No. Residents may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Morocco for numismatic or investment purposes. Ten different types of foreign gold coins are traded on the Casablanca Stock Exchange, which does not, however, deal in gold bars. Imports of gold are subject to authorization from the Customs and Indirect Taxes Administration. The MOF fixes an annual quota for the importation of gold ingots. The quota is then allocated among jewelers and industrial users of precious metals. Exports of gold are also regulated. The regulatory framework for foreign currency exchange stipulates that foreign exchange bureaus dealing exclusively with foreign currency exchange business must be legal entities with a minimum capital of DH 500,000. In addition to licensed intermediary banks, foreign exchange bureaus and cash transfer corporations are authorized to buy, in exchange for domestic currency, foreign banknotes and/or foreign-currency-denominated traveler’s checks, and to sell for cash, in exchange for domestic currency, foreign banknotes or traveler’s checks, 952 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MOROCCO as part of the allowance for tourists and the allowances for missions and internships abroad undertaken by personnel of central and local governments and of public institutions and enterprises. Subdelegated institutions may engage solely in the purchase of foreign-currency-denominated banknotes and traveler’s checks in exchange for dirhams, on behalf of an authorized intermediary of their choice. Exportation of domestic banknotes is subject to authorization. However, authorized intermediary banks may export dirham-denominated banknotes to the Tangiers free export zone, subject to an export declaration. The dirhams must be drawn from convertible dirham accounts of operators in the free export zone and used solely for payments to residents for the following expenditures: wages and other wage-earner remuneration up to any amount, transportation, repairs, work, and supplies of products from the territory covered, in sums of up to DH 3,000 an operation and subject to an annual ceiling of DH 120,000 an operator. Effective April 25, 2007, travelers are also authorized to export up to DH 1,000 in dirham banknotes. Foreign and Moroccan nonresidents may export foreign-currency-denominated means of payment debited from their foreign exchange or convertible dirham accounts, or previously imported. Foreign nationals visiting Morocco are permitted to repurchase foreign exchange on presentation of receipts indicating the amount of the original conversion of foreign exchange into dirhams. Residents may also export foreign banknotes within the limits specified in foreign exchange regulations. Effective April 25, 2007, exports of foreign banknotes must be declared at border customs offices and be justified by the original signed import declaration when the amount to be exported exceeds or is equal to the foreign exchange equivalent of DH 100,000 (previously, DH 50,000). Moroccans residing abroad may export up to 40% of foreign exchange that was repatriated and sold on the foreign exchange market over the previous 12 months, up to a maximum of DH 50,000, excluding the foreign exchange credited to the convertible dirham account. The importation of domestic banknotes is subject to authorization. Travelers are, however, authorized to import, effective April 25, 2007, up to DH 1,000 in dirham banknotes. Nonresident travelers may bring in unlimited amounts of foreign banknotes, traveler’s checks, and other means of payment denominated in foreign exchange. Resident travelers may also import unlimited amounts of foreign banknotes, but must surrender them for dirhams within 30 days of their return to Morocco. Effective April 25, 2007, imports of foreign banknotes must be declared at border customs offices when the amount to be imported exceeds the equivalent of DH 100,000 (previously, DH 50,000). www.oc.gov.ma; www.bkam.ma; www.douane.gov.ma. Not for Redistribution Foreign exchange accounts permitted Held domestically Approval required Held abroad MOROCCO Resident Accounts Yes. Two types of accounts may be opened. (1) Foreign resident individuals and corporations may open foreign exchange accounts in Moroccan banks without limitation. These accounts may be credited with transfers from abroad, any foreign- exchange-denominated means of payment (e.g., banknotes or traveler’s checks), or foreign currency that was withdrawn from a Moroccan bank in accordance with current foreign exchange regulations. They may be debited for transfers abroad or for purchases of dirhams for all domestic settlements. There are no restrictions on the rate of interest payable on the accounts or on transfers between foreign exchange accounts or between these accounts and convertible dirham accounts. Authorized banks may issue international credit cards to holders of these accounts. Overdrafts on these accounts are not permitted. (2) Effective January 8, 2007, Moroccan exporters of goods and services (including fishing companies) may open foreign exchange accounts and deposit up to 50% of the repatriated foreign exchange receipts from exports (previously, 20%). The accounts may be credited in full or in part, at the discretion of the exporter. In the case of a partial credit, the remaining amount may subsequently be credited to the account within a maximum period of one year from the date the foreign exchange was sold on the foreign exchange market. Exporters’ foreign exchange accounts may also be credited without restriction within one year (a) with transfers from other foreign exchange or convertible dirham accounts belonging to the same account holder, (b) with amounts debited from foreign exchange accounts and sold on the foreign exchange market, and (c) with amounts withdrawn from convertible dirham accounts for payment of expenses in Morocco. These amounts may be credited to exporters’ accounts within a period of one year of the date on which they are debited. The accounts may also be credited with foreign banknotes withdrawn and not used, provided the account is credited within 90 days of the date the foreign currency is withdrawn. The accounts may be debited (a) for all expenses in foreign exchange related to the account holder’s professional activity; (b) to credit another foreign exchange or convertible dirham account opened in the name of the same account holder; and (c) to sell foreign exchange on the foreign exchange market. Authorized banks may issue international credit cards to holders of these accounts. Overdrafts on these accounts are not permitted. The overall limit on exporters crediting their repatriated export earnings on a foreign exchange or a convertible dirham account is 50% of repatriated earnings. Effective March 1, 2007, authorized banks may open foreign currency accounts for insurance and reinsurance companies and make transfers related to foreign deposit, investment, and placement operations. Effective March 21, 2007, authorized banks may open foreign currency accounts to allow traders to improve their management of international trade operations while avoiding exchange rate fluctuations and the commissions and fees related to foreign currency buying and selling operations. Approval is not required for resident foreign nationals, nor, effective January 8, 2007, for exporters of goods and services. Effective January 8, 2007, authorized banks may transfer funds for deposit in accounts with banks in OECD, EU, and AMU member countries on their own behalf and on behalf of (1) insurance and reinsurance companies for up to 5% of the total volume of their reserves, (2) retirement agencies for up to 5% of the total volume of their reserves, and (3) UCITS for up to 10% of their assets.
