Status under IMF Articles of Agreement Restrictions and/or multiple currency practices Exchange measures imposed for security reasons In accordance with IMF Executive Board Decision No. 144-(52/51) References to legal instruments and hyperlinks Currency Exchange rate structure Classification Managed floating with no predetermined path for the exchange rate Exchange tax Exchange subsidy Exchange Measures No restrictions as reported in the latest staff report as of December 31, 2007. On August 10, 2007, the authorities notified the IMF that under Article 17 of Law 17.835 of September 23, 2004, on the Strengthening of the System for the Control and Prevention of Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing, financial intermediation institutions are required to inform the Central Bank of Uruguay’s (CBU’s) Financial Intelligence and Analysis Unit (FIAU) of the existence of assets linked to (1) persons identified as terrorists or as belonging to terrorist organizations in the relevant lists of individuals and entities prepared by the United Nations; (2) persons who have been declared terrorists by means of a valid national or foreign judicial decision. In addition, Article 6 of said law gives the FIAU powers to prevent transactions involving such individuals or legal entities from being carried out for a period of 72 hours. The law further provides that the FIAU’s decision must be communicated immediately to the criminal courts, which shall determine, in light of the circumstances of the case, whether the assets should be frozen without prior notice. In addition, this procedure applies to all transactions giving rise to reasonable suspicion of a link with criminal organizations related to the predicate offenses of money laundering, as described and cited in Article 8 of the law. n.a. Provisions Specific to the Financial Sector Provisions specific to commercial banks and other credit institutions Differential treatment of deposit accounts in foreign exchange Reserve requirements Liquid asset requirements Differential treatment of deposit accounts held by nonresidents Reserve requirements Liquid asset requirements The mandatory minimum reserve requirements for deposits in local currency are 17%, 9%, 6%, and 4% for maturities of less than 30 days, 30 to 90 days, 91 to 180 days, and 181 to 367 days, respectively. The mandatory reserve requirements on foreign currency interest-bearing deposits of residents are 25% for maturities of less than 180 days and 19% for longer maturities. The reserve requirement position is calculated on the basis of daily deposits, including weekends, and must be held in deposits with the CBU or in notes and coins. For minimum reserve requirements in both local and foreign currency, reserve balances are allowed to be less than the required level for up to four days a month without incurring a fine. Liquidity requirements in domestic currency are as follows: (1) 17% of demand obligations, with notice and for a contractual maturity of less than 30 days; (2) 9% of obligations with maturities of between 30 and 90 days; (3) 6% of obligations with maturities of between 91 and 180 days; and (4) 4% of obligations with maturities of more than 180 days and less than 367 days (maturities are contractual). These requirements may be met by (1) notes and coins, (2) demand deposits with the CBU, (3) fixed-term deposits with the CBU for less than 30 days, (4) fixed- term deposit certificates issued by the CBU with maturities of less than 30 days, (5) monetary regulation bills issued by the CBU, and (6) indexed securities issued by the CBU. The following liquidity requirements apply to foreign currency deposits of residents: (1) 25% of demand obligations, with notice and maturities of up to 180 days, and (2) 19% of obligations with maturities of more than 180 days (maturities are contractual). These requirements may be met by (1) notes and coins, (2) demand deposits with the CBU, (3) fixed-term deposits with the CBU for less than 30 days, (4) demand placements for less than 30 days with foreign banks with a rating of at least BBB+ or the equivalent, and (5) foreign government securities with a rating of at least BBB+ or the equivalent. Some banks have specific instructions for greater liquidity requirements. Foreign currency deposits of nonresidents are exempt from the foreign currency reserve requirement. There is a 30% liquidity requirement for all obligations in foreign currency to nonresidents. The requirement may be met by (1) notes and coins, (2) demand 1534 ©International Monetary Fund. The instruments detailed in points (1) through (5) should be used to constitute at least 50% of this requirement. A ceiling is placed on foreign or local currency asset positions of 150% of the book value equity less administrative fixed assets (i.e., nonperforming loans that are two years or more overdue, fixed assets, investments, and deferred charges). The ceiling on the long or short asset-liability positions in foreign-currency-denominated “operations to be settled” (i.e., future contracts and sales of securities subject to repurchase agreements) is 150% of the book value equity less administrative fixed assets. In addition, there is a ceiling on the foreign currency position (after deduction of the operations-to-be-settled position) of 170% of the book value equity less administrative fixed assets. In order to comply with technical coverage ratios, insurance institutions may invest in securities issued by nonresidents, up to a maximum per-issuer limit of 5% of nonpension obligations and required capital. This limit may be increased by up to 20% for sovereign securities. In order to comply with technical coverage ratios, insurance companies may invest in securities issued by nonresidents, up to a maximum per-issuer limit of 5% of nonpension obligations and required capital. This limit may be increased by up to 20% for sovereign securities. At least 70% of obligations and required capital must be covered by domestic instruments. Insurance companies must match assets with liabilities in each currency. For foreign currency, the same-day buy and sell ceiling for pension funds is 0.4% of assets or the equivalent of $2 million. However, if 0.4% of assets is less than $1 million, pension funds may trade up to that amount daily. Further, there is a limit on trading the same instrument on the same day of up to 1.5% of the pension fund assets for the previous day. Private pension funds are prohibited from investing in securities held abroad. Nevertheless, temporary funds may invest in fixed-income securities issued by international lending institutions of which the country is a member, up to 15% of the value of their assets. Private pension funds must hold a minimum of 30% and a maximum of 60% of total assets in government securities. In the public sector, the type of operation permitted depends on the type of institution. Public institutions are bound by their own bylaws, and the central government and subgovernments use their own procedures, which are more restrictive. Pension funds are authorized to hold up to 60% of their assets in foreign-currency-denominated instruments. No. n.a. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Uzbekistan is the Uzbek sum. Unitary. Since April 2007, the sum has been depreciating vis-à-vis the dollar within a 2% crawling band, while the Central Bank of Uzbekistan’s (CBU’s) one-sided interventions have resulted in steady reserve accumulation. As a result, the exchange rate arrangement has been reclassified, effective April 1, 2007, to the category crawling peg from the category conventional pegged arrangement. Effective January 1, 2008, the official exchange rate is determined on the basis of interbank trading sessions (ITS) relative to two currencies, the dollar and the euro. The official exchange rate of the CBU is determined once a week as the average ITS rate for the previous week, and it remains in effect for one week. Exchange rates for other currencies are determined on the basis of their cross rates vis-à-vis the dollar in the international market. The margin of the official buying and selling rates vis-à-vis the official exchange rate did not exceed 0.15% in 2007. The CBU participates in ITS for the purpose of balancing supply and demand. No. No. Commercial banks perform spot transactions with clients by mutual agreement. Transactions in interbank trading sessions are performed on a spot basis at the exchange rate determined in trading. Commercial banks may conclude over-the-counter swap agreements with each other and with clients. Resident and nonresident individuals may export cash domestic currency in an amount not exceeding 50 times the minimum wage; larger amounts require CBU permission. Resident and nonresident legal entities are not permitted to export cash domestic currency, with the exception of the CBU and authorized banks that have CBU permission. Resident individuals may export cash foreign currency up to the equivalent of $2,000 without restriction, amounts between $2,000 and $5,000 with permission of the CBU or an authorized bank, and amounts in excess of $5,000 with CBU permission. Nonresident individuals may export cash foreign currency up to the amount imported and declared to customs; exports of cash foreign currency in excess of this amount require permission from the CBU or an authorized bank. Resident and nonresident legal entities are not permitted to export cash foreign currency, with the exception of the CBU and authorized banks that have CBU permission. Imports and Import Payments No. No. Prior to the conversion of funds, the MFERIT evaluates import contracts that are (1) financed by the budget, (2) financed by credits or loans borrowed or guaranteed by the government, or (3) entered into by entities that are more than 50% state owned and are not secured by their own foreign exchange resources. All contracts must be registered with the relevant foreign exchange control division in the territorial offices of the State Customs Committee within seven days after application is made to an authorized bank. In order to purchase foreign currency, enterprises and organizations that are clients of an authorized bank must present to the bank a conversion application and a contract (agreement, accord) with a foreign partner. Importer entities may engage consulting firms for evaluation of contracts and execution of preshipment inspections of the imported goods followed by the registration of the contract with the MFERIT, or apply to the MFERIT for evaluation of contracts based on the established procedure without a preshipment inspection, with certain exceptions as established in the legislation. Preshipment inspection is mandatory for imports of meat and edible meat by-products; dairy products; oils, seeds, and fruits; alcoholic and nonalcoholic beverages; tobacco products; equipment, mechanical devices, and electrical machinery imported for the implementation of projects that are part of the Republic of Uzbekistan Investment Program. Preshipment inspection is not required for deliveries of goods under contracts that do not exceed $10,000 in total value nor for specific goods imported under licenses issued by the MFERIT. Documentary LCs are used in import settlements. Certain consumer goods require health and quality certification by the state agency, Uzstandart. Imports of narcotic drugs, psychotropic substances, and their precursors require import licenses from the Ministry of Health. Imports of weapons, precious metals and stones, and uranium and other radioactive substances require MFERIT import licenses. Imports of foreign movies, videos, and audio recordings require import licenses from the Ministry of Cultural Affairs and Sports. Imports of ozone- depleting substances require a permit from the State Conservation Committee. Individuals importing goods for commercial purposes must be registered as unincorporated individual entrepreneurs and authorized to engage in export-import operations and retail trade. Foreign citizens may engage in any work not reserved for the citizens of Uzbekistan (e.g., the practice of law). Imports of the following are prohibited: printed matter, manuscripts, printing plates, drawings, photographs, photographic film, negatives, movies, video or audio products, phonograph records, and audio materials aimed at undermining 1540 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Other nontariff measures Import taxes and/or tariffs State import monopoly References to legal instruments and hyperlinks UZBEKISTAN state or social order; violating the country’s territorial integrity, political independence, or state sovereignty; or promoting war, terrorism, violence, national exclusivity, religious hatred, or racism and various forms thereof; and materials with pornographic content. Maximum limits for duty-free imports by resident and nonresident individuals apply to the following: (1) consumer goods for personal use from the territory of contiguous states, and (2) goods for proprietary needs from the territory of noncontiguous states. The simple average customs tariff rate is 14.93%, and the weighted average tariff rate is 16.6%, based on total import volume, or 1.85%, based on total import volume, excluding duty-free items. Ad valorem customs duty rates are applied at four levels: zero, 5%, 10%, and 30% of the customs value. Of 10,814 subheadings of the Harmonized Code (at the 10-digit level), the zero rate applies to 930 subheadings, the 5% rate to 2,758, the 10% rate to 3,070, and the 30% rate to 3,283. Combined duty rates apply to 773 commodity headings. In addition, an excise tax of between 5% and 200% is levied on 2,500 product groups. A VAT of 20% is levied on all imported goods, excluding the following: (1) goods imported by individuals within the limits of the duty-free import allowances established by the customs legislation; (2) goods intended for official use by foreign diplomatic and equivalent representative offices, as well as goods intended for the personal use of diplomatic and administrative and technical personnel of these representative offices and members of their families residing with them; (3) goods imported in the form of humanitarian assistance, following the procedure determined by the Cabinet of Ministers of the Republic of Uzbekistan; (4) goods imported for charitable purposes, including technical assistance, under the auspices of states, governments, and international institutions; (5) goods imported at the expense of grants provided by states, governments, and international institutions; (6) pharmaceuticals (veterinary drugs), medical (veterinary) products, and raw materials imported for manufacturing pharmaceuticals and medical (veterinary) products; (7) technical equipment imported into the customs territory of Uzbekistan based on a list established in accordance with the legislation, as well as components and spare parts, provided their delivery is specified under the terms of the contract for the delivery of the technical equipment. If imported technical equipment is sold or transferred free of charge for exportation within three years of the date it is imported, this concession is revoked, and the requirement to pay the VAT for the entire period the concession was applied is reinstated; (8) property imported as fulfillment of an investment commitment under a contract between an investor and the authorized government agency responsible for state property management; (9) systems hardware used for operational investigative purposes, acquired by telecommunications operators and the special agency for certification of systems hardware, for operational investigative purposes, provided there is written confirmation by the authorized government body; (10) raw materials, supplies, and semi-finished products for use in one’s own production operations and imported by foreign investment enterprises specializing in production of children’s shoes. Effective January 1, 2008, the procedure for the payment of customs charges established for legal entities applies to individuals who are involved in foreign economic activity. Agreements and guarantees pertaining to state external borrowing must be registered with the MOF, and agreements on external borrowing not guaranteed by Uzbekistan must be registered with the CBU. Controls apply to all credit operations and transactions in guarantees, sureties, and financial backup facilities. Investors may establish enterprises abroad on decision of the legal entity’s top management body. The MFERIT must be notified of the registration of an enterprise abroad. Investors may establish foreign investment enterprises (FIEs), which are a form of direct investment, after their registration with the Ministry of Justice and its regional offices. Enterprises may acquire FIE status subject to the following conditions: (1) The statutory capital of the enterprise must be at least $150,000. (2) One of the participants in the enterprise must be a foreign legal entity. (3) The share of foreign investment must be at least 30% of the enterprise’s statutory capital. Enterprises with foreign capital participation that do not meet these criteria may be established via registration with the khokimiyats (governor’s offices). The Ministry of Justice and its regional offices oversee the FIEs’ compliance with their statutory obligations and the procedures for their registration and liquidation. 1546 ©International Monetary Fund. In accordance with the relevant legislation, an investment fund is a legal entity engaging in the acquisition and issuance of stocks for the purpose of mobilizing monetary resources of investors and investing them in the fund’s name in securities, bank accounts, and deposits. Banks and insurance companies whose activities are regulated by Uzbek legislation on banks and insurance companies may not be investment funds. The issuance and circulation of securities in Uzbekistan are subject to registration by the state and must receive a registration number following the established procedure. The Cabinet of Ministers establishes the general rules, annual quotas, and procedure for permitting the circulation of securities of nonresident issuers. Investment funds may invest only in securities of enterprises registered by the state and with their principal business carried out in Uzbekistan. In accordance with government decisions, an investment fund does not have the right (1) to acquire common stock of any joint-stock company in the event that after their acquisition more than 10% of the stock of that company will belong to entities affiliated with the investment fund; (2) to invest more than 10% of its net assets in the securities of a single issuer or in the stakes (participation shares) of a limited liability company established on the basis of a privatized enterprise, with the exception of government securities; and (3) to exchange stocks issued by the fund for stocks of joint-stock companies established in the process of denationalization, of which the State Property Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan is a holder in an amount exceeding 5% of the net assets of the investment fund. The proportion of stocks of the investment fund of which the State Property Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan acts as a holder may not exceed 5% of the net assets of the investment fund. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Vanuatu is the Vanuatu vatu. Unitary. Officially, the external value of the vatu is determined on the basis of an undisclosed transactions-weighted (trade and tourism receipts) basket of currencies of Vanuatu’s major trading partners. In pratice, the vatu has shown significant volatility against possible composites. Effective April 30, 2007, the classification of the de facto exchange rate arrangement has been changed from a conventional pegged arrangement to managed floating with no predetermined path for the exchange rate. The Reserve Bank of Vanuatu (RBV) buys from and sells to commercial banks U.S. dollars only; however, it also deals in Australian dollars, euros, yen, New Zealand dollars, and pounds sterling with other customers. The RBV quotes rates daily for the vatu against the above currencies. Buying and selling rates of the vatu against the currencies in the basket are quoted once a day within margins ranging between 0.25% and 0.30% around the middle rate. The RBV has the authority to restrict imports to the equivalent of $100,000 an individual. The import duty structure consists of eight rates, ranging from zero to 30%, with the 30% rate applying to most goods. Most basic items that were previously duty- free are subject to a 5% duty. Approved goods imported under the Melanesian Spearhead Group Trade Agreement and the PICTA and PACER trade agreements are duty-free. These goods require certificates of origin issued to exporters and importers by the member countries. Effective January 2, 2007, the import duty rates of tariff items have been revised, leading to an increase in all tariffs. Exports and Export Proceeds n.r. n.r. n.r. n.r. The exportation of logs and flitches is banned for environmental reasons. Under special circumstances, small parcels of logs may be exported if they cannot be processed by a company in Vanuatu. Proposals to export logs require approval of the Council of Ministers. Export permits—whose issuance is coordinated by the Environmental Unit and the Forestry Department—are required for rare or endangered species. The exportation of sandalwood logs is banned, and sandalwood must be processed locally prior to exportation. For conservation purposes, exports of certain products, including trochus, green snails, bêches-de-mer, mother-of-pearl, aquarium fish, crustaceans, and coconut crabs, are subject to authorization. The annual quota of bêches-de-mer that can be exported from Vanuatu in a year is 26 tons, and they must be of the specified size. Exports of copra and cocoa are channeled through the Vanuatu Commodities Marketing Board. Exports of kava, declared a prescribed commodity under the Vanuatu Commodities Marketing Board, are subject to authorization from the Quarantine Office. Exports of artifacts having exceptional value, either as a result of ceremonial use or because they are more than 10 years old, are subject to authorization from the Cultural Center. There are taxes on exports of logs; unworked shells; and wood in the rough, whether stripped of bark and sapwood or roughly squared. n.a. No. www.bcv.org.ve; www.cadivi.gob.ve. Exchange Arrangement The currency of the República Bolivariana de Venezuela is the Venezuelan bolívar. Venezuelan gold coins are legal tender, but do not circulate. Some foreign exchange transactions take place in the parallel market at exchange rates that may differ from the official exchange rate. The exchange rate of the bolívar is pegged to the dollar. The Central Bank of Venezuela (CBV), by joint agreement with the National Executive Power, may adjust the exchange rate at any time. The bolívar has been stable since March 3, 2005, after having been devalued by 11.98%. Effective January 1, 2008, exchange transactions and their value in bolívares must be reexpressed by using the following formula: the amounts must be divided by 1,000, and multiplied by 10 to the Nth power, with N being set by the CBV. According to the new methodology, the exchange rate of the bolívar is Bs 2,144.600.000 (buying) and Bs 2,150.000.000 (selling) per $1. No. No. n.a. n.a. n.a. n.a. Yes. n.a. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Vietnam is the Vietnamese dong. Unitary. The State Bank of Vietnam (SBV) announces the daily average interbank exchange rate against the dollar; authorized credit institutions base their bid and offer quotations on this rate. Effective March 10, 2008, the SBV widened the dollar- dong trading band, allowing banks to trade in the trading band of ±1% around the rate quoted by the SBV. Previously, the band was widened to ±0.5% on January 1, 2007, and to ±0.75% on December 24, 2007. There is no preannounced path for the central rate. According to a previous announcement of the SBV, the annual depreciation target for the dong is limited to 1%. The actual central exchange rate remained stable in 2007. Not for Redistribution Interbank market Forward exchange market References to legal instruments and hyperlinks VIETNAM Banks and financial institutions are not allowed to trade outside the dollar- dong trading band, but they may set exchange rates with respect to other currencies at their discretion. The SBV permits authorized credit institutions to enter into forward and swap transactions between the dong and foreign currency with maturities of 3 to 365 days. The maturities of forward, swap, and option transactions of foreign currencies are negotiated between authorized credit institutions and customers. The dong-dollar forward rate is set on the basis of (1) the spot rate of the day of signing the forward and swap contract, (2) the difference between the dong base interest rate (a year) announced by the SBV and the U.S. target interest rate (announced by the Federal Reserve), and (3) the maturity of the contract. Authorized credit institutions are not permitted to conduct options transactions with economic entities and other organizations and individuals; however, recently, options transactions with negotiated fees were introduced as a pilot. Imports of certain products are controlled by other ministries for health, safety, and moral purposes. Prohibited imports are weapons, ammunition, explosives, and other military equipment; nonmedical drugs and toxic chemicals; reactionary and/or pornographic materials; fireworks and children’s toys that detrimentally influence personality, education, social order, or safety; cigarettes (excluding limited quantities imported during personal travel); most used consumer goods; most used vehicles, including bicycles and motorcycles, and used vehicle parts; and some types of passenger vehicles. The Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI), in coordination with the Ministry of Trade (MOT), may impose ad hoc temporary quantity controls. In addition, imports of motorcycles with a capacity of 175 cubic centimeters require an import license from the MOT, and imports of sport guns and bullets require an import license from the Sport Ministry. Some additional nontariff measures exist. There are 20 tariff rates, ranging up to 150%. Most imports of machinery, equipment, and medicine are exempt from tariffs. Certain imports of foreign enterprises that are incorporated under the Law on Foreign Investment are also exempt from tariffs. (Country Report No. 08/41) No. n.a. Exchange Arrangement The currency of Zambia is the Zambian kwacha. Unitary. The official exchange rate is determined in the interbank market. The Bank of Zambia (BOZ) intervenes in the market primarily through transactions with primary dealers but may also engage in transactions with other banks. The interbank rates provide the basis for determining the BOZ exchange rates: the BOZ’s buying rate is the simple average of the primary dealers’ low-bid rates, and the BOZ’s selling rate is the simple average of the primary dealers’ high-offer rates. Reflecting the practice of the BOZ to intervene only in exceptional circumstances, the classification of the de facto exchange rate arrangement has been changed effective January 1, 2008, from managed floating with no predetermined path for the exchange rate to independently floating. No. No. n.a. n.a. n.a. All foreign currency trades must take place in the interbank market. The market relies on primary dealers as market makers to provide two-way bid and offer prices during business hours, with the spread based on market fundamentals. Interbank trades are quoted in lots of $500,000. The bid-offer rate spread may not exceed $20.00. 1583 ©International Monetary Fund. Currency Exchange rate structure Classification Conventional pegged arrangement Exchange tax Exchange subsidy Foreign exchange market Exchange Arrangement The currency of Zimbabwe is the Zimbabwe dollar. The Zimbabwe dollar has been redenominated using a rate of 1:1,000. Multiple. Effective May 2, 2008, a new market-determined foreign exchange pricing framework has been introduced. The Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe (RBZ) posts on Reuters the average interbank exchange rate derived from the bid/offer rates of ADs reported to the RBZ. Previously, under the Tradable Foreign Currency Balance System, the interbank exchange rate was allowed to depreciate by a daily maximum of (1) 1% if the volume transacted in the market reached US$5– US$10 million a day; (2) 1.5% if daily transaction volume reached US$10– US$15 million a day; and (3) 2% if it exceeded US$15 million a day. Under this system, volume was known only to the RBZ, and the RBZ effectively fixed the exchange rate. All foreign exchange transactions by the government are effected at the rate of Z$30,000 per US$1. The guaranteed floor exchange rate for inward remittances is the interbank rate. No. Effective May 2, 2008, the support price of Z$700 billion a kilogram on gold deliveries was eliminated. The new pricing structure is based on the previous day’s London gold afternoon fix price, calculated at the prevailing interbank exchange rate. An official rate for government imports and debt service with Afreximbank applies at Z$30 per US$1 (after redenomination). Public enterprises receive foreign exchange from the RBZ at the prevailing interbank rate. For the 2007 selling season, the new producer price of cotton was Z$500 a kilogram. The producer prices of wheat and maize were Z$49,000 a ton and Z$2,000 a ton, respectively. Effective May 2, 2008, ADs may match buyers and sellers of foreign exchange according to a predetermined list of priorities. ADs are required to submit to the RBZ the details of the transactions they handle on a biweekly basis. 1588 ©International Monetary Fund. No person, either as principal or agent, may deal in or possess gold unless that person is (1) the holder of a license or permit, (2) the holder or distributor of a registered mining location from which gold is being produced, or (3) the employee or agent of any of the persons mentioned in (1) and (2) above and authorized by an employer or principal to deal in or possess gold that is already in the lawful possession of the employer or principal. A mining commissioner may issue to any person a permit authorizing the acquisition, possession, or disposal of any gold, provided the quantity does not exceed one troy ounce. In all other cases, permission may be issued only by the secretary for mines. Under the terms of the Gold Trade Act, three types of licenses may be issued: a gold dealing license, a gold recovery works license, and a gold assaying license. All gold obtained from a registered mining location must be lodged with the holder of its gold-dealing license no later than the tenth day of the month, unless specific permission has been granted by the mining commissioner or the appropriate minister. Any person intending to smelt gold or any article containing gold must first obtain a license issued by a district commissioner under the terms of the Secondhand Goods Act, which authorizes the possession of smelting equipment. Small-scale gold producers receive a support price of Z$16,000 a gram. There is no longer a gold support price for large-scale producers, but they may receive the support price for small-scale producers if they choose to be paid in Zimbabwe dollars. The exportation of gold in unmanufactured form is controlled and licensed by the Ministry of Mines; these controls do not apply to the RBZ. No export licenses for gold are issued. The importation of gold is controlled by the Gold Trade Act, which requires those intending to import gold into Zimbabwe to meet certain requirements. Residents may take out up to the equivalent of US$1,000 a day without Exchange Control approval and may take out up to the equivalent of US$600 a day for business travel and up to US$2,500 a year for holiday travel. Nonresident travelers may take out the traveler’s checks they brought in, minus the amount they sold to ADs. On departure, nonresident travelers may reconvert unspent Zimbabwean currency into foreign currency on presentation of exchange certificates. Effective May 2, 2008, ADs manage export proceeds and corporate foreign currency account (FCA) deposits. Previously, FCAs for all companies, including EPZ companies and nongovernmental organizations (NGOs), were kept with the RBZ; ADs maintained mirror accounts for their exporting clients. Effective October 2, 2007, exporters, including EPZ companies, may retain 65% of export proceeds in FCAs, since the portion of foreign currency received from exports of goods and services that must be sold in the foreign exchange market has been reduced to 35% from 40%. In addition, 10% of export earnings are directed toward the Fuel and Electricity Stabilization Fund (FESF). Tobacco prices are quoted in U.S. dollars at auctions; cotton and tobacco producers may retain, effective October 2, 2007, 25% (previously, 15%) of the sales in FCAs and receive the rest in the local currency equivalent at the interbank rate. Gold producers are allowed to deposit the same percentage of their proceeds in FCAs as exporters of other goods, and they receive the international price at the interbank rate for the remainder. Effective October 2, 2007, exporters, including EPZ companies and gold producers, may retain 65% of export proceeds (previously, 75%) in FCAs for 21 days; the remainder must be sold to the RBZ at the rate of Z$30,000 per US$1. At the end of that time, unused FCA balances must be sold in the interbank foreign exchange market. Previously, exporters were allowed to retain FCA balances for an indefinite period. Effective the same day, cotton and tobacco producers are allowed to retain 25% (previously, 15%) in FCAs. Corporate FCA holders (nonresident controlled companies and EPZ companies that are wholly financed from abroad) may use retained foreign exchange earnings for an indefinite period for purposes specified on a priority list and for other business-related expenses. An additional 10% of receipts must be paid to the FESF, to which the RBZ also contributes 10% from its 25% compulsory surrender. Effective May 2, 2008, the retention rate of export proceeds is linked to the increase in export revenues. Exporters with (1) a 0%–9% incremental export increase may retain 65%; (2) a 10%–19% incremental export increase may retain 75%; (3) a 20%–24% incremental export increase may retain 85%; (4) a 25%–29% incremental export increase may retain 90%; (5) a 30%–34% incremental export increase may retain 95%; and (6) an incremental export increase of 35% or more may retain 97.5% for their own use. A retention rate of 60% for incremental export proceeds applied during 2007. Effective October 2, 2007, exporters have the following options for investing their export proceeds with the RBZ: (1) The exporter may sell 100% of export proceeds to the RBZ at the prevailing exchange rate of Z$30,000 per US$1 and invest at the RBZ’s overnight window at a one-off overnight return of 800%. (2) The exporter may retain 65% and invest 35% at the overnight window. (3) The exporter may sell its FCA entitlement to the RBZ through the overnight investment window. Ten percent of export earnings are directed toward the FESF, effectively increasing the surrender requirement to 32.5%. The basic foreign exchange allowance for nonbusiness travel is US$2,500 a person a year regardless of age; the allowance for business travel is, effective May 2, 2008, US$600 (previously, US$500) a day. In practice, owing to the foreign exchange shortage, foreign exchange is not readily made available for nonbusiness travel. Yes. Foreign investors are permitted to participate in the Zimbabwe Stock Exchange (ZSE) using currency received in Zimbabwe through normal banking channels. Foreign investors may also subscribe for up to 35% of primary issues of bonds and stocks. Nonresidents are not permitted to purchase bonds and stocks on the secondary market. Former residents holding blocked assets and new emigrants are allowed to invest their funds in government external bonds with a maturity of 12 years and an annual interest rate of 4%. For investments prior to May 1993, under current legislation, disinvestment proceeds on the original amount of the investment may be remitted, but any capital appreciation that arises from revaluation of the investment goes to blocked funds, which are then converted into six-year bonds at a 4% interest rate, and a variable ratio of remittances is allowed, depending on the discount offered. However, if the amount of capital appreciation is small, it generally may be repatriated without restriction. Yes. 1596 ©International Monetary Fund. All foreign borrowing requires RBZ approval and prior approval of the External Loans Coordination Committee. These investments require RBZ and MOF approval on a case-by-case basis. Direct foreign investment in various sectors is subject to the approval of the Zimbabwe Investment Authority, normally with the following conditions: (1) Up to 100% foreign ownership is allowed in the following priority sectors: manufacturing, mining, quarry and mineral exploration, and development of hotels for tourism. (2) Up to 70% foreign shareholding is permitted in specialized services such as management consultancy and construction. (3) A maximum of 35% foreign ownership is allowed in selected sectors (reserved sector list), where foreign investors wishing to participate may do so only in joint-venture partnership with Zimbabwean firms or individuals. The reserved sector list comprises primary production of food and cash crops; primary horticulture; game, wildlife ranching, and livestock; forestry; fishing and fish farming; poultry farming; employment agencies; estate agencies; valet services; armaments manufacture, marketing, and distribution; public water provision for domestic and industrial purposes; rail operations; grain mill products; bakery products; sugar products; tobacco packaging and grading; and tobacco products. All foreign investment, irrespective of their source, undertaken through normal banking channels since May 1, 1993, may be repatriated. In all cases, specific applications must be submitted to the RBZ with respect to repatriation of capital. 1597 ©International Monetary Fund. Applications for emigrant status must be submitted to the RBZ; the settling-in allowance emigrants may remit abroad is limited to the equivalent of US$1,000 a person or US$2,000 a family. In exceptional cases, the exchange control authorities will consider applications exceeding this maximum. All those applying for emigrant status are required to liquidate their assets within six months of emigrating and invest the total proceeds, less any settling-in allowance granted, in 4%, 12-year Zimbabwe government external bonds. Lottery prizes due to nonresidents may be transferred, provided the funds that were used in betting were originally transferred into Zimbabwe in foreign currency. Not for Redistribution Exchange arrangement Arrangements for payments and receipts Resident accounts Exports and export proceeds Exchange arrangement Arrangements for payments and receipts Resident accounts ZIMBABWE Changes during 2007 October 2. The RBZ introduced the centralized allocation system for nonexporting users of foreign currency and for exporters with zero balances. All strategic imports are funded through allocation at the prevailing exchange rate. Foreign exchange for nonpriority imports may be purchased at the official exchange rate plus the RBZ’s mobilization and carrying costs as reflected by the overnight investment return. February 1. The limit for the export of local currency by resident travelers was increased to Z$100,000 (new currency) from Z$5,000. October 2. The limit for export and import of local currency in person or baggage by resident travelers was increased from Z$100,000 to Z$500 million. October 2. The portion of export proceeds that may be deposited by exporters, including EPZ companies, in FCAs was increased from 60% to 65%. October 2. The portion of foreign exchange proceeds cotton and tobacco producers may retain on FCAs was increased from 15% to 25%. October 2. The retention rate for cotton and tobacco producers was increased from 15% to 25% of foreign exchange receipts. October 2. The export proceeds retention rate for exporters, including EPZ companies and gold producers, was increased from 60% to 65%; the remainder must be sold to the RBZ at the rate of Z$30,000 per US$1. October 2. Exporters were allowed to invest their export proceeds with the RBZ under the following options: (1) The exporter may sell 100% of export proceeds to the RBZ at the prevailing exchange rate of Z$30,000 per US$1 and invest at the CB’s overnight window at a one-off overnight return of 800%. (2) The exporter may retain 65% and invest 35% at the overnight window. (3) The exporter may sell its FCA entitlement to the RBZ through the overnight investment window. Changes during 2008 May 2. A new market-determined foreign exchange pricing framework was introduced. ADs may match buyers and sellers of foreign exchange according to a predetermined list of priorities and are required to submit to the RBZ the details of the transactions they handle on a biweekly basis. May 2. The support price of Z$700 billion a kilogram on gold deliveries was eliminated. The new pricing structure is based on the previous day’s London gold afternoon fix price, calculated at the prevailing interbank exchange rate. May 2. ADs and MTAs were allowed to exchange foreign currency up to US$1,000 for local currency offered for sale by clients; excess foreign currency may be deposited in the client’s bank account. May 2. The limit for exportation and importation of local currency in person or baggage by resident travelers was increased from Z$500 million to Z$5 billion. May 2. Foreign currency and traveler’s checks were allowed to be sold or exchanged through MTAs under the enhanced framework for the operation of MTAs. January 31. The amount deposited in FCAs by resident individuals that is subject to declaration of source was increased from US$2,000 to US$10,000. 1600 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZIMBABWE May 2. The interest rate that can be earned on FCAs of companies and NGOs was set at 12%. May 2. The requirement that all companies, including EPZ companies and NGOs, keep their FCAs with the RBZ was eliminated, and ADs were allowed to manage export proceeds and corporate FCA deposits. May 2. Funds withdrawn from FCAs and converted into local currency may not be redeposited in an FCA, except for the amount of the initial investment and income or capital gains from investments in listed companies on the stock exchange or money market accounts. May 2. Exporters were required to use their FCA balances in 21 days; at the end of this period, FCA balances must be sold in the interbank market. May 2. Exporters were required to use their FCA balances in 21 days; at the end of this period, FCA balances must be sold in the interbank market. Previously, exporters were allowed to retain FCA balances for an indefinite period. May 2. The retention rate linked to the incremental increase in export proceeds was increased from 60%. Exporters with (1) a 0%–9% incremental export increase were allowed to retain 65%; (2) a 10%–19% incremental export increase were allowed to retain 75%; (3) a 20%–24 % incremental export increase were allowed to retain 85%; (4) 25%–29% incremental export increase were allowed to retain 90%; (5) a 30%–34% incremental export increase were allowed to retain 95%; and (6) an incremental export increase of 35% or more were allowed to retain 97.5% for their own use. May 2. The foreign exchange allowance for business travel was increased from US$500 to US$600 a day.
